Just a fortnight before Christmas , 1871 , [a young man , twenty - four years of age]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age , returned [home]103-home to [his]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age dinner about eight o’clock in the evening . [He]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age was married , and with [him]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age and [[his]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age wife]104-his wife lived [[his]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age wife ’s sister]105-his wife ’s sister . At that somewhat late hour [he]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age walked in among [the two young women]106-the two young women , and [another much older woman who was preparing the table for dinner]107-another much older woman who was preparing the table for dinner . [The wife]108-the wife and [[the wife]108-the wife ’s sister]110-the wife ’s sister each had [a child]111-a child in [her]108-the wife lap , [the elder having seen some fifteen months of its existence]112-the elder having seen some fifteen months of its existence , and [the younger three months]113-the younger three months . “ [He]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age has been out since seven , and [I]108-the wife do n’t think [he]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age ’s had a mouthful , ”[108-the wife] [the wife]108-the wife had just said . “ Oh , [Harry]37-harry , [you]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age must be half starved , ”[108-the wife] [she]108-the wife exclaimed , jumping up to greet [him]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age , and throwing [her]108-the wife arm round [his]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age bare neck . “ [I]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age ’m about whole melted , ”[102-a young man , twenty - four years of age] [he]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age said , as [he]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age kissed [her]108-the wife . “ In the name of charity give [me]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age a nobbler . [I]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age did get a bit of damper and a pannikin of tea up at [the German ’s hut]1415-the german ’s hut ; but [I]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age never was so hot or so thirsty in [my]102-a young man , twenty - four years of age life . [We]1416-we ’re going to have it in earnest this time . [Old Bates]38-old bates says that when the gum leaves crackle , as they do now , before Christmas , there wo n’t be a blade of grass by the end of February . ”[102-a young man , twenty - four years of age] “ [I]108-the wife hate [Old Bates]38-old bates , ”[108-the wife] said [the wife]108-the wife . “ [He]38-old bates always prophesies evil , and complains about [his]38-old bates rations . ”[108-the wife] “ [He]38-old bates knows more about sheep than [any man this side of [the Mary]40-mary]1417-any man this side of the mary , ”[116-her husband] said [[her]108-the wife husband]116-her husband . From all this [I]0-i trust [the reader]117-the reader will understand that the Christmas to which [he]116-her husband is introduced is not the Christmas with which [he]116-her husband is intimate on [this side of the equator]118-this side of the equator — a Christmas of blazing fires in - doors , and of sleet arid snow and frost outside — but the Christmas of [Australia]2-australia , in which [happy land]119-happy land the Christmas fires are apt to be lighted — or to light themselves — when they are by no means needed . [The young man]120-the young man who had just returned [home]103-home had on a flannel shirt , a pair of mole - skin trowsers , and an old straw hat , battered nearly out of all shape . [He]120-the young man had no coat , no waistcoat , no braces , and nothing round [his]120-the young man neck . Round [his]120-the young man waist there was a strap or belt , from the front of which hung a small pouch , and , behind , a knife in a case . And stuck into a loop in the belt , made for the purpose , there was a small brier - wood pipe . As [he]120-the young man dashed [his]120-the young man hat off , wiped [his]120-the young man brow , and threw [himself]120-the young man into a rocking - chair , [he]120-the young man certainly was rough to look at , but by all who understood [Australian]3-australian life [he]120-the young man would have been taken to be [a gentleman]122-a gentleman . [He]120-the young man was [a young squatter , well known [west of [the Mary River]4-the mary river]124-west of the mary river , in [Queensland]5-queensland]123-a young squatter , well known west of the mary river , in queensland . [Harry Heathcote of Gangoil]65-harry , who owned 30,000 sheep of [his]65-harry own , was [a magistrate in those parts]125-a magistrate in those parts , and able to hold [his]65-harry own among [[his]65-harry neighbors]126-his neighbors , whether rough or gentle ; and [some neighbors]127-some neighbors [he]65-harry had , very rough , who made it almost necessary that [a man]128-a man should be able to be rough also , on occasions , if [he]128-a man desired to live among [them]127-some neighbors without injury . [[Heathcote]65-harry of [Gangoil]65-harry]129-heathcote of gangoil could do all that . [Men]130-men said of [him]65-harry that [he]65-harry was too imperious , too masterful , too much inclined to think that all things should be made to go as [he]65-harry would have [them]131-them . Young as [he]65-harry was , [he]65-harry had been altogether [[his]65-harry own master]132-his own master since [he]65-harry was of age — and not only [[his]65-harry own master]132-his own master , but [the master also of all with whom [he]65-harry was brought into contact from day to day]134-the master also of all with whom he was brought into contact from day to day . In [his]65-harry life [he]65-harry conversed but seldom with any but [those who were dependent on [him]65-harry , nor had [he]65-harry done so for the last three years . At an age at which [young men]136-young men at [home]103-home are still subject to [pastors]138-pastors and [masters]139-masters]135-those who were dependent on him , nor had he done so for the last three years . at an age at which young men at home are still subject to pastors and masters , [he]65-harry had sprung at once into patriarchal power , and , being [a man determined to thrive]140-a man determined to thrive , had become laborious and thoughtful beyond [his]65-harry years . [Harry Heathcote]65-harry had been left [an orphan]141-an orphan , with a small fortune in money , when [he]65-harry was fourteen . For two years after that [he]65-harry had consented to remain quietly at [school]142-school , but at sixteen [he]65-harry declared [his]65-harry purpose of emigrating . [Boys less than [himself]65-harry in stature]143-boys less than himself in stature got above [him]65-harry at [school]142-school , and [he]65-harry had not liked it . For a twelvemonth [he]65-harry was opposed by [[his]65-harry guardian]145-his guardian ; but at the end of the year [he]65-harry was fitted forth for [the colony]146-the colony . [The guardian]147-the guardian was not sorry to be quit of [him]65-harry , but prophesied that [he]65-harry would be [home]103-home again before a year was over . [The lad]149-the lad had not returned , and it was now a settled conviction among all who knew [him]65-harry that [he]65-harry would make or mar [his]65-harry fortune in [the new land that [he]65-harry had chosen]150-the new land that he had chosen . [He]149-the lad was [a tall , well - made young fellow , with fair hair and a good - humored smile]151-a tall , well - made young fellow , with fair hair and a good - humored smile , but ever carrying in [his]149-the lad countenance marks of what [[his]149-the lad enemies]152-his enemies called pig - headedness , [[his]149-the lad acquaintances]153-his acquaintances obstinacy , and [those who loved [him]149-the lad firmness]154-those who loved him firmness . [[His]149-the lad acquaintances]153-his acquaintances were , perhaps , right , for [he]149-the lad certainly was obstinate . [He]149-the lad would take [no man]156-no man ’s advice , [he]149-the lad would submit [himself]149-the lad to [no man]156-no man , and in the conduct of [his]149-the lad own business preferred to trust to [his]149-the lad own insight than to the experience of [others]158-others . It would sometimes occur that [he]149-the lad had to pay heavily for [his]149-the lad obstinacy . But , on the other hand , the lessons which [he]149-the lad learned [he]149-the lad learned thoroughly . And [he]149-the lad was kept right in [his]149-the lad trade by [his]149-the lad own indefatigable industry . That trade was the growth of wool . [He]149-the lad was [a breeder of sheep on [a Queensland sheep - run]160-a queensland sheep - run]159-a breeder of sheep on a queensland sheep - run , and [his]149-the lad flocks ran far afield over [a vast territory of which [he]149-the lad was [the only lord]162-the only lord]161-a vast territory of which he was the only lord . [[His]149-the lad house]163-his house was near [the river]164-the river [Mary]40-mary , and beyond [the river]164-the river [his]149-the lad domain did not extend ; but around [him]149-the lad on [[his]149-the lad own side of [the river]164-the river]166-his own side of the river [he]149-the lad could ride for ten miles in each direction without getting off [[his]149-the lad own pastures]168-his own pastures . [He]149-the lad was [master]169-master , as far as [his]149-the lad mastership went , of 120,000 acres — almost [an English county]170-an english county — and it was the pride of [his]149-the lad heart to put [his]149-the lad foot off [[his]149-the lad own territory]171-his own territory as seldom as possible . [He]149-the lad sent [his]149-the lad wool annually down to [Brisbane]7-brisbane , and received [[his]149-the lad stores]172-his stores , tea and sugar , flour and brandy , boots , clothes , tobacco , etc . , once or twice a year from thence . But the traffic did not require [his]149-the lad own presence at [the city]173-the city . So self - contained was the working of the establishment that [he]149-the lad was never called away by [his]149-the lad business , unless [he]149-the lad went to see some lot of highly bred sheep which [he]149-the lad might feel disposed to buy ; and as for pleasure , it had come to be altogether beyond the purpose of [his]149-the lad life to go in quest of that . When the work of the day was over , [he]149-the lad would lie at [his]149-the lad length upon rugs in [the veranda]174-the veranda , with a pipe in [his]149-the lad mouth , while [[his]149-the lad wife]104-his wife sat over [him]149-the lad reading a play of Shakspeare or the last novel that had come to [them]176-them from [England]8-england . [He]149-the lad had married [a fair girl]177-a fair girl , [the orphan daughter of [a bankrupt squatter whom [he]149-the lad had met in [Sydney]9-sydney]179-a bankrupt squatter whom he had met in sydney , and had brought [her]177-a fair girl and [[her]177-a fair girl sister]180-her sister into [the Queensland bush]181-the queensland bush with [him]149-the lad]178-the orphan daughter of a bankrupt squatter whom he had met in sydney , and had brought her and her sister into the queensland bush with him . [[His]149-the lad wife]104-his wife idolized [him]149-the lad . [[His]149-the lad sister - in - law]183-his sister - in - law , [Kate Daly]41-kate , loved [him]149-the lad dearly — as [she]41-kate had cause to do , for [he]149-the lad had proved [himself]149-the lad to be [a very brother to [her]41-kate]184-a very brother to her ; but [she]41-kate feared [him]149-the lad also somewhat . [The people about the Mary]185-the people about the mary said that [she]41-kate was fairer and sweeter to look at even than [the elder sister]186-the elder sister . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was the taller of the two , and the larger - featured . [She]42-mrs. heathcote certainly was the higher in intellect , and the fittest to be [the mistress of [such an establishment as that at [Gangoil]65-harry]188-such an establishment as that at gangoil]187-the mistress of such an establishment as that at gangoil . When [he]149-the lad had washed [his]149-the lad hands and face , and had swallowed the very copious but weak allowance of brandy - and - water which [[his]149-the lad wife]104-his wife mixed for [him]149-the lad , [he]149-the lad took [the eldest boy]190-the eldest boy on [his]149-the lad lap and fondled [him]190-the eldest boy . “ By [George]43-georgie ! ”[149-the lad] [he]149-the lad said , “ [old fellow]1418-old fellow , [you]43-georgie sha’n’t be [a squatter]1419-a squatter . ”[149-the lad] “ Why not , [Harry]65-harry ? ”[104-his wife] asked [[his]149-the lad wife]104-his wife . “ Because [I]104-his wife do n’t want [him]190-the eldest boy to break [his]190-the eldest boy heart every day of [his]190-the eldest boy life . ”[104-his wife] “ Are [you]65-harry always breaking [yours]65-harry ? [I]149-the lad thought [your]65-harry heart was pretty well hardened now . ”[149-the lad] “ When [a man]128-a man talks of [his]128-a man heart , [you]65-harry and [Kate]41-kate are thinking of loves and doves , of course . ”[104-his wife] “ [I]41-kate was n’t thinking of loves and doves , [Harry]65-harry , ”[41-kate] said [Kate]41-kate . “ [I]41-kate was thinking how very hot it must have been to - day . [We]1421-we could only bear it in [the veranda]174-the veranda by keeping the blinds always wet . [I]41-kate do n’t wonder that [you]65-harry were troubled . ”[41-kate] “ That comes from heaven or [Providence]44-providence , or from something that one knows to be unassailable , and therefore [one]1423-one can put up with it . Even if [one]1423-one gets a sun - stroke [one]1423-one does not complain . The sun has a right to be there , and is [no interloper]1426-no interloper , like a free - selector . [I]104-his wife ca n’t understand why free - selectors and mosquitoes should have been introduced into the arrangements of [the world]1427-the world . ”[104-his wife] “ [I]45-mrs. growler s’pose [the poor]1428-the poor must live somewheres , and ‘ squiters too , ”[45-mrs. growler] said [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , [the old maid - servant]192-the old maid - servant , as [she]45-mrs. growler put a boiled leg of mutton on the table . “ Now , [Mr. Harry]37-harry , if [you]37-harry ’re hungered , there ’s something for [you]37-harry to eat in spite of the free - selectors . ”[45-mrs. growler] “ [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , ”[193-the master] said [the master]193-the master , “ excuse [me]193-the master for saying that [you]45-mrs. growler jump to conclusions . ”[193-the master] “ [My]194-the old woman jumping is pretty well - nigh done , ”[194-the old woman] said [the old woman]194-the old woman . “ By no means . [I]194-the old woman find that [old people]1429-old people can jump quite as briskly as [young]1430-young . [You]37-harry have rebuked [me]194-the old woman under the impression that [I]194-the old woman was grudging something to [the poor]1428-the poor . Let [me]194-the old woman explain to [you]37-harry that [a free - selector]1432-a free - selector may be , and very often is , [a rich man]1433-a rich man . [He]1433-a rich man whom [I]194-the old woman had in [my]194-the old woman mind is not [a poor man]1434-a poor man , though [I]194-the old woman wo n’t swear but what [he]1433-a rich man will be before a year is over . ”[194-the old woman] “ [I]193-the master know who [you]37-harry mean , [Mr. Harry]37-harry ; [you]37-harry mean [the Medlicots]46-the medlicots . [A very nice gentleman]1435-a very nice gentleman is [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , and [a very nice old lady]1436-a very nice old lady is [Mrs. Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot . And a deal of good [they]196-the two ladies ’re going to do , by all accounts . ”[193-the master] “ Now , [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , that will do , ”[108-the wife] said [the wife]108-the wife . The dinner consisted of a boiled leg of mutton , a large piece of roast beef , potatoes , onions , and an immense pot of tea . No glasses were even put upon the table . [The two ladies]196-the two ladies had dressed for dinner , and were bright and pretty as [they]196-the two ladies would have been in [a country house]197-a country house at [home]103-home ; but [Harry Heathcote]65-harry had sat down just as [he]65-harry had entered [the room]199-the room . “ [I]104-his wife know [you]65-harry are tired to death , ”[104-his wife] said [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife , “ when [I]104-his wife see [you]65-harry eat [your]65-harry dinner like that . ”[104-his wife] “ It is n’t being tired , [Mary]40-mary ; [I]104-his wife ’m not particularly tired . But [I]104-his wife must be off again in about an hour . ”[104-his wife] “ Out again to - night ? ”[104-his wife] “ Yes , indeed . ”[104-his wife] “ On horseback ? ”[104-his wife] “ How else ? [Old Bates]38-old bates and [Mickey]49-mickey are in [their]196-the two ladies saddles still . [I]104-his wife do n’t want to have [my]104-his wife fences burned as soon as [they]196-the two ladies ’re put up . It ’s a ticklish thing to think that a spark of fire any where about [the place]1437-the place might ruin [me]104-his wife , and to know at the same time that [every man about the run]1438-every man about the run and [every swagsman that passes along]1439-every swagsman that passes along have matches in [their]196-the two ladies pocket . There is n’t a pipe lighted on [Gangoil]65-harry this time of the year that might n’t make [a beggar of [you]1441-you and [me]104-his wife]1440-a beggar of you and me . That ’s another reason why [I]104-his wife would n’t have [the young un a squatter]1442-the young un a squatter . ”[104-his wife] “ — [I]41-kate declare [I]41-kate think that [squatters]1443-squatters have more trouble than [any people in [the world]1427-the world]1444-any people in the world , ”[41-kate] said [Kate Daly]41-kate . “ — Free - selectors have [their]1443-squatters own troubles too , [Kate]41-kate , ”[201-he] said [he]201-he . It must be explained as [we]202-we go on that [Heathcote]65-harry felt that [he]65-harry had received a great and peculiar grievance from the hands of [one Medlicot]203-one medlicot , [a stranger who had lately settled near [him]65-harry]204-a stranger who had lately settled near him , and that this last remark referred to a somewhat favorable opinion which had been expressed about [this stranger]205-this stranger by [the two ladies]196-the two ladies . It was a little unfair , as having been addressed specially to [Kate]41-kate , intending as it did to imply that [Kate]41-kate had better consider the matter well before [she]41-kate allowed [her]41-kate opinion of [the stranger]207-the stranger to become dangerously favorable ; for in truth [she]41-kate had said no more than [[her]41-kate sister]180-her sister . “ [The Medlicots]46-the medlicots ’ troubles will never trouble [me]41-kate , [Harry]65-harry , ”[41-kate] [she]41-kate said . “ [I]41-kate hope not , [Kate]41-kate ; nor [mine]41-kate either more than [we]1446-we can help . ”[41-kate] “ But [they]1447-they do , ”[40-mary] said [Mary]40-mary . “ [They]1447-they trouble [me]40-mary , and [her]40-mary too , very much . ”[40-mary] “ [A man]128-a man ’s back should be broad enough to bear all that for [himself]128-a man , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry . “ [I]65-harry get ashamed of [myself]65-harry when [I]65-harry grumble , and yet [one]1423-one seems to be surly if [one]1423-one does n’t say what [one]1423-one ’s thinking . ”[65-harry] “ [I]40-mary hope [you]41-kate ’ll always tell [me]40-mary what [you]41-kate ’re thinking , [dear]1452-dear . ”[40-mary] “ Well , [I]40-mary suppose [I]40-mary shall — till [this fellow]1453-this fellow is old enough to be talked to , and to be made to bear the burden of [[his]1453-this fellow father]1454-his father ’s care . ”[40-mary] “ By that time , [Harry]65-harry , [you]65-harry will have got rich , and [we]1455-we shall all be in [England]8-england , sha’n’t [we]1455-we ? ”[65-harry] “ [I]40-mary do n’t know about being rich , but [we]1455-we shall have been free - selected off [Gangoil.—Now]50-gangoil.—now , [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , [we]1455-we ’ve done dinner , and [I]40-mary ’ll have a pipe before [I]40-mary make another start . Is [Jacko]51-jacko in [the kitchen]1456-the kitchen ? Send [him]51-jacko through to [me]40-mary on to [the veranda]174-the veranda . ”[40-mary] [Gangoil]65-harry was decidedly in the bush — according to common Australian parlance , [all sheep stations]209-all sheep stations are in the bush , even though there should not be a tree or shrub within sight . [[They]210-they who live away from [the towns]212-the towns]211-they who live away from the towns live a “ bush life . ”[65-harry] [Small towns]213-small towns , as [they]213-small towns grow up , are called [bush towns]214-bush towns , as [we]215-we talk of [country towns]216-country towns . [The “ bush]1458-the “ bush , ”[65-harry] indeed , is [the country]217-the country generally . But [the Heathcotes]52-the heathcotes lived absolutely and actually in [the bush]218-the bush . There are [Australian pastures which consist of [plains on which not a tree is to be seen for miles]220-plains on which not a tree is to be seen for miles]219-australian pastures which consist of plains on which not a tree is to be seen for miles ; but others are forests , so far extending that [their]221-their limits are almost unknown . [Gangoil]65-harry was surrounded by forest , in some places so close as to be impervious to [men]130-men and almost to animals in which the undergrowth was thick and tortuous and almost platted , through which no path could be made without an axe , but of which the greater portions were open , without any under - wood , between which [the sheep]223-the sheep could wander at [their]223-the sheep will , and [men]130-men could ride , with a sparse surface of coarse grass , which after rain would be luxuriant , but in hot weather would be scorched down to the ground . At such times — and those times were by far the more common — [a stranger]225-a stranger would wonder where the sheep would find [their]223-the sheep feed . Immediately round [the house]226-the house , or station , as [it]227-it was called , about one hundred acres had been cleared , or nearly cleared , with a few trees left here and there for ornament or shade . Further afield , but still round [the home quarters]228-the home quarters , the trees had been destroyed , the run of the sap having been stopped by “ ringing ”[128-a man] the bark ; but they still stood like troops of skeletons , and would stand , very ugly to look at , till they fell , in the course of nature , by reason of [their]221-their own rottenness . There was [a man]128-a man always at work about [the place]1437-the place — [Boscobel]53-boscobel [he]128-a man was called — whose sole business was to destroy the timber after this fashion , so that the air might get through to the grasses , and that the soil might be relieved from the burden of nurturing the forest trees . For miles around [the domain]231-the domain was divided into [paddocks]232-paddocks , as [they]232-paddocks were there called ; but these were so large that [a stranger]225-a stranger might wander in one of them for a day and never discover that [he]225-a stranger was inclosed . There were [five or six paddocks on [the Gangoil run]235-the gangoil run]234-five or six paddocks on the gangoil run , each of which comprised over ten thousand acres , and as [all the land]236-all the land was undulating , and as the timber was around [you]237-you every where , [one paddock]238-one paddock was exactly like another . The scenery in itself was fine , for the trees were often large , and here and there [rocky knolls]239-rocky knolls would crop up , and there were broken crevices in the ground ; but it was all alike . [A stranger]225-a stranger would wonder that [any one straying from [the house]226-the house]241-any one straying from the house should find [his]225-a stranger way back to [it]226-the house . There were [sundry bush houses]243-sundry bush houses here and there , and the so - called road to [the coast]244-the coast from [the wide pastoral districts further west]245-the wide pastoral districts further west passed across the run ; but [these roads]246-these roads and tracks would travel hither and thither , new tracks being opened from time to time by [the heavy wool drays and store wagons]247-the heavy wool drays and store wagons , as in wet weather the ruts on [the old tracks]248-the old tracks would become insurmountable . [The station]249-the station itself was certainly very pretty . [It]249-the station consisted of [a cluster of [cottages]251-cottages]250-a cluster of cottages , each of which possessed a ground - floor only . No such luxury as stairs was known at [Gangoil]65-harry . [It]249-the station stood about half a mile from [the Mary River]4-the mary river , on the edge of [a creek which ran into [it]249-the station]252-a creek which ran into it . [The principal edifice]253-the principal edifice , that in which [the Heathcotes]52-the heathcotes lived , contained only [one sitting - room]254-one sitting - room , and [a bedroom on each side of [it]253-the principal edifice]255-a bedroom on each side of it ; but in truth there was [another room , very spacious , in which [the family]257-the family really passed [their]257-the family time]256-another room , very spacious , in which the family really passed their time ; and this was [the veranda which ran along the front and two ends of [the house]226-the house]258-the veranda which ran along the front and two ends of the house . [It]258-the veranda which ran along the front and two ends of the house was twelve feet broad , and , of course , of great length . [Here]260-here was clustered the rocking - chairs , and sofas , and work - tables , and very often the cradle of [the family]257-the family . Here stood [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ’s sewing - machine , and here [the master]193-the master would sprawl at [his]193-the master length , while [[his]193-the master wife]104-his wife , or [[[his]193-the master wife]104-his wife ’s sister]105-his wife ’s sister , read to [him]193-the master . It was here , in fact , that [they]257-the family lived , having [a parlor simply for [their]257-the family meals]266-a parlor simply for their meals . Behind [the main edifice]267-the main edifice there stood , each apart , [various buildings]268-various buildings , forming an irregular quadrangle . [The kitchen]1456-the kitchen came first , with [a small adjacent chamber in which slept [the Chinese man - cook]271-the chinese man - cook , [Sing Sing]54-sing sing , as [he]271-the chinese man - cook had come to be called]270-a small adjacent chamber in which slept the chinese man - cook , sing sing , as he had come to be called ; then [the cottage]272-the cottage , consisting also of [three rooms]273-three rooms and [a small veranda]274-a small veranda , in which lived [[Harry]65-harry ’s superintendent]275-harry ’s superintendent , commonly known as [Old Bates]38-old bates , [a man who had been [a squatter]1419-a squatter once [himself]38-old bates , and having lost [his]38-old bates all in bad times]276-a man who had been a squatter once himself , and having lost his all in bad times , now worked for a small salary . In [the cottage]272-the cottage [two of [the rooms]280-the rooms]279-two of the rooms were devoted to hospitality when , as was not unusual , [guests]281-guests , known or unknown , came that way ; and here [Harry]65-harry [himself]65-harry would sleep , if the entertainment of [other ladies]282-other ladies crowded [the best apartments]283-the best apartments . Then at the back of [the quadrangle]284-the quadrangle was [the store]285-the store , perhaps of all the buildings the most important . In [here]260-here was kept a kind of shop , which was supposed , according to an obsolete rule , to be open for custom for half a day twice a week . [The exigencies of [the station]249-the station]287-the exigencies of the station did not allow of this regularity ; but after some fashion [the shop]289-the shop was maintained . Tea was to be bought [there]290-there , and sugar , tobacco , and pickles , jam , nails , boots , hats , flannel shirrs , and mole - skin trowsers . Any body who came might buy , but the intention was to provide [the station hands , who would otherwise have had to go or send thirty miles for the supply of [their]291-the station hands , who would otherwise have had to go or send thirty miles for the supply of their wants wants]291-the station hands , who would otherwise have had to go or send thirty miles for the supply of their wants . Very little money was taken here , generally none . But the quantity of pickles , jam , and tobacco sold was great . [The men]292-the men would consume large quantities of these bush delicacies , and the cost would be deducted from [their]292-the men wages . The tea and sugar , and flour also , were given out weekly , as rations — so much a week — and meat was supplied to [them]292-the men after the same fashion . For it was the duty of [this young autocratic patriarch]293-this young autocratic patriarch to find provisions for [all who were employed around [him]293-this young autocratic patriarch]294-all who were employed around him . For such luxuries as jam and tobacco [the men]292-the men paid [themselves]292-the men . On the fourth side of [the quadrangle]284-the quadrangle was [a rough coach - house]297-a rough coach - house , and [rougher stables]298-rougher stables . [The carriage part of [the establishment]300-the establishment]299-the carriage part of the establishment consisted of two “ buggies”—so[302-the other four sitters] called always in the bush — [open carriages on four wheels]301-open carriages on four wheels , one of which was intended to hold two and [the other four sitters]302-the other four sitters . [A Londoner]303-a londoner looking at [them]304-them would have declared [them]304-them to be hopeless ruins ; but [Harry Heathcote]65-harry still made wonderful journeys in them , taking care generally that the wheels were sound , and using ropes for the repair of dilapidations . [The stables]305-the stables were almost unnecessary , as the horses , of which the supply at [Gangoil]65-harry was very large , roamed in [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock , [a comparatively small inclosure containing not above three or four hundred acres]307-a comparatively small inclosure containing not above three or four hundred acres , and were driven up as [they]308-they were wanted . One horse was always kept close at [home]103-home with which to catch the others ; but this horse , for handiness , was generally hitched to a post outside the kitchen door . [Harry]65-harry was proud of [his]65-harry horses , and was sometimes heard to say that [few men in [England]8-england]310-few men in england had a lot of thirty at hand as [he]65-harry had , out of which so many would be able to carry [a man]128-a man eighty miles in eight hours at a moment ’s notice . But [his]65-harry stable arrangements would not have commanded respect in [the “ Shires]1459-the “ shires . ”[65-harry] The animals were never groomed , never fed , and many of [them]312-they never shod . [They]312-they lived upon grass , and , [Harry]65-harry always said , “ cut [their]312-they own bread - and - butter for [themselves]312-they . ”[65-harry] [Gangoil]65-harry was certainly very pretty . [The veranda]174-the veranda was covered in with striped blinds , so that when the sun shone hot , or when the rains fell heavily , or when the mosquitoes were more than usually troublesome , there might be something of the protection of [an inclosed room]314-an inclosed room . Up all the posts there were flowering creepers , which covered the front with greenery even when the flowers were wanting . From the front of [the house]226-the house down to [the creek]316-the creek there was [a pleasant failing garden]317-a pleasant failing garden — heart - breaking , indeed , in regard to vegetables , for the opossums always came first , and [they]312-they who followed [the opossums]318-the opossums got but little . But [the garden]319-the garden gave a pleasant home - like look to [the place]1437-the place , and was very dear to [Harry]65-harry , who was , perhaps , indifferent in regard to pease and tomatoes . [Harry Heathcote]65-harry was very proud of [the place]1437-the place , for [he]65-harry had made it all [himself]65-harry , having pulled down [a wretched barrack that [he]65-harry had found [there]290-there]322-a wretched barrack that he had found there . But [he]65-harry was far prouder of [[his]65-harry wool - shed]324-his wool - shed , which [he]65-harry had also built , and which [he]65-harry regarded as first and foremost among [wool - sheds in [those parts]326-those parts]325-wool - sheds in those parts . By - and - by [we]327-we shall be called on to visit [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed . Though [Heathcote]65-harry had done all this for [Gangoil]65-harry , it must be understood that the vast extent of territory over which [his]65-harry sheep ran was by no means [[his]65-harry own property]329-his own property . [He]65-harry was simply [the tenant of the Crown]330-the tenant of the crown , paying a rent computed at so much a sheep . [He]65-harry had , indeed , purchased the ground on which [[his]65-harry house]163-his house stood , but this [he]65-harry had done simply to guard [himself]65-harry against [other purchasers]332-other purchasers . [These other purchasers]333-these other purchasers were the bane of [his]65-harry existence , the one great sorrow which , as [he]65-harry said , broke [his]65-harry heart . While [he]65-harry was speaking , [a rough - looking lad , about sixteen years of age]334-a rough - looking lad , about sixteen years of age , came through [the parlor]335-the parlor to [the veranda]174-the veranda , dressed very much like [[his]334-a rough - looking lad , about sixteen years of age master]337-his master , but unwashed , uncombed , and with that wild look which falls upon those who wander about [the Australian plains]338-the australian plains , living a nomad life . This was [Jacko]51-jacko — so called , and [no one]339-no one knew [him]51-jacko by any other name — [a lad whom [Heathcote]65-harry had picked up about six months since , and who had become a favorite]340-a lad whom heathcote had picked up about six months since , and who had become a favorite . “ [The old woman]194-the old woman says as [you]65-harry was wanting [me]51-jacko ? ”[51-jacko] suggested [Jacko]51-jacko . “ Going to be fine to - night , [Jacko]51-jacko ? ”[51-jacko] [Jacko]51-jacko went to the edge of [the veranda]174-the veranda and looked up to the sky . “ [My]51-jacko word ! little squall a - coming , ”[51-jacko] [he]51-jacko said . “ [I]193-the master wish it would come from ten thousand buckets , ”[193-the master] said [the master]193-the master . “ No buckets at all , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . “ Want the horses , [master]169-master ? ”[51-jacko] “ Of course . [I]65-harry want the horses , and [I]65-harry want [you]65-harry to come with [me]65-harry . There are two horses saddled [there]290-there ; [I]65-harry ’ll ride [Hamlet]55-hamlet . ”[65-harry] [Harry]65-harry jumped from the ground , kissed [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife , called [her]104-his wife “ [old girl]1463-old girl , ”[104-his wife] and told [her]104-his wife to be happy , and got on [his]65-harry horse at the garden gate . [Both the ladies]344-both the ladies came off [the veranda]174-the veranda to see [him]65-harry start . “ It ’s as dark as pitch , ”[41-kate] said [Kate Daly]41-kate . “ That ’s because [you]65-harry have just come out of the light . ”[41-kate] “ But it is dark — quite dark . [You]65-harry wo n’t be late , will [you]65-harry ? ”[108-the wife] said [the wife]108-the wife . “ [I]108-the wife ca n’t be very early , as it ’s near ten now . [I]108-the wife shall be back about twelve . ”[108-the wife] So saying , [he]65-harry broke at once into a gallop , and vanished into the night , [[his]65-harry young groom]347-his young groom scampering after [him]65-harry . “ Why should [he]65-harry go out now ? ”[41-kate] [Kate]41-kate said to [[her]41-kate sister]180-her sister . “ [He]65-harry is afraid of fire . ”[41-kate] “ But [he]65-harry ca n’t prevent the fires by riding about in the dark . [I]180-her sister suppose the fires come from the heat . ”[180-her sister] “ [He]65-harry thinks they come from [enemies]1464-enemies , and [he]65-harry has heard something . [One wretched man]1465-one wretched man may do so much when every thing is dried to tinder . [I]41-kate do so wish it would rain . ”[41-kate] The night , in truth , was very dark . It was now midsummer , at which time with [us]349-they the days are so long that the coming of the one almost catches the departure of its predecessor . But [Gangoil]65-harry was not far outside [the tropics]350-the tropics , and there were no long summer nights . The heat was intense ; but there was a low soughing wind which seemed to moan among the trees without moving them . As [they]349-they crossed [the little home inclosure]351-the little home inclosure and [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock , [the track]353-the track was just visible , the trees being dead and the spaces open . About half a mile from [the house]226-the house , while [they]349-they were still in [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock , [Harry]65-harry turned from [the track]353-the track , and [Jacko]51-jacko , of course , turned with [him]65-harry . “ [You]51-jacko can sit [your]51-jacko horse jumping , [Jacko]51-jacko ? ”[51-jacko] [he]51-jacko asked . “ [My]51-jacko word ! jump like glory , ”[51-jacko] answered [Jacko]51-jacko . [He]51-jacko was soon tried . [Harry]65-harry rode at the bush fence — which was not , indeed , much of a fence , made of logs lengthways and crossways , about three feet and a half high — and went over [it]357-it . [Jacko]51-jacko followed [him]65-harry , rushing [his]51-jacko horse at the leap , losing [his]51-jacko seat and almost falling over the animal ’s shoulders as [he]51-jacko came to the ground . “ [My]51-jacko word ! ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko , just saving [himself]51-jacko by a scramble ; “ who ever saw the like of that ? ”[51-jacko] “ Why do n’t [you]51-jacko sit in [your]51-jacko saddle , [[you]51-jacko stupid young duffer]1466-you stupid young duffer ? ”[51-jacko] “ Sit in [my]51-jacko saddle ! Why do n’t [he]65-harry jump proper ? Well , [you]51-jacko go on . [I]51-jacko do n’t know that [I]51-jacko ’m [a duffer]1467-a duffer . [Duffer]56-duffer , indeed ! [My]51-jacko word ! ”[51-jacko] [Heathcote]65-harry had turned to the left , leaving the track , which was , indeed , [the main road toward [the nearest town]359-the nearest town and [the coast]244-the coast]358-the main road toward the nearest town and the coast , and was now pushing on through [the forest]361-the forest with no pathway at all to guide [him]65-harry . To ordinary eyes the attempt to steer any course would have been hopeless . But [an Australian squatter]362-an australian squatter , if [he]362-an australian squatter have any well - grounded claim to the character of [a bushman]363-a bushman , has eyes which are not ordinary , and [he]362-an australian squatter has , probably , nurtured within [himself]362-an australian squatter , unconsciously , topographical instincts which are unintelligible to [the inhabitants of [cities]365-cities]364-the inhabitants of cities . [Harry]65-harry , too , was near [[his]65-harry own home]366-his own home , and went forward through the thick gloom without a doubt , [Jacko]51-jacko following [him]65-harry faithfully . In about half an hour [they]367-they came to another fence , but now it was too absolutely dark for jumping . [Harry]65-harry had not seen it till [he]65-harry was close to [it]368-it , and then [he]65-harry pulled up [his]65-harry horse . “ [My]65-harry word ! why do n’t [you]65-harry jump away , [Mr. Harry]37-harry ? Who ’s a duffer now ? ”[65-harry] “ Hold [your]65-harry tongue , or [I]51-jacko ’ll put [my]51-jacko whip across [your]65-harry back . Get down and help [me]51-jacko pull a log away . The horses could n’t see where to put [their]370-the two feet . ”[51-jacko] [Jacko]51-jacko did as [he]51-jacko was bid , and worked hard , but still grumbled at having been called [a duffer]1467-a duffer . The animals were quickly led over , the logs were replaced , and [the two]370-the two were again galloping through [the forest]361-the forest . “ [I]51-jacko thought [you]51-jacko were making for [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . “ [We]370-the two ’re eight miles beyond [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , ”[37-harry] said [Harry]37-harry . [They]370-the two had now crossed [another paddock]372-another paddock , and had come to the extreme fence on the run . [The Gangoil pastures]373-the gangoil pastures extended much further , but in that direction had not as yet been inclosed . Here [they]370-the two both got off [their]370-the two horses and walked along the fence till [they]370-the two came to an opening , with a slip panel , or movable bars , which had been [[Heathcote]65-harry ’s intended destination]374-heathcote ’s intended destination . “ Hold the horses , [Jacko]51-jacko , till [I]37-harry come back , ”[37-harry] [he]37-harry said . [Jacko]51-jacko , when alone , nothing daunted by the darkness or solitude , seated [himself]51-jacko on the top rail , took out a pipe , and struck a match . When the tobacco was ignited [he]51-jacko dropped the match on the dry grass at [his]51-jacko feet , and a little flame instantly sprang up . [The boy]375-the boy waited a few seconds till the flames began to run , and then putting [his]375-the boy feet together on the ground stamped out the incipient fire . “ [My]51-jacko word ! ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko to [himself]51-jacko , “ it ’s easy done , anyway . ”[51-jacko] [Harry]37-harry went on to the left for about half a mile , and then stood leaning against the fence . It was very dark , but [he]37-harry was now looking over into an inclosure which had been altogether cleared of trees , and which , as [he]37-harry knew well , had been cultivated and was covered with sugar - canes . Where [he]37-harry stood [he]37-harry was not distant above a quarter of a mile from [the river]164-the river , and [the field before [him]37-harry]377-the field before him ran down to [the banks]378-the banks . This was [the selected land of [Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot]379-the selected land of giles medlicot — two years since [a portion of [his]47-medlicot own run]380-a portion of his own run , which had now been purchased from [the government]381-the government — for the loss of which [he]47-medlicot had received and was entitled to receive no compensation . And the matter was made worse for [him]47-medlicot by the fact that [the interloper]382-the interloper had come between [him]47-medlicot and [the river]164-the river . But [he]47-medlicot was not standing here near midnight merely to exercise [his]47-medlicot wrath by straining [his]47-medlicot eyes through the darkness at [[his]47-medlicot neighbor]384-his neighbor ’s crops . [He]47-medlicot put [his]47-medlicot finger into [his]47-medlicot mouth to wet it , and then held it up that [he]47-medlicot might discover which way the light breath of wind was coming . There was still the low moan to be heard continually through [the forest]361-the forest , and yet not a leaf seemed to be moved . After a while [he]47-medlicot thought [he]47-medlicot caught a sound , and put [his]47-medlicot ear down to the ground . [He]47-medlicot distinctly heard a footstep , and rising up , walked quickly toward the spot whence the noise came . “ Who ’s that ? ”[47-medlicot] [he]47-medlicot said , as [he]47-medlicot saw the figure of [a man]128-a man standing on [his]128-a man side of the fence , and leaning against it , with a pipe in [his]128-a man month . “ Who are [you]47-medlicot ? ”[387-the man on the fence] replied [the man on the fence]387-the man on the fence . “ [My]387-the man on the fence name is [Medlicot]47-medlicot . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ Oh , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , is it ? ”[387-the man on the fence] “ Is that [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ? Good - night , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . [You]47-medlicot are going about at a late hour of the night . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ [I]387-the man on the fence have to go about early and late ; but [I]387-the man on the fence ai n’t later than [you]47-medlicot . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ [I]47-medlicot ’m close at [home]103-home , ”[47-medlicot] said [Medlicot]47-medlicot . “ [I]37-harry am , at any rate , on [my]37-harry own run , ”[37-harry] said [Harry]37-harry . “ [You]388-the other mean to say that [I]388-the other am trespassing ? ”[388-the other] said [the other]388-the other ; “ because [I]388-the other can very soon jump back over the fence . ”[388-the other] “ [I]387-the man on the fence did n’t mean that at all , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot ; [any body]1471-any body is welcome on [my]387-the man on the fence run , night or day , who knows how to behave [himself]1471-any body . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ [I]387-the man on the fence hope [I]387-the man on the fence ’m included in that list . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ Just so ; of course . Considering the state that every thing is in , and all the damage that a fire would do , [I]388-the other rather wish that [people]1472-people would be a little more careful about smoking . ”[388-the other] “ [My]387-the man on the fence canes , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , would burn quite as quickly as [your]57-mr. heathcote grass . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ It is not only the grass . [I]387-the man on the fence ’ve a hundred miles of fencing on the run which is as dry as tinder , not to talk of [the station]249-the station and [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ [They]1475-they sha’n’t suffer from [my]388-the other neglect , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . ”[388-the other] “ [You]57-mr. heathcote have [men about who may n’t be so careful]1476-men about who may n’t be so careful . The wind , such as it is , is coming right across from [[your]57-mr. heathcote place]1477-your place . If there were light enough , [I]387-the man on the fence could show [you]57-mr. heathcote three or four patches where there has been fire within half a mile of [this spot]1478-this spot . There was a log burning there for two or three days , not long ago , which was lighted by [one of [[our]1480-our men]1481-our men]1479-one of our men . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ That was a fortnight since . There was no heat then , and [the men]292-the men were boiling [their]292-the men kettle . [I]387-the man on the fence spoke about it . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ A log like that , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , will burn for weeks sometimes . [I]388-the other ’ll tell [you]57-mr. heathcote fairly what [I]388-the other ’m afraid of . There ’s [a man with [you]57-mr. heathcote whom [I]388-the other turned out of [the shed]1484-the shed last shearing]1483-a man with you whom i turned out of the shed last shearing , and [I]388-the other think [he]1483-a man with you whom i turned out of the shed last shearing might put a match down — not by accident . ”[388-the other] “ [You]47-medlicot mean [Nokes]58-nokes . As far as [I]387-the man on the fence know , [he]1483-a man with you whom i turned out of the shed last shearing ’s [a decent man]1485-a decent man . [You]47-medlicot would n’t have [me]387-the man on the fence not employ [a man]128-a man just because [you]47-medlicot had dismissed [him]1483-a man with you whom i turned out of the shed last shearing ? ”[387-the man on the fence] “ Certainly not ; that is , [I]387-the man on the fence should n’t think of dictating to [you]57-mr. heathcote about such a thing . ”[387-the man on the fence] “ Well , no , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , [I]388-the other suppose not . [Nokes]58-nokes has got to earn [his]58-nokes bread , though [you]47-medlicot did dismiss [him]58-nokes . [I]388-the other do n’t know that [he]58-nokes ’s not as honest a man as [you]47-medlicot or [I.]388-the other ”[388-the other] “ If so , there ’s three of [us]1487-us very bad ; that ’s all , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . Good - night ; and if [you]47-medlicot ’ll trouble [yourself]47-medlicot to look after the ash of [your]47-medlicot tobacco it might be the saving of [me]389-me and all [I]389-me have . ”[389-me] So saying , [he]389-me turned round , and made [his]389-me way back to the horses . [Medlicot]47-medlicot had placed [himself]47-medlicot on the fence during the interview , and [he]47-medlicot still kept [his]47-medlicot seat . Of course [he]47-medlicot was now thinking of [the man who had just left [him]47-medlicot , whom [he]47-medlicot declared to [himself]47-medlicot to be [an ignorant , prejudiced , ill - constituted cur]391-an ignorant , prejudiced , ill - constituted cur]390-the man who had just left him , whom he declared to himself to be an ignorant , prejudiced , ill - constituted cur . “ [I]47-medlicot believe in [his]47-medlicot heart [he]47-medlicot thinks that [I]47-medlicot ’m going to set fire to [[his]47-medlicot run]1488-his run , ”[47-medlicot] [he]47-medlicot said , almost aloud . “ And because [he]47-medlicot grows wool [he]47-medlicot thinks [himself]47-medlicot above [every body in [the colony]146-the colony]1489-every body in the colony . [He]47-medlicot occupies thousands of acres , and employs [three or four men]1491-three or four men . [I]47-medlicot till about two hundred , and maintain [thirty families]1492-thirty families . But [he]47-medlicot is such a pig that [he]47-medlicot ca n’t understand all that ; and [he]47-medlicot thinks that [I]47-medlicot must be something low because [I]47-medlicot ’ve bought with [my]47-medlicot own money a bit of land which never belonged to [him]47-medlicot , and which [he]47-medlicot could n’t use . ”[47-medlicot] Such was the nature of [Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s soliloquy as [he]47-medlicot sat swinging [his]47-medlicot legs , and still smoking [his]47-medlicot pipe , on the fence which divided [his]47-medlicot sugar - cane from [the other young man]392-the other young man ’s run . And [Harry Heathcote]65-harry uttered [his]65-harry soliloquy also . “ [I]65-harry would n’t swear that [he]47-medlicot would n’t do it [himself]47-medlicot , after all ; ”[65-harry] meaning that [he]65-harry almost suspected that [Medlicot]47-medlicot [himself]47-medlicot would be an incendiary . To [him]65-harry , in [his]65-harry way of thinking , [a man who would take advantage of the law to buy [a bit of [another man]395-another man ’s land]394-a bit of another man ’s land — or become [a free - selector]1432-a free - selector , as the term goes — was [a public enemy]397-a public enemy , and might be presumed capable of any iniquity . It was all very well for [the girls]398-the girls — meaning [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife and [sister - in - law]400-sister - in - law]393-a man who would take advantage of the law to buy a bit of another man ’s land — or become a free - selector , as the term goes — was a public enemy , and might be presumed capable of any iniquity . it was all very well for the girls — meaning his wife and sister - in - law — to tell [him]65-harry that [Medlicot]47-medlicot had the manners of [a gentleman]122-a gentleman and had come of [decent people]402-decent people . [Women]403-women were always soft enough to be taken by soft hands , a good - looking face , and a decent coat . [This Medlicot]47-medlicot went about dressed like [a man]128-a man in [the towns]212-the towns , exhibiting , as [Harry]65-harry thought , a contemptible , unmanly finery . Of what use was it to tell [him]65-harry that [Medlicot]47-medlicot was [a gentleman]122-a gentleman ? What [Harry]65-harry knew was that since [Medlicot]47-medlicot had come [he]65-harry had lost [his]65-harry sheep , that the heads of three or four had been found buried on [Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s side of [his]65-harry run , and that if [he]65-harry dismissed “ a hand , ”[65-harry] [Medlicot]47-medlicot employed [him]65-harry — a proceeding which , in [Harry Heathcote]65-harry ’s aristocratic and patriarchal views of life , was altogether ungentleman - like . How were the “ hands ”[65-harry] to be kept in [their]407-their place if [one employer of labor]408-one employer of labor did not back up another ? [He]65-harry had been warned to be on [his]65-harry guard against fire . The warnings had hardly been implicit , but yet had come in a shape which made [him]65-harry unable to ignore them . [Old Bates]38-old bates , whom [he]65-harry trusted implicitly , and who was [a man of very few words]409-a man of very few words , had told [him]65-harry to be on [his]65-harry guard . [The German , at whose hut [he]65-harry had been in the morning]410-the german , at whose hut he had been in the morning , [Karl Bender]59-karl bender by name , and [a servant of [his]65-harry own]411-a servant of his own , had told [him]65-harry that there would be fire about before long . “ Why should [any one]1493-any one want to ruin [me]65-harry ? ”[65-harry] [Harry]65-harry had asked . “ Did [I]65-harry ever wrong [a man of a shilling]1494-a man of a shilling ? ”[65-harry] [The German]60-the german had learned to know [[his]60-the german young master]412-his young master , had made [his]60-the german way through the crust of [[his]60-the german master]337-his master ’s character , and was prepared to be faithful at all points — though [he]60-the german too could have quarreled and have avenged [himself]60-the german had it not chanced that [he]60-the german had come to the point of loving instead of hating [[his]60-the german employer]414-his employer . “ [You]65-harry like too much to be [governor]1495-governor over all , ”[415-the german] said [the German]415-the german , as [he]415-the german stooped over the fire in [[his]415-the german own hut]416-his own hut in [his]415-the german anxiety to boil the water for [Heathcote]65-harry ’s tea . “ [Somebody]1496-somebody must be [governor]1495-governor , or every thing would go to the devil , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry . “ Dat ’s true — only [fellows]1498-fellows do n’t like be made feel it , ”[415-the german] said [the German]415-the german , “ [Nokes]58-nokes , [he]58-nokes was made feel it when [you]65-harry put [him]58-nokes over de gate . ”[415-the german] But neither would [Bates]38-old bates nor [the German]60-the german express absolute suspicion of [any man]418-any man . That [Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s “ hands ”[60-the german] at [the sugar - mill]419-the sugar - mill were stealing [his]47-medlicot sheep [Harry]65-harry thought that [he]65-harry knew ; but that was comparatively a small affair , and [he]65-harry would not have pressed it , as [he]65-harry was without absolute evidence . And even [he]65-harry had a feeling that it would be unwise to increase the anger felt against [himself]65-harry — at any rate , during the present heats . [Jacko]51-jacko had [his]51-jacko pipe still alight when [Heathcote]65-harry returned . “ [[You]37-harry young monkey]1499-you young monkey , ”[51-jacko] said [he]51-jacko , “ have [you]37-harry been using matches ? ”[51-jacko] “ Why not , [Mr. Harry]37-harry ? Do n’t the grass burn ready , [Mr. Harry]37-harry ? [My]51-jacko word ! ”[51-jacko] Then [Jacko]51-jacko stooped down , lit another match , and showed [Heathcote]65-harry the burned patch . “ Was it so when [we]1500-we came ? ”[37-harry] [Harry]37-harry asked , with emotion . [Jacko]51-jacko , still kneeling on the ground , and holding the lighted match in [his]51-jacko hand , shook [his]51-jacko head and tapped [his]51-jacko breast , indicating that [he]51-jacko had burned the grass . “ [You]37-harry dropped the match by accident ? ”[51-jacko] “ [My]37-harry word ! no . Did it o ’ purpose to see . It ’s all just one as gunpowder , [Mr. Harry]37-harry . ”[37-harry] [Harry]37-harry got on [his]37-harry horse without a word , and rode away through [the forest]361-the forest , taking a direction different from that by which [he]37-harry had come , and [the boy]375-the boy followed [him]37-harry . [He]37-harry was by no means certain that [this young fellow]422-this young fellow might not turn against [him]37-harry ; but it had been a part of [his]37-harry theory to make no difference to [any man]418-any man because of such fears . If [he]37-harry could make [the men around [him]37-harry]424-the men around him respect [him]37-harry , then [they]424-the men around him would treat [him]37-harry well ; but [they]424-the men around him could never be brought to respect [him]37-harry by flattery . [He]37-harry was very nearly right in [his]37-harry views of [men]130-men , and would have been right altogether could [he]37-harry have seen accurately what justice demanded for [others]158-others as well as for [himself]37-harry . As far as the intention went , [he]37-harry was minded to be just to [every man]427-every man . It seemed , as [they]428-they were riding , that the heat grew fiercer and fiercer . Though there was still the same moaning sound , there was not a breath of air . [They]428-they had now got upon [a track very well known to [Heathcote]65-harry , which led up from [the river]164-the river to [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed]429-a track very well known to heathcote , which led up from the river to the wool - shed , and so on to [the station]249-the station , and [they]428-they had turned homeward . When [they]428-they were near [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , suddenly there fell a heavy drop or two of rain . [Harry]65-harry stopped and turned [his]65-harry face upward , when , in a moment , the whole heavens above [them]428-they and [the forest]361-the forest around were illumined by a flash of lightning so near [them]428-they that it made each of [them]428-they start in [his]65-harry saddle , and made the horses shudder in every limb . Then came the roll of thunder immediately over [their]428-they heads , and with the thunder rain so thick and fast that [Harry]65-harry ’s “ ten thousand buckets ”[65-harry] seemed to be emptied directly over [their]428-they heads . “ [God A’mighty]61-god a’mighty has put out the fires now , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . [Harry]65-harry paused for a moment , feeling the rain through to [his]65-harry bones — for [he]65-harry had nothing on over [his]65-harry shirt — and rejoicing in it . “ Yes , ”[65-harry] [he]65-harry said ; “ [we]428-they may go to bed for a week , and let the grass grow , and [the creeks]1501-the creeks fill , and [the earth]1502-the earth cool . Half an hour like this over the whole run , and there wo n’t be a dry stick on it . ”[65-harry] As [they]428-they went on , the horses splashed through the water . It seemed as though a deluge were falling , and that already the ground beneath [their]428-they feet were becoming [a lake]435-a lake . “ [We]428-they might have too much of this , [Jacko]51-jacko . ”[65-harry] “ [My]65-harry word ! yes . ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry do n’t want to have [the Mary]1503-the mary flooded again . ”[65-harry] “ [My]65-harry word ! no . ”[65-harry] But by the time [they]428-they reached [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed it was over . From the first drop to the last , there had hardly been a space of twenty minutes . But there was a noise of waters as the little streams washed hither and thither to [their]428-they destined courses and still the horses splashed , and still there was the feeling of an incipient deluge . When [they]428-they reached [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , [Harry]65-harry again got off [his]65-harry horse , and [Jacko]51-jacko , dismounting also , hitched the two animals to the post and followed [[his]51-jacko master]337-his master into [the building]439-the building . [Harry]65-harry struck a wax match , and holding it up , strove to look round [the building]439-the building by the feeble light which [it]439-the building shed . [It]439-the building was [a remarkable edifice , built in the shape of a great T]441-a remarkable edifice , built in the shape of a great t , open at the sides , with a sharp - pitched timber roof covered with felt , which came down within four feet of the ground . [It]439-the building was calculated to hold about four hundred sheep at a time , and was divided into pens of various sizes , partitioned off for various purposes . If [Harry Heathcote]65-harry was sure of any thing , [he]65-harry was sure that [[his]65-harry wool - shed]324-his wool - shed was the best that had ever been built in [this district]443-this district . “ By [Jimini]62-jimini ! what ’s that ? ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . “ Did [you]65-harry hear any thing ? ”[51-jacko] [Jacko]51-jacko pointed with [his]51-jacko finger down the centre walk of [the shed]1484-the shed , and [Harry]65-harry , striking another match as [he]65-harry went , rushed forward . But the match was out as soon as ignited , and gave no glimmer of light . Nevertheless [he]65-harry saw , or thought that [he]65-harry saw , the figure of [a man]128-a man escaping out of the open end of [the shed]1484-the shed . [The place itself]447-the place itself was black as midnight , but [the space beyond]448-the space beyond was clear of trees , and the darkness outside being a few shades lighter than within [the building]439-the building , allowed something of the outline of [a figure]450-a figure to be visible . And as [the man]451-the man escaped , the sounds of [his]451-the man footsteps were audible enough . [Harry]65-harry called to [him]451-the man , but of course received no answer . Had [he]65-harry pursued [him]451-the man , [he]65-harry would have been obliged to cross sundry rails , which would have so delayed [him]65-harry as to give [him]65-harry no chance of success . “ [I]65-harry knew there was [a fellow]1504-a fellow about , ”[65-harry] [he]65-harry said ; “ [one of [[our]1506-our own men]1507-our own men]1505-one of our own men would not have run like that . ”[65-harry] [Jacko]51-jacko shook [his]51-jacko head , but did not speak . “ [He]1504-a fellow has got in [here]260-here for shelter out of the rain , but [he]1504-a fellow was doing no good about [the place]1437-the place . ”[51-jacko] [Jacko]51-jacko again shook [his]51-jacko head . “ [I]51-jacko wonder who [he]1504-a fellow was ? ”[51-jacko] [Jacko]51-jacko came up and whispered in [his]51-jacko ear , “ [Bill Nokes]58-nokes . ”[51-jacko] “ [You]51-jacko could n’t see [him]1504-a fellow . ”[51-jacko] “ [Seed]63-seed the drag of [his]1504-a fellow leg . ”[51-jacko] Now it was well known that [the man Nokes]452-the man nokes had injured some of [his]452-the man nokes muscles , and habitually dragged one foot after another . “ [I]452-the man nokes do n’t think [you]51-jacko could have been sure of [him]1504-a fellow by such a glimpse as that . ”[452-the man nokes] “ Maybe not , ”[375-the boy] said [the boy]375-the boy , “ only [I]375-the boy ’m sure as sure . ”[375-the boy] [Harry Heathcote]65-harry said not another word , but getting again upon [his]65-harry horse , galloped [home]103-home . It was past one when [he]65-harry reached [the station]249-the station , but [the two girls]456-the two girls were waiting up for [him]65-harry , and at once began to condole with [him]65-harry because [he]65-harry was wet . “ Wet ! ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry ; “ if [you]456-the two girls could only know how much [I]65-harry prefer things being wet to dry just at present ! But give [Jacko]51-jacko some supper . [I]65-harry must keep [that young fellow]1510-that young fellow in good humor if [I]65-harry can . ”[65-harry] So [Jacko]51-jacko had half a loaf of bread , and a small pot of jam , and a large jug of cold tea provided for [him]51-jacko , in the enjoyment of which luxuries [he]51-jacko did not seem to be in the least impeded by the fact that [he]51-jacko was wet through to the skin . [Harry Heathcote]65-harry had [another nobbler — being only the second in the day]457-another nobbler — being only the second in the day — and then went to bed . As [Harry]65-harry said , [they]458-they might all now lie in bed for a day or two . The rain had set aside for the time the necessity for that urgent watchfulness which kept all hands on [the station]249-the station hard at work during the great heat . There was not , generally , much rest during the year at [Gangoil]65-harry . Lambing in April and May , washing and shearing in September , October , and November , with the fear of fires and the necessary precautions in December and January , did not leave more than sufficient intervals for looking after the water - dams , making and mending fences , procuring stores , and attending to the ailments of the flocks . [No man]156-no man worked harder than [the young squatter]461-the young squatter . But now there had suddenly come a day or two of rest — rest from work which was not of itself productive , but only remedial , and which , therefore , was not begrudged . But it soon was apparent that the rest could be only for a day or two . The rain had fallen as from ten thousand buckets , but it had fallen only for a space of minutes . On the following morning [the thirsty earth]462-the thirsty earth had apparently swallowed all the flood . The water in [the creek beneath [the house]226-the house]463-the creek beneath the house stood two feet higher than [it]465-it had done , and [Harry]65-harry , when [he]65-harry visited the dams round the run , found that they were fall to overflowing , and the grasses were already springing , so quick is the all but tropical growth of [the country]217-the country . [They]458-they might be safe , perhaps , for eight - and - forty hours . Fire would run only when the ground was absolutely dry , and when every twig or leaf was a combustible . But during those eight - and - forty hours there might be comparative ease at [Gangoil]65-harry . On the day following the night of the ride [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote suggested to [[her]42-mrs. heathcote husband]116-her husband that [she]42-mrs. heathcote and [Kate]41-kate should ride over to [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s Mill]468-medlicot ’s mill , as [the place]1437-the place was already named , and call on [Mrs. Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot . “ It is n’t Christian , ”[42-mrs. heathcote] [she]42-mrs. heathcote said , “ for [people living out in the bush as [we]1512-we are to quarrel with [[their]1511-people living out in the bush as we are to quarrel with their neighbors neighbors]1513-their neighbors]1511-people living out in the bush as we are to quarrel with their neighbors just because [they]1511-people living out in the bush as we are to quarrel with their neighbors are [neighbors]1514-neighbors . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] “ [Neighbors]1514-neighbors ! ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry ; “ [I]65-harry do n’t know any word that there ’s so much humbug about . [The Samaritan]64-the samaritan was [the best neighbor [I]65-harry ever heard of]1516-the best neighbor i ever heard of , and [he]64-the samaritan lived a long way off , [I]65-harry take it . Anyway , [he]64-the samaritan was n’t a free - selector . ”[65-harry] “ [Harry]65-harry , that ’s profane . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] “ Every thing [I]42-mrs. heathcote say is wicked . [You]65-harry can go , of course , if [you]65-harry like it . [I]42-mrs. heathcote do n’t want to quarrel with any body . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] “ Quarreling is so uncomfortable , ”[104-his wife] said [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife . “ That ’s a matter of taste . There are people whom [I]104-his wife find it very comfortable to quarrel with . [I]104-his wife should n’t at all like not to quarrel with [the Brownbies]65-harry , and [I]104-his wife ’m not at all sure it may n’t come to be the same with [Mr. Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot . ”[104-his wife] “ [The Brownbies]1517-the brownbies live by sheep - stealing and horse - stealing . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] “ And [Medlicot]47-medlicot means to live by employing [sheep - stealers]1518-sheep - stealers and [horse - stealers]1519-horse - stealers . [You]65-harry can go if [you]65-harry like it . [You]65-harry wo n’t want [me]104-his wife to go with [you]65-harry . Will [you]65-harry have the baggy ? ”[104-his wife] But [the ladies]471-the ladies said that [they]471-the ladies would ride . The air was cooler now than it had been , and [they]471-the ladies would like the exercise . [They]471-the ladies would take [Jacko]51-jacko with [them]471-the ladies to open the slip - rails , and [they]471-the ladies would be back by seven for dinner . So [they]471-the ladies started , taking [the track]353-the track by [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed . [The wool - shed]328-the wool - shed was about two miles from [the station]249-the station , and [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s Mill]468-medlicot ’s mill was seven miles farther , on [the bank of [the river]164-the river]477-the bank of the river . [Mr. Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot , though at [Gangoil]65-harry [he]47-medlicot was still spoken of as [a new - comer]479-a new - comer , had already been located for nearly two years on [the land which [he]47-medlicot had purchased immediately on [his]47-medlicot coming to [the colony]146-the colony]480-the land which he had purchased immediately on his coming to the colony . [He]47-medlicot had come out direct from [England]8-england with the intention of growing sugar , and , whether successful or not in making money , had certainly succeeded in growing crops of sugar - canes and in erecting [a mill]482-a mill for crushing them . It probably takes more than two years for [a man]128-a man [himself]128-a man to discover whether [he]128-a man can achieve ultimate success in such an enterprise ; and [Medlicot]47-medlicot was certainly not a man likely to talk much to others of [his]47-medlicot private concerns . [The mill]484-the mill had just been built , and [he]47-medlicot had lived [there]290-there [himself]47-medlicot as soon as [a water - tight room]486-a water - tight room had been constructed . It was only within the last three months that [he]47-medlicot had completed [a small cottage residence]487-a small cottage residence , and had brought [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother to live with [him]47-medlicot . Hitherto [he]47-medlicot had hardly made [himself]47-medlicot popular . [He]47-medlicot was not either fish or fowl . [The squatters]489-the squatters regarded [him]47-medlicot as [an interloper]490-an interloper , and as [a man holding opinions directly averse to [their]489-the squatters own interests — in which [they]489-the squatters were right]491-a man holding opinions directly averse to their own interests — in which they were right . And [the small free - selectors , who lived on the labor of [their]492-the small free - selectors , who lived on the labor of their own hands own hands]492-the small free - selectors , who lived on the labor of their own hands — or , as was said of many of [them]492-the small free - selectors , who lived on the labor of their own hands , by stealing sheep and cattle — knew well that [he]47-medlicot was not of [[their]492-the small free - selectors , who lived on the labor of their own hands class]493-their class . But [Medlicot]47-medlicot had gone [his]47-medlicot way steadfastly , if not happily , and complained aloud to [no one]339-no one in the midst of [his]47-medlicot difficulties . [He]47-medlicot had not , perhaps , found the Paradise which [he]47-medlicot had expected in [Queensland]5-queensland , but [he]47-medlicot had found that [he]47-medlicot could grow sugar ; and having begun the work , [he]47-medlicot was determined to go on with it . [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was [[his]47-medlicot nearest neighbor]495-his nearest neighbor , and [the only man in [his]47-medlicot own rank of life who lived within twenty miles of [him]47-medlicot]496-the only man in his own rank of life who lived within twenty miles of him . When [he]47-medlicot had started [his]47-medlicot enterprise [he]47-medlicot had hoped to make [this man]497-this man [[his]47-medlicot friend]498-his friend , not comprehending at first how great a cause for hostility was created by the very purchase of [the land]499-the land . [He]47-medlicot had been [a new - comer from [the old country]501-the old country]500-a new - comer from the old country , and , being alone , had desired friendship . [He]47-medlicot was [Harry Heathcote]65-harry ’s equal in education , intelligence , and fortune , if not in birth — which surely , in [the Australian bush]502-the australian bush , need not count for much . [He]47-medlicot had assumed , when first meeting [the squatter]503-the squatter , that good - fellowship between [them]504-them , on equal terms , would be acceptable to [both]505-both ; but [his]47-medlicot overtures had been coldly received . Then [he]47-medlicot , too , had drawn [himself]47-medlicot up , had declared that [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was [an ignorant ass]506-an ignorant ass , and had unconsciously made up [his]47-medlicot mind to commence hostilities . It was in this spirit that [he]47-medlicot had taken [Nokes]58-nokes into [[his]47-medlicot mill]507-his mill , of whose character , had [he]47-medlicot inquired about it , [he]47-medlicot would certainly have heard no good . [He]47-medlicot had now brought [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother to [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill . [She]488-his mother and [the Gangoil ladies]509-the gangoil ladies had met each other on neutral ground , and it was almost necessary that [they]504-them should either be [friends]510-friends or [absolute enemies]511-absolute enemies . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had been aware of this , and bad declared that enmity was horrible . “ Upon [my]65-harry word , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , “ [I]65-harry sometimes think that friendship is more so . [I]65-harry suppose [I]65-harry ’m fitted for bush life , for [I]65-harry want to see [no one]339-no one from year ’s end to year ’s end but [[my]65-harry own family]1521-my own family and [[my]65-harry own people]1522-my own people . ”[65-harry] And yet [this young patriarch in [the wilderness]513-the wilderness]512-this young patriarch in the wilderness was only twenty - four years old , and had been educated at [an English school]514-an english school ! [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s cottage]515-medlicot ’s cottage was about a hundred and fifty yards from [the mill]484-the mill , looking down upon [the Mary]40-mary , the banks of which at this spot were almost precipitous . [The site for [the plantation]518-the plantation]517-the site for the plantation had been chosen because [the river]164-the river afforded the means of carriage down to [the sea]520-the sea , and [the mill]484-the mill had been so constructed that the sugar hogsheads could be lowered from [the buildings]522-the buildings into [the river]164-the river boats . Here [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote and [Kate Daly]41-kate found [the old lady]524-the old lady sitting at work , all alone , in [the veranda]174-the veranda . [She]524-the old lady was [a handsome old woman , with gray hair , seventy years of age , with wrinkled face , and a toothless mouth , but with bright eyes , and with no signs of the infirmity of age]526-a handsome old woman , with gray hair , seventy years of age , with wrinkled face , and a toothless mouth , but with bright eyes , and with no signs of the infirmity of age . “ This is [gey]1523-gey kind of [you]527-you to run so far to see [an auld woman]1524-an auld woman , ”[524-the old lady] [she]524-the old lady said . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote declared that [they]527-you were used to the heat , and that after the rain the air was pleasant . “ [You]527-you ’re [two bright lassies]1525-two bright lassies , and [you]527-you ’re hearty , ”[524-the old lady] [she]524-the old lady said . “ [I]524-the old lady ’m auld , and just out of [Cumberland]12-cumberland , and [I]524-the old lady find it ’s hot enough — and [I]524-the old lady ’m no guid at horseback at all . [I]524-the old lady dinna know how [I]524-the old lady ’m to get aboot . ”[524-the old lady] Then [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote explained that there was an excellent track for [a buggy]528-a buggy all the way to [Gangoil]65-harry . “ [Giles]47-medlicot is aye telling [me]42-mrs. heathcote that [I]42-mrs. heathcote ’m to gang aboot in a bouggey , but [I]42-mrs. heathcote dinna feel sure of thae bouggeys . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote , of course , praised [the country carriages]529-the country carriages , and [the country roads]530-the country roads , and [the country]217-the country generally . Tea was brought in , and [the old lady]524-the old lady was delighted with [[her]524-the old lady guests]533-her guests . Since [she]524-the old lady had been at [the mill]484-the mill , week had followed week , and [she]524-the old lady had seen [no woman]535-no woman ’s face but that of [the uncouth girl who waited upon [her]524-the old lady]536-the uncouth girl who waited upon her . “ Did [ye]537-ye ever see rain like that ! ”[524-the old lady] [she]524-the old lady said , putting up [her]524-the old lady hands . “ [I]524-the old lady thought [the Lord]1526-the lord was sending [his]1526-the lord clouds down upon [us]537-ye in a lump like . ”[524-the old lady] Then [she]524-the old lady told [them]537-ye that [some of [the men]292-the men]538-some of the men had declared that if it went on like that for two hours [the Mary]1503-the mary would rise and take [the cottage]272-the cottage away . [Giles]47-medlicot , however , had declared that to be trash , as [the cottage]272-the cottage was twenty feet above the ordinary course of [the river]164-the river . [They]537-ye were just rising to take [their]537-ye leave , when [Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot [himself]47-medlicot came in out of [the mill]484-the mill . [He]47-medlicot was [a man of good presence]545-a man of good presence , dark , and tall like [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote , but stoutly made , with a strongly marked face , given to frowning much when [he]47-medlicot was eager ; bright - eyed , with a broad forehead — certainly [a man to be observed as far as [his]47-medlicot appearance was concerned]546-a man to be observed as far as his appearance was concerned . [He]47-medlicot was dressed much as [a gentleman]122-a gentleman dresses in [the country]217-the country at [home]103-home , and was therefore accounted to be a fop by [Harry Heathcote]65-harry , who was rarely seen abroad in other garb than that which has been described . [Harry]65-harry was [an aristocrat , and hated such innovations in the bush as cloth coats and tweed trowsers and neck - hand - kerchiefs]550-an aristocrat , and hated such innovations in the bush as cloth coats and tweed trowsers and neck - hand - kerchiefs . [Medlicot]47-medlicot had been full of wrath against [[his]47-medlicot neighbor]384-his neighbor all the morning .
