There had been a tone in [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ’s voice when [he]47-medlicot gave [his]47-medlicot parting warning as to the fire in [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s pipe]552-medlicot ’s pipe which [the sugar grower]553-the sugar grower had felt to be intentionally insolent . Nothing had been said which could be openly resented , but offense had surely been intended ; and then [he]47-medlicot had remembered that [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother had been already some months at [the mill]484-the mill , and that no mark of neighborly courtesy had been shown to [her]488-his mother . [The Heathcotes]52-the heathcotes had , [he]47-medlicot thought , chosen to assume [themselves]52-the heathcotes to be superior to [him]47-medlicot and [his]47-medlicot , and to treat [him]47-medlicot as though [he]47-medlicot had been [some laboring man who had saved money enough to purchase [a bit of land]557-a bit of land for [himself]47-medlicot]556-some laboring man who had saved money enough to purchase a bit of land for himself . [He]47-medlicot was , therefore , astonished to find [the two young ladies]558-the two young ladies sitting with [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother on the very day after such an interview as that of the preceding night . “ [The leddies from [Gangoil]65-harry]1527-the leddies from gangoil , [Giles]47-medlicot , have been guid enough to ride over and see [me]488-his mother , ”[488-his mother] said [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother . [Medlicot]47-medlicot , of course , shook hands with [them]558-the two young ladies , and expressed [his]47-medlicot sense of [their]558-the two young ladies kindness , but [he]47-medlicot did it awkwardly . [He]47-medlicot soon , however , declared [his]47-medlicot purpose of riding part of the way back with [them]558-the two young ladies . “ [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote must have been very wet last night , ”[47-medlicot] [he]47-medlicot said , when [they]558-the two young ladies were on horse - back , addressing [himself]47-medlicot to [Kate Daly]41-kate rather than to [[her]41-kate sister]180-her sister . “ Indeed [he]57-mr. heathcote was — wet to the skin . Were [you]47-medlicot not ? ”[47-medlicot] “ [I]47-medlicot saw [him]57-mr. heathcote at about eleven , before the rain began . [I]47-medlicot was close [home]103-home , and just escaped . [He]57-mr. heathcote must have been under it all . Does [he]57-mr. heathcote often go about the run in that way at night ? ”[47-medlicot] “ Only when [he]57-mr. heathcote ’s afraid of fires , ”[41-kate] said [Kate]41-kate . “ Is there much to be afraid of ? [I]41-kate do n’t suppose that [any body]1471-any body can be so wicked as to wish to burn the grass . ”[41-kate] Then [the ladies]471-the ladies took upon [themselves]471-the ladies to explain . “ The fires might be caused from negligence or trifling accidents , or might possibly come from the unaided heat of the sun ; or there might be [enemies]1464-enemies . ”[471-the ladies] “ [My]51-jacko word ! yes ; [enemies]1464-enemies , rather ! ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko , who was riding close behind , and who had no idea of being kept out of the conversation merely because [he]51-jacko was [a servant]563-a servant . [Medlicot]47-medlicot , turning round , looked at [the lad]149-the lad , and asked who were [the enemies]565-the enemies . “ [Free - selectors]1532-free - selectors , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . “ [I]47-medlicot ’m [a free - selector]1432-a free - selector , ”[47-medlicot] said [Medlicot]47-medlicot . “ Did not jist mean [you]47-medlicot , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko . “ [Jacko]51-jacko , [you]51-jacko ’d better hold [your]51-jacko tongue , ”[42-mrs. heathcote] said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote . “ Hold [my]42-mrs. heathcote tongue ! [My]42-mrs. heathcote word ! Well , [you]51-jacko go on . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] [Medlicot]47-medlicot came as far as [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , and then said that [he]47-medlicot would return . [He]47-medlicot had thoroughly enjoyed [his]47-medlicot ride . [Kate Daly]41-kate was bright and pretty and winning ; and in the bush , when [a man]128-a man has not seen [a lady]568-a lady perhaps for months , brightness and prettiness and winning ways have a double charm . To ride with [fair women]569-fair women over turf , through [a forest]570-a forest , with [a woman who may perhaps some day be wooed]571-a woman who may perhaps some day be wooed , can be a matter of indifference only to [a very lethargic man]572-a very lethargic man . [Giles Medlicot]47-medlicot was by no means lethargic . [He]47-medlicot owned to [himself]47-medlicot that though [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was [a pig - headed ass]573-a pig - headed ass , [the ladies]471-the ladies were very nice , and [he]47-medlicot thought that the pig - headed ass in choosing one of [them]471-the ladies for [himself]47-medlicot had by no means taken the nicest . “ [You]47-medlicot ’ll never find [your]47-medlicot way back , ”[41-kate] said [Kate]41-kate , “ if [you]47-medlicot ’ve not been [here]260-here before . ”[41-kate] “ [I]42-mrs. heathcote never was [here]260-here before , and [I]42-mrs. heathcote suppose [I]42-mrs. heathcote must find [my]42-mrs. heathcote way back . ”[42-mrs. heathcote] Then [he]47-medlicot was urged to come on and dine at [Gangoil]65-harry , with a promise that [Jacko]51-jacko should return with [him]47-medlicot in the evening . But this [he]47-medlicot would not do . [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was [a pig - headed ass]573-a pig - headed ass , who possibly regarded [him]47-medlicot as an incendiary simply because [he]47-medlicot had bought [some land]576-some land . [This boy of [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ’s , whose services had been offered to [him]47-medlicot]577-this boy of heathcote ’s , whose services had been offered to him , had not scrupled to tell [him]47-medlicot to [his]47-medlicot face that [he]47-medlicot was to be regarded as [an enemy]578-an enemy . Much as [he]47-medlicot liked the company of [Kate Daly]41-kate , [he]47-medlicot could not go to [the house of [that stupid , arrogant , pig - headed young squatter]580-that stupid , arrogant , pig - headed young squatter]579-the house of that stupid , arrogant , pig - headed young squatter . “ [I]47-medlicot ’m not such [a bad bushman]1536-a bad bushman but what [I]47-medlicot can find [my]47-medlicot way to [the river]164-the river , ”[47-medlicot] [he]47-medlicot said . “ Find it blindful , ”[51-jacko] said [Jacko]51-jacko , who did not relish the idea of going back to [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s Mill]468-medlicot ’s mill as guide to [another man]395-another man . There was a weakness in the idea that such aid could be necessary , which was revolting to [Jacko]51-jacko ’s sense of bush independence . [They]583-we were standing on [their]583-we horses at the entrance to [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed as [they]583-we discussed the point , when suddenly [Harry]65-harry [himself]65-harry appeared out of [the building]439-the building . [He]65-harry came up and shook hands with [Medlicot]47-medlicot , with sufficient courtesy , but hardly with cordiality , and then asked [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife as to [her]104-his wife ride . “ [We]583-we have been very jolly , have n’t [we]583-we , [Kate]41-kate ? Of course it has been hot , but every thing is not so frightfully parched as it was before the rain . As [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot has come back so far with [us]583-we , [we]583-we want [him]65-harry to come on and dine . ”[65-harry] “ Pray do , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry . But again the tone of [his]65-harry voice was not sufficiently hearty to satisfy [the man who was invited]587-the man who was invited . “ Thanks , no : [I]65-harry think [I]65-harry ’ll hardly do that.—Good - night , [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ; good - night . [Miss Daly]66-miss daly ; ”[65-harry] and [the two ladies]196-the two ladies immediately perceived that [his]65-harry voice , which had hitherto been pleasant in [their]196-the two ladies ears , had ceased to be cordial . “ [I]42-mrs. heathcote am very glad [he]65-harry has gone back , ”[42-mrs. heathcote] said [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote . “ Why do [you]65-harry say so , [Harry]65-harry ? [You]65-harry are not given to be inhospitable , and why should [you]65-harry grudge [me]42-mrs. heathcote and [Kate]41-kate the rare pleasure of seeing a strange face ? ”[42-mrs. heathcote] “ [I]65-harry ’ll tell [you]65-harry why . It ’s not about [him]65-harry at this moment ; but [I]65-harry ’ve been disturbed.—Jacko , go on to [the station]249-the station , and say [we]196-the two ladies ’re coming . Do [you]65-harry hear [me]65-harry ? Go on at once . ”[65-harry] Then [Jacko]51-jacko , somewhat unwillingly , galloped off toward [the house]226-the house . “ Get off [your]65-harry horses , and come in . ”[51-jacko] [He]51-jacko helped [the two ladies]196-the two ladies from [their]196-the two ladies saddles , and [they]196-the two ladies all went into [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , [Harry]65-harry leading the way . In one of [the side pens]592-the side pens , immediately under the roof , there was a large heap of leaves , the outside portion of which was at present damp , for the rain had beaten in upon it , but which had been as dry as tinder when collected ; and there was a row or ridge of mixed brush - wood and leaves so constructed as to form a line from the grass outside on to the heap . “ [The fellow who did that]1539-the fellow who did that was [an ass]1540-an ass , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry ; “ a greater ass than [I]65-harry should have taken [him]1539-the fellow who did that to be , not to have known that if [he]1539-the fellow who did that could have gotten the grass to burn outside , [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed must have gone without all that preparation . But there is n’t much difficulty now in seeing what [the fellow]1542-the fellow has intended . ”[65-harry] “ Was it for a fire ? ”[41-kate] asked [Kate]41-kate . “ Of course it was . [He]1539-the fellow who did that would n’t have been contented with the grass and fences , but wanted to make sure of [the shed]1484-the shed also . [He]1539-the fellow who did that ’d have come to [the house]226-the house and burned [us]196-the two ladies in [our]196-the two ladies beds , only [a fellow like that]1545-a fellow like that is too much of [a coward]1546-a coward to run the risk of being seen . ”[41-kate] “ But , [Harry]65-harry , why did n’t [he]1539-the fellow who did that light it when [he]1539-the fellow who did that ’d done it ? ”[42-mrs. heathcote] said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote . “ Because [the Almighty]1547-the almighty sent the rain at the very moment , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , striking the top rail of one of [the pens]593-the pens with [his]65-harry fist . “ [I]65-harry ’m not much given to talk about [Providence]44-providence , but this looks like it , does it not ? ”[65-harry] “ [He]1539-the fellow who did that might have put a match in at the moment ? ”[41-kate] “ Rain or no rain ? Yes , [he]1539-the fellow who did that might . But [he]1539-the fellow who did that was interrupted by more than the rain . [I]41-kate got into [the shed]1484-the shed [myself]41-kate just at the moment — [I]41-kate and [Jacko]51-jacko . It was last night , when the rain was pouring . [I]41-kate heard [the man , and dark as was the night]1549-the man , and dark as was the night , [I]41-kate saw [his]1539-the fellow who did that figure as [he]1539-the fellow who did that fled away . ”[41-kate] “ [You]65-harry did n’t know [him]1539-the fellow who did that ? ”[66-miss daly] said [Miss Daly]66-miss daly . “ But [that boy , who has the eyes of a cat]1550-that boy , who has the eyes of a cat , [he]1550-that boy , who has the eyes of a cat knew [him]1539-the fellow who did that . ”[66-miss daly] “ [Jacko]51-jacko ? ”[41-kate] “ [Jacko]51-jacko knew [him]1539-the fellow who did that by [his]1539-the fellow who did that gait . [I]41-kate should have hardly wanted [any one]1493-any one to tell [me]41-kate who it was . [I]41-kate could have named [the man]451-the man at once , but for the fear of doing an injustice . ”[41-kate] “ And who was it ? ”[41-kate] “ [[Our]1553-our friend [Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s prime favorite and new factotum]1554-our friend medlicot ’s prime favorite and new factotum , [Mr. William Nokes]58-nokes . [Mr. William Nokes]58-nokes is [the gentleman who intends to burn [us]1553-our all out of [house]1556-house and [home]103-home]1555-the gentleman who intends to burn us all out of house and home , and [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot is [the gentleman whose pleasure it is to keep [Mr. Nokes]58-nokes in [the neighborhood]1559-the neighborhood]1558-the gentleman whose pleasure it is to keep mr. nokes in the neighborhood . ”[41-kate] [The two women]594-the two women stood awe - struck for a moment , but a sense of justice prevailed upon [the wife]108-the wife to speak . “ That may be all true , ”[108-the wife] [she]108-the wife said . “ Perhaps it is as [you]65-harry say about [that man]1560-that man . But [you]65-harry would not therefore think that [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot knows any thing about it ? ”[108-the wife] “ It would be impossible , ”[41-kate] said [Kate]41-kate . “ [I]65-harry have not accused [him]47-medlicot , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry ; “ but [he]47-medlicot knows that [the man]451-the man was dismissed , and yet keeps [him]451-the man about [the place]1437-the place . Of course [he]47-medlicot is responsible . ”[65-harry] For the first mile between [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed and [the house Heathcote]597-the house heathcote and [the two ladies]196-the two ladies rode without saying a word . There was something so terrible in the reality of the danger which encompassed [them]594-the two women that [they]594-the two women hardly felt inclined to discuss it . [Harry]65-harry ’s dislike to [Medlicot]47-medlicot was quite a thing apart . That [some one]599-some one had intended to burn down [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed , and had made preparation for doing so , was as apparent to [the women]601-the women as to [him]47-medlicot . And [the man who had been balked by a shower of rain]602-the man who had been balked by a shower of rain in [his]47-medlicot first attempt might soon find an opportunity for a second . [Harry]65-harry was well aware that even [Jacko]51-jacko ’s assertion could not be taken as evidence against [the man whom [he]65-harry suspected]603-the man whom he suspected . In all probability no further attempt would be made upon [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed ; but a fire on some distant part of the run would be much more injurious to [him]65-harry than the mere burning of [a building]605-a building . The fire that might ruin [him]65-harry would be one which should get ahead before it was seen , and scour across [the ground]606-the ground , consuming the grass down to the very roots over thousands of acres , and destroying fencing over many miles . Such fires pass on , leaving the standing trees unscathed , avoiding even the scrub , which is too moist with the sap of life for consumption , but licking up with fearful rapidity every thing that the sun has dried . [He]65-harry could watch [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed and [house]1556-house , but with no possible care could [he]65-harry so watch the whole run as to justify [him]65-harry in feeling security . There need be no preparation of leaves . A match thrown loosely on the ground would do it . And in regard to a match so thrown , it would be impossible to prove a guilty intention . “ Ought [we]609-all of them not to have dispersed the heap ? ”[42-mrs. heathcote] said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote at last . The minds of [all of [them]609-all of them]609-all of them were full of the matter , but these were the first words spoken . “ [I]65-harry ’ll leave it as it is , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , giving no reason for [his]65-harry decision . [He]65-harry was too full of thought , too heavily laden with anxiety , to speak much . “ Come , let ’s get on ; [you]611-the two sisters ’ll want [your]611-the two sisters dinner , and it ’s getting dark . ”[65-harry] So [they]609-all of them cantered on , and got off [their]609-all of them horses at the gate , without another word . And not another word was spoken on the subject that night . [Harry]65-harry was very silent , walking up and down [the veranda]174-the veranda with [his]65-harry pipe in [his]65-harry mouth — not lying on the ground in idle enjoyment — and there was no reading . [The two sisters]611-the two sisters looked at [him]65-harry from time to time with wistful , anxious - eyes , half afraid to disturb [him]65-harry by speech . As for [him]65-harry , [he]65-harry felt that the weight was all on [his]65-harry own shoulders . [He]65-harry had worked hard , and was on the way to be rich . [I]0-i do not know that [he]65-harry thought much about money , but [he]65-harry thought very much of success . And [he]65-harry was by nature anxious , sanguine , and impulsive . There might be before [him]65-harry , within the next week , such desolation as would break [his]65-harry heart . [He]65-harry knew [men who had been ruined]612-men who had been ruined , and had borne [their]612-men who had been ruined [ruin almost without a wail — who had seemed contented to descend to security and mere absence from want]613-ruin almost without a wail — who had seemed contented to descend to security and mere absence from want . There was [[his]65-harry own superintendent]614-his own superintendent , [Old Bates]38-old bates , who , though [he]38-old bates grumbled at every thing else , never bewailed [his]38-old bates own fate . But [he]65-harry knew of [himself]65-harry that any such blow would nearly kill [him]65-harry — such a blow , that is , as might drive [him]65-harry from [Gangoil]65-harry , and force [him]65-harry to be [the servant]615-the servant instead of [the master of]616-the master of [men]130-men . Not to be [master of all around [him]65-harry]618-master of all around him seemed to [him]65-harry to be misery . [The merchants at [Brisbane]7-brisbane who took [his]65-harry wool and supplied [him]65-harry with stores]619-the merchants at brisbane who took his wool and supplied him with stores had advanced money when [he]65-harry first bought [his]65-harry run , and [he]65-harry still owed [them]619-the merchants at brisbane who took his wool and supplied him with stores some thousands of pounds . The injury which a great fire would do [him]65-harry would bring [him]65-harry to such a condition that [the merchants]620-the merchants would demand to have [their]620-the merchants money repaid . [He]65-harry understood it all , and knew well that it was after this fashion that [many a squatter before [him]65-harry]621-many a squatter before him had been ruined . “ Speak a word to [me]104-his wife about it , ”[104-his wife] [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife said to [him]65-harry , imploringly , when [they]623-we were alone together that night . “ [[My]104-his wife darling]1563-my darling , if there were a word to say , [I]104-his wife would say it . [I]104-his wife must be on the watch , and do the best [I]104-his wife can . At present [the earth]1502-the earth is too damp for mischief . ”[104-his wife] “ Oh that it would rain again ! ”[104-his wife] “ There will be heat enough before the summer is over ; [we]623-we need not doubt that . But [I]104-his wife will tell [you]1563-my darling of every thing as [we]623-we go on . [I]104-his wife will endeavor to have [the man]451-the man watched . God bless [you]1563-my darling ! Go to sleep , and try to get it out of [your]1563-my darling thoughts . ”[104-his wife] On the following morning [he]65-harry breakfasted early , and mounted [his]65-harry horse without saying a word as to the purport of [his]65-harry journey . This was in accordance with the habit of [his]65-harry life , and would not excite observation ; but there was something in [his]65-harry manner which made both [the ladies]471-the ladies feel that [he]65-harry was intent on some special object . When [he]65-harry intended simply to ride round [[his]65-harry fences]625-his fences or to visit [the hut of [some distant servant]627-some distant servant]626-the hut of some distant servant , a few minutes signified nothing . [He]65-harry would stand under [the veranda]174-the veranda and talk , and [the women]601-the women would endeavor to keep [him]65-harry from the saddle . But now there was no loitering , and but little talking . [He]65-harry said a word to [Jacko]51-jacko , who brought the horse for [him]65-harry , and then started at a gallop toward [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed . [He]65-harry did not stop a moment at [the shed]1484-the shed , not even entering [it]1484-the shed to see whether the heap of leaves had been displaced during the night , but went on straight to [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill . [He]65-harry rode the nine miles in an hour , and at once entered [the building in which the canes were crushed]632-the building in which the canes were crushed . [The first man]633-the first man [he]65-harry met was [Nokes]58-nokes , who acted as [overseer]634-overseer , having [a gang of Polynesian laborers under [him]58-nokes]635-a gang of polynesian laborers under him — [sleek , swarthy fellows from [the South Sea Islands]13-the south sea islands]636-sleek , swarthy fellows from the south sea islands , with linen trowsers on and nothing else — who crept silently among the vats and machinery , shifting the sugar as it was made . “ Well , [Nokes]58-nokes , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , “ how are [you]58-nokes getting on ? Is [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot [here]260-here ? ”[65-harry] [Nokes]58-nokes was [a big fellow]637-a big fellow , with a broad , solid face , which would not have condemned [him]58-nokes among [physiognomists]638-physiognomists but for a bad eye , which could not look [you]639-you in the face . [He]58-nokes had been [a boundary rider for [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote]640-a boundary rider for heathcote , and on an occasion had been impertinent , refusing to leave [the yard]641-the yard behind [the house]226-the house unless something was done which [those about [the place]1437-the place]643-those about the place refused to do for [him]58-nokes . During the discussion [Harry]65-harry had come in . [The man]451-the man had been drinking , and was still insolent , and [Harry]65-harry had ejected [him]451-the man violently , thrusting [him]451-the man over a gate . [The man]451-the man had returned the next morning , and had then been sent about [his]451-the man business . [He]451-the man had been employed at [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill , but from the day of [his]451-the man dismissal to this [he]451-the man and [Harry]65-harry had never met [each other]647-each other face to face . “ [I]68-picky ’m pretty well , thank [ye]451-the man , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . [I]68-picky hope [you]451-the man ’re [the same]1567-the same , and [the ladies]471-the ladies . [The master]193-the master ’s about somewhere , [I]68-picky take it.—Picky , go and find [the master]193-the master . ”[68-picky] [Picky]68-picky was one of [the Polynesians]648-the polynesians , who at once started on [his]451-the man errand . “ Have [you]451-the man been over to [Gangoil]65-harry since [you]451-the man left [it]65-harry ? ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , looking [the man]451-the man full in the face . “ Not [I]65-harry , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . [I]65-harry never go where [I]65-harry ’ve had words . And , to tell [you]451-the man the truth , sugar is better than sheep . [I]65-harry ’m very comfortable [here]260-here , and [I]65-harry never liked [your]451-the man work . ”[65-harry] “ [You]451-the man have n’t been at [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed ? ”[65-harry] “ What , [the Gangoil shed]1573-the gangoil shed ! What the blazes ‘ d [I]65-harry go [there]290-there for ? It ’s a matter of ten miles from [here]260-here . ”[65-harry] “ Seven , [Nokes]58-nokes . ”[65-harry] “ Seven , is it ? [It]1576-it is a longish seven miles , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . How could [I]65-harry get that distance ? [I]65-harry ai n’t so good at walking as [I]65-harry was before [I]65-harry was hurt . [You]451-the man should have remembered that , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , when [you]451-the man laid hands on [me]65-harry the other day . ”[65-harry] “ [You]451-the man ’re not much the worse for what [I]65-harry did ; nor yet for the accident , [I]65-harry take it . At any rate , [you]451-the man ’ve not been at [Gangoil wool - shed]1577-gangoil wool - shed ? ”[65-harry] “ No , [I]451-the man ’ve not , ”[451-the man] said [the man]451-the man , roughly . “ What the mischief should [I]451-the man be doing at [[your]451-the man shed]1578-your shed at night - time ? ”[451-the man] “ [I]65-harry said nothing about night - time . ”[65-harry] “ [I]451-the man ’m [here]260-here all day , ai n’t [I]451-the man ? If [you]451-the man ’re going to palm off any story against [me]451-the man , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , [you]451-the man ’ll find [yourself]451-the man in the wrong box . What [I]451-the man does [I]451-the man does on [the square]1580-the square . ”[451-the man] [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote was now quite sure that [Jacko]51-jacko had been right . [He]57-mr. heathcote had not doubted much before , but now [he]57-mr. heathcote did not doubt at all but that [the man with whom [he]57-mr. heathcote was speaking]651-the man with whom he was speaking was the wretch who was endeavoring to ruin [him]57-mr. heathcote . And [he]57-mr. heathcote felt certain , also , that [Jacko]51-jacko was true to [him]57-mr. heathcote . [He]57-mr. heathcote knew , too , that [he]57-mr. heathcote had plainly declared [his]57-mr. heathcote suspicion to [the man]451-the man [himself]57-mr. heathcote . But [he]57-mr. heathcote had resolved upon doing this . [He]57-mr. heathcote could in no way assist [himself]57-mr. heathcote in circumventing [the man]451-the man ’s villainy by keeping [his]57-mr. heathcote suspense to [himself]57-mr. heathcote . [The man]451-the man might be frightened , and in spite of all that had passed between [him]451-the man and [Medlicot]47-medlicot , [he]57-mr. heathcote still thought it possible that [he]57-mr. heathcote might induce [the sugar grower]553-the sugar grower to co - operate with [him]57-mr. heathcote in driving [Nokes]58-nokes from [the neighborhood]1559-the neighborhood . [He]57-mr. heathcote had spent the night in thinking over it all , and this was the resolution to which [he]57-mr. heathcote had come . “ There ’s [the master]193-the master , ”[58-nokes] said [Nokes]58-nokes . “ If [you]65-harry ’ve got any thing to say about any thing , [you]65-harry ’d better say it to [him]193-the master . ”[58-nokes] [Harry]65-harry had never before set [his]65-harry foot upon [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s land]657-medlicot ’s land since [it]657-medlicot ’s land had been bought away from [his]65-harry own run , and had felt that [he]65-harry would almost demean [himself]65-harry by doing so . [He]65-harry had often looked at the canes from over [his]65-harry own fence , as [he]65-harry had done on the night of the rain ; but [he]65-harry had stood always on [[his]65-harry own land]658-his own land . Now [he]65-harry was in [the sugar - mill]419-the sugar - mill , never before having seen [such a building]660-such a building . “ [You]47-medlicot ’ve a deal of machinery here , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , ”[65-harry] [he]65-harry said . “ It ’s a small affair , after all , ”[388-the other] said [the other]388-the other . “ [I]388-the other hope to get a good plant before [I]388-the other ’ve done . ”[388-the other] “ Can [I]388-the other speak a word with [you]47-medlicot ? ”[388-the other] “ Certainly . Will [you]47-medlicot come into [the office]1582-the office , or will [you]47-medlicot go across to [the house]226-the house ? ”[65-harry] [Harry]65-harry said that [the office]1582-the office would do , and followed [Medlicot]47-medlicot into a little box - like inclosure which contained a desk and two stools . “ Not much of [an office]1584-an office , is [it]1584-an office ? What can [I]65-harry do for [you]47-medlicot , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ? ”[65-harry] Then [Harry]65-harry began [his]65-harry story , which [he]65-harry told at considerable length . [He]65-harry apologized for troubling [[his]65-harry neighbor]384-his neighbor at all on the subject , and endeavored to explain , somewhat awkwardly , that as [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot was [a new - comer]479-a new - comer , [he]47-medlicot probably might not understand the kind of treatment to which employers in [the bush]218-the bush were occasionally subject from [[their]666-their men]667-their men . On this matter [he]65-harry said much , which , had [he]65-harry been [a better tactician]668-a better tactician , [he]65-harry might probably have left unspoken . [He]65-harry then went on to the story of [his]65-harry own quarrel with [Nokes]58-nokes , who had , in truth , been grossly impudent to [the women about [the house]226-the house , but who had been punished by instant and violent dismissal from [his]58-nokes employment]669-the women about the house , but who had been punished by instant and violent dismissal from his employment . It was evidently [Harry]65-harry ’s idea that [a man who had so sinned against [[his]65-harry master]337-his master should be allowed to find [no other master]673-no other master — at any rate in [that district]674-that district]671-a man who had so sinned against his master should be allowed to find no other master — at any rate in that district ; an idea with which [the other man]675-the other man , who had lately come out from [the old country]501-the old country , did not at all sympathize . “ Do [you]65-harry want [me]47-medlicot to dismiss [him]58-nokes ? ”[47-medlicot] said [Medlicot]47-medlicot , in a tone which implied that that would be the last thing [he]65-harry would think of doing . “ [You]65-harry have n’t heard [me]47-medlicot yet . ”[47-medlicot] Then [Harry]65-harry went on and told of the fires in the heat of summer , and of their terrible effects — of the easy manner of revenge which [they]677-they supplied to [angry , unscrupulous men]678-angry , unscrupulous men , and of [his]65-harry own fears at the present moment . “ [I]47-medlicot can believe it all , ”[47-medlicot] said [Medlicot]47-medlicot , “ and am very sorry that it should be so . But [I]47-medlicot can not see the justice of punishing [a man]128-a man on the merest , vaguest suspicion . [Your]65-harry only ground for imputing this crime to [him]128-a man is that [your]65-harry own conduct to [him]128-a man may have given [him]128-a man a motive . ”[47-medlicot] [Harry]65-harry had schooled [himself]65-harry vigorously during the ride as to [his]65-harry own demeanor , and had resolved that [he]65-harry would be cool . “ [I]65-harry was going on to tell [you]65-harry , ”[65-harry] [he]65-harry said , “ what occurred that night after [I]65-harry saw [you]65-harry up by the fence . ”[65-harry] Then [he]65-harry described how [he]65-harry and [[his]65-harry boy]679-his boy had entered [the shed]1484-the shed , and had both seen and heard [a man]128-a man as [he]128-a man escaped from [it]1484-the shed ; how [the boy]375-the boy had at once declared that [the man]451-the man was [Nokes]58-nokes ; how the following day [he]375-the boy had discovered the leaves , which [Nokes]58-nokes no doubt had deposited there just before the rain , intending to burn [the place]1437-the place at once ; and how [Nokes]58-nokes ’s manner to [him]128-a man within the last half hour had corroborated [his]65-harry suspicions . “ Is [he]451-the man [the boy [you]65-harry call [Jacko]51-jacko]1586-the boy you call jacko ? ”[58-nokes] “ That ’s the name [he]451-the man goes by . ”[58-nokes] “ [You]65-harry do n’t know [his]451-the man real name ? ”[58-nokes] “ [I]58-nokes have never heard any other name . ”[58-nokes] “ Nor any thing about [him]451-the man ? ”[58-nokes] [Harry]65-harry owned , in answer to half a dozen such questions , that [Jacko]51-jacko had come to [Gangoil]65-harry about six months ago — [he]51-jacko did not know whence — had been kept for a week ’s job , and had then been allowed to remain about [the place]1437-the place without any regular wages . “ [You]65-harry admit it was quite dark , ”[47-medlicot] continued [Medlicot]47-medlicot . [Harry]65-harry did not at all like the cross - examination , and [his]65-harry resolution to be cool was quickly fading . “ [I]65-harry told [you]65-harry that [I]65-harry saw [myself]65-harry the figure of [a man]128-a man . ”[65-harry] “ But that [you]65-harry barely saw a figure . [You]65-harry did not form any opinion of [your]65-harry own as to [the man]451-the man ’s identity . ”[65-harry] [Harry Heathcote]65-harry was as honest as the sun . Much as [he]65-harry disliked being cross - examined , [he]65-harry found [himself]65-harry compelled not only to say the exact truth , but the whole truth . “ Certainly not . [I]65-harry barely saw a glimpse of a figure , and , till [I]65-harry spoke to [Nokes]58-nokes just now , [I]65-harry almost doubted whether [the lad]149-the lad could have distinguished [him]451-the man . [I]65-harry am sure [he]451-the man was right now . ”[65-harry] “ Really , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , [I]65-harry ca n’t go along with [you]57-mr. heathcote . [You]57-mr. heathcote are accusing [a man]128-a man of committing an offense , which [I]65-harry believe is capital , on the evidence of [a boy of whom [you]57-mr. heathcote know nothing , who may have [his]1591-a boy of whom you know nothing , who may have his own reasons for spiting the man own reasons for spiting [the man]451-the man]1591-a boy of whom you know nothing , who may have his own reasons for spiting the man , and whom [you]57-mr. heathcote [yourself]57-mr. heathcote did not believe till [you]57-mr. heathcote had looked [this man]497-this man in the face . [I]65-harry think [you]57-mr. heathcote allow [yourself]57-mr. heathcote to be guided too much by [your]57-mr. heathcote own power of intuition . ”[65-harry] “ No , [I]65-harry do n’t , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , who hated [[his]65-harry neighbor]384-his neighbor ’s methodical argument . “ At any rate , [I]65-harry ca n’t consent to take [a man]128-a man ’s bread out of [his]128-a man mouth , and to send [him]128-a man away tainted as [he]128-a man would be with this suspicion , either because [Jacko]51-jacko thought that [he]51-jacko saw [him]128-a man in the dark , or because — ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry have never asked [you]384-his neighbor to send [him]128-a man away . ”[65-harry] “ What is it [you]384-his neighbor want , then ? ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry want to have [him]128-a man watched , so that [he]128-a man may feel that if [he]128-a man attempts to destroy [[my]65-harry property]1595-my property [his]128-a man guilt will be detected . ”[65-harry] “ Who is to watch [him]128-a man ? ”[65-harry] “ [He]128-a man is in [your]384-his neighbor employment . ”[65-harry] “ [He]128-a man lives in [the hut]1596-the hut down beyond the gate . Am [I]65-harry to keep [a sentry]1597-a sentry [there]290-there all night , and every night ? ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry will pay for it . ”[65-harry] “ No , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . [I]65-harry do n’t pretend to know [this country]1599-this country yet , but [I]65-harry ’ll encourage no such espionage as that . At any rate , it is not English . [I]65-harry dare say [the man]451-the man misbehaved [himself]451-the man in [your]384-his neighbor employment . [You]384-his neighbor say [he]451-the man was drunk . [I]65-harry do not doubt it . But [he]451-the man is not [a drunkard]1601-a drunkard , for [he]451-the man never drinks [here]260-here . [A man]128-a man is not to starve forever because [he]128-a man once got drunk and was impertinent . Nor is [he]128-a man to have [a spy]1604-a spy at [his]128-a man heels because [a boy whom [nobody knows]1606-nobody knows]1605-a boy whom nobody knows chooses to denounce [him]128-a man . [I]65-harry am sorry that [you]65-harry should be in trouble , but [I]65-harry do not know that [I]65-harry can help [you]65-harry . ”[65-harry] [Harry]65-harry ’s passion was now very high , and [his]65-harry resolution to be cool was almost thrown to the winds . [Medlicot]47-medlicot had said many things which were odious to [him]65-harry . In the first place , there had been a tone of insufferable superiority , so [Harry]65-harry thought , and that , too , when [he]65-harry [himself]65-harry had divested [himself]65-harry of all the superiority naturally attached to [his]65-harry position , and had frankly appealed to [Medlicot]47-medlicot as [a neighbor]687-a neighbor . And then [this new - fangled sugar grower]688-this new - fangled sugar grower had told [him]65-harry that [he]65-harry was not English , and had said grand words , and had altogether made [himself]65-harry objectionable . What did [this man]497-this man know of [the Australian bush]502-the australian bush , that [he]497-this man should dare to talk of this or that as being wrong because it was un - English ! In [England]8-england there were [police]691-police to guard [[men]130-men ’s property]693-men ’s property . Here , out in [the Australian forests]694-the australian forests , [a man]128-a man must guard [his]128-a man own , or lose it . But perhaps it was the indifference to the ruin of [the women belonging to [him]128-a man]696-the women belonging to him that [Harry Heathcote]65-harry felt the strongest . [The stranger]207-the stranger cared nothing for the utter desolation which [one unscrupulous ruffian]698-one unscrupulous ruffian might produce , felt no horror at the idea of a vast devastating fire , but could be indignant in [his]128-a man mock philanthropy because it was proposed to watch the doings of [a scoundrel]699-a scoundrel ! “ Good - morning , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , turning round and leaving [the office]1582-the office brusquely . [Medlicot]47-medlicot followed [him]65-harry , but [Harry]65-harry went so quickly that not another word was spoken . To [him]65-harry the idea of [a neighbor in the bush]701-a neighbor in the bush refusing such assistance as [he]65-harry had asked was as terrible as to [us]702-us is the thought of [a ship]703-a ship at sea leaving [another ship]704-another ship in distress . [He]65-harry unhitched [his]65-harry horse from the fence , and galloped [home]103-home as fast as the animal would carry [him]65-harry . [Medlicot]47-medlicot , when [he]47-medlicot was left alone , took two or three turns about [the mill]484-the mill , as though inspecting the work , but at every turn fixed [his]47-medlicot eyes for a few moments on [Noke]69-noke ’s face . [The man]451-the man was standing under a huge caldron regulating the escape of the boiling juice into the different vats by raising and lowering a trap , and giving directions to [the Polynesians]648-the polynesians as [he]451-the man did so . [He]451-the man was evidently conscious that [he]451-the man was being regarded , and , as is usual in such a condition , manifestly failed in [his]451-the man struggle to appear unconscious . [Medlicot]47-medlicot acknowledged to [himself]47-medlicot that [the man]451-the man could not look even [him]47-medlicot in the face . Was it possible that [he]47-medlicot had been wrong , and that [Heathcote]65-harry , though [he]65-harry had expressed [himself]65-harry badly , was entitled to some sympathy in [his]65-harry fear of what might be done to [him]65-harry by [an enemy]578-an enemy ? [Medlicot]47-medlicot also desired to be just , being more rational , more logical , and less impulsive than the other , being also somewhat too conscious of [his]47-medlicot own superior intelligence . [He]47-medlicot knew that [Heathcote]65-harry had gone away in great dudgeon , and [he]47-medlicot almost feared that [he]65-harry had been harsh and unneighborly . After a while [he]47-medlicot stood opposite [Nokes]58-nokes and addressed [him]451-the man . “ Do [the squatters]489-the squatters suffer much from fires ? ”[47-medlicot] [he]47-medlicot said . “ [Heathcote]65-harry has been talking to [you]47-medlicot about that , ”[451-the man] said [the man]451-the man . “ Ca n’t [you]47-medlicot say [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote when [you]47-medlicot speak of [a gentleman whose bread [you]47-medlicot have eaten]1608-a gentleman whose bread you have eaten ? ”[451-the man] “ [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , if [you]47-medlicot like it . [We]1609-we ai n’t particular to a shade out here as [you]47-medlicot are at [home]103-home . [He]65-harry has been telling [you]47-medlicot about fires , has [he]65-harry ? ”[47-medlicot] “ Well , [he]65-harry has . ”[47-medlicot] “ And talking of [me]451-the man , [I]451-the man suppose ? ”[451-the man] “ [You]47-medlicot were talking of having a turn at mining some day . How would it be with [you]47-medlicot if [you]47-medlicot were to be off to [Gympie]15-gympie ? ”[47-medlicot] “ [You]47-medlicot mean to say [I]47-medlicot ’m to go , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot ? ”[47-medlicot] “ [I]451-the man do n’t say that at all . ”[451-the man] “ Look here , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . [My]47-medlicot going or staying wo n’t make any difference to [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . There ’s a lot of ’em about here hates [him]57-mr. heathcote that much that [he]57-mr. heathcote is never to be allowed to rest in peace . [I]47-medlicot tell [you]47-medlicot that fairly . It ai n’t any thing as [I]47-medlicot shall do . [Them]1611-them ’s not [my]47-medlicot ways , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . But [he]57-mr. heathcote has [enemies here]1612-enemies here as’ll never let [him]57-mr. heathcote rest . ”[47-medlicot] “ Who are [they]1612-enemies here ? ”[47-medlicot] “ Pretty nigh every body round . [He]57-mr. heathcote has carried [himself]57-mr. heathcote that high [they]1612-enemies here wo n’t stand [him]57-mr. heathcote . Who ’s [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ? ”[451-the man] “ Name [some who are [[his]57-mr. heathcote enemies]152-his enemies]1613-some who are his enemies . ”[451-the man] “ There ’s [the Brownbies]65-harry . ”[47-medlicot] “ Oh , [the Brownbies]65-harry . Well , it ’s a bad thing to have [enemies]1464-enemies . ”[451-the man] After that [he]712-he left [the sugar - house]713-the sugar - house and went across to [the cottage]272-the cottage . Two days and two nights passed without fear of fire , and then [Harry Heathcote]65-harry was again on the alert . [The earth]1502-the earth was parched as though no drop of rain had fallen . The fences were dry as tinder , and the ground was strewed with broken atoms of timber from the trees , each of which a spark would ignite . Two nights [Harry]65-harry slept in [his]65-harry bed , but on the third [he]65-harry was on horseback about the run , watching , thinking , endeavoring to make provision , directing [others]158-others , and hoping to make it believed that [his]65-harry eyes were every where . In this way an entire week was passed , and now it wanted but four days to Christmas . [He]65-harry would come [home]103-home to breakfast about seven in the morning , very tired , but never owning that [he]65-harry was tired , and then sleep heavily for an hour or two in a chair . After that [he]65-harry would go out again on the run , would sleep perhaps for another hour after dinner , and then would start for [his]65-harry night ’s patrol . During this week [he]65-harry saw nothing of [Medlicot]47-medlicot , and never mentioned [his]47-medlicot name but once . On that occasion [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife told [him]65-harry that during [his]65-harry absence [Medlicot]47-medlicot had been at [the station]249-the station . “ What brought [him]47-medlicot [here]260-here ? ”[65-harry] [Harry]65-harry asked , fiercely . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote explained that [he]65-harry had called in a friendly way , and had said that if there were any fear of fire [he]65-harry would be happy [himself]65-harry to lend assistance . Then [the young squatter]461-the young squatter forgot [himself]65-harry in [his]65-harry wrath . “ Confound [his]47-medlicot hypocrisy ! ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , aloud . “ [I]108-the wife do n’t think [he]47-medlicot ’s [a hypocrite]1617-a hypocrite , ”[108-the wife] said [the wife]108-the wife . “ [I]41-kate ’m sure [he]47-medlicot ’s not , ”[41-kate] said [Kate Daly]41-kate . Not a word more was spoken , and [Harry]65-harry immediately left [the house]226-the house . [The two women]594-the two women did not as usual go to the gate to see [him]65-harry mount [his]65-harry horse , not refraining from doing so in any anger , or as wishing to exhibit displeasure at [Harry]65-harry ’s violence , but because [they]594-the two women were afraid of [him]65-harry . [They]594-the two women had found [themselves]594-the two women compelled to differ from [him]65-harry , but were oppressed at finding [themselves]594-the two women in opposition to [him]65-harry . The feeling that [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife should in any way take part against [him]65-harry added greatly to [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ’s trouble . It produced in [his]65-harry mind a terrible feeling of loneliness in [his]65-harry sorrow . [He]65-harry bore a brave outside to [all [[his]65-harry men]726-his men , and to [any stranger whom in these days [he]65-harry met about the run]727-any stranger whom in these days he met about the run — to [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife and [sister]729-sister also , and to [the old woman at [home]103-home]730-the old woman at home]725-all his men , and to any stranger whom in these days he met about the run — to his wife and sister also , and to the old woman at home . [He]65-harry forced upon [them]726-his men all an idea that [he]65-harry was not only autocratic , but self - sufficient also — that [he]65-harry wanted neither help nor sympathy . [He]65-harry never cried out in [his]65-harry pain , being heartily ashamed even of the appeal which [he]65-harry had made to [Medlicot]47-medlicot . [He]65-harry spoke aloud and laughed with [the men]292-the men , and never acknowledged that [his]65-harry trials were almost too much for [him]65-harry . But [he]65-harry was painfully conscious of [his]65-harry own weakness . [He]65-harry sometimes felt , when alone in the bush , that [he]65-harry would fain get off [his]65-harry horse , and lie upon the ground and weep till [he]65-harry slept . It was not that [he]65-harry trusted [no one]339-no one . [He]65-harry suspected [no one]339-no one with a positive suspicion , except [Nokes]58-nokes , and [Medlicot]47-medlicot as [the supporter of [Nokes]58-nokes]735-the supporter of nokes . But [he]65-harry had [no one with whom [he]65-harry could converse freely — none whom [he]65-harry had not been accustomed to treat as [the mere ministers of [his]65-harry will]737-the mere ministers of his will — except [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife and [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife ’s sister]736-no one with whom he could converse freely — none whom he had not been accustomed to treat as the mere ministers of his will — except his wife and his wife ’s sister ; and now [he]65-harry was disjoined from [them]740-them by [their]740-them sympathy with [Medlicot]47-medlicot ! [He]65-harry had chosen to manage every thing [himself]65-harry without contradiction and almost without counsel ; but , like [other such imperious masters]741-other such imperious masters , [he]65-harry now found that when trouble came the privilege of dictatorship brought with it an almost unsupportable burden . [Old Bates]38-old bates was [an excellent man , of whose fidelity]742-an excellent man , of whose fidelity [the young squatter]461-the young squatter was quite assured . [No one]339-no one understood foot - rot better than [Old Bates]38-old bates , or was less sparing of [himself]65-harry in curing it . [He]38-old bates was [a second mother to all the lambs]745-a second mother to all the lambs , and when shearing came watched with the eyes of [Argus]70-argus to see that the sheep were not wounded by [the shearers]746-the shearers , or the wool left on [their]746-the shearers backs . But [he]65-harry had no conversation , none of that imagination which in such a time as this might have assisted in devising safeguards , and but little enthusiasm . [Shepherds]747-shepherds , so called , [Harry]65-harry kept none upon the run ; and would have felt [himself]65-harry insulted had [any one]1493-any one suggested that [he]65-harry was so backward in [his]65-harry ways as to employ [men of that denomination]749-men of that denomination . [He]65-harry had fenced [his]65-harry run , and dispensed with [shepherds]747-shepherds and shepherding as old - fashioned and unprofitable . [He]65-harry had [two mounted men]751-two mounted men , whom [he]65-harry called [boundary riders]752-boundary riders , [one an Irishman]753-one an irishman and [the other a German]754-the other a german — and [them]751-two mounted men [he]65-harry trusted fully , [the German]415-the german altogether , and [the Irishman]756-the irishman equally as regarded [his]65-harry honesty . But [he]65-harry could not explain to [them]751-two mounted men the thoughts that loaded [his]65-harry brain . [He]65-harry could instigate them to eagerness ; but [he]65-harry could not condescend to tell [Karl Bender]59-karl bender , [the German]415-the german , that if [his]65-harry fences were destroyed neither [his]65-harry means nor [his]65-harry credit would be sufficient to put them up again , and that if the scanty herbage were burned off any large proportion of [his]65-harry run , [he]65-harry must sell [his]65-harry flocks at a great sacrifice . Nor could [he]65-harry explain to [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey , [the Irishman]756-the irishman , that [his]49-mickey peace of mind was destroyed by [his]49-mickey fear of [one man]759-one man . [He]65-harry had to bear it all alone . And there was heavy on [him]65-harry also the great misery of feeling that every thing might depend on own exertions , and that yet [he]65-harry did not know how or where to exert [himself]65-harry . When [he]65-harry had ridden about all night and discovered nothing , [he]65-harry might just as well have been in bed . And [he]65-harry was continually riding about all night and discovering nothing . After leaving [the station]249-the station on the evening of the day on which [he]65-harry had expressed [himself]65-harry to [the women]601-the women so vehemently respecting [Medlicot]47-medlicot , [he]65-harry met [Bates]38-old bates coming [home]103-home from [his]65-harry day ’s work . It was then past eight o’clock , and [the old man]763-the old man was sitting wearily on [his]763-the old man horse , with [his]763-the old man head low down between [his]763-the old man shoulders , and the reins hardly held within [his]763-the old man grasp . “ [You]71-mr. bates ’re late , [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry ; “ [you]71-mr. bates take too much out of [yourself]71-mr. bates this hot weather . ”[65-harry] “ [I]71-mr. bates ’ve got to move slower , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , as [I]71-mr. bates grow older . That ’s about it . And the beast [I]71-mr. bates ’m on is not much good . ”[71-mr. bates] Now [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates was always complaining of [his]71-mr. bates horse , and yet was allowed to choose any on the run for [his]71-mr. bates own use . “ If [you]57-mr. heathcote do n’t like [him]763-the old man , why do n’t [you]57-mr. heathcote take another ? ”[65-harry] “ There ai n’t much difference in ’em , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . Better the devil [you]57-mr. heathcote know than the devil [you]57-mr. heathcote do n’t . It ’s getting uncommon close shaving for [them]1618-they wethers in [the new paddock]1619-the new paddock . [They]1618-they ’re down upon the roots pretty well already . ”[65-harry] “ There ’s grass along the bush on [the north side]1620-the north side . ”[65-harry] “ [They]1618-they wo n’t go there ; it ’s rank and sour . [They]1618-they wo n’t feed up there as long as [they]1618-they can live lower down and nearer [the water]1621-the water . Weather like this , [they]1618-they ’d sooner die near the water than travel to fill [their]1618-they bellies . It ’s about the hottest day [we]1622-we ’ve had , and the nights a’most hotter . Are [you]57-mr. heathcote going to be out , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ? ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry think so . ”[65-harry] “ What ’s the good of it , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ? There is no use in it . [Lord]1623-lord love [you]57-mr. heathcote , what can [yon]57-mr. heathcote do ? [You]57-mr. heathcote ca n’t be every side at once . ”[65-harry] “ Fire can only travel with the wind , [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates . ”[65-harry] “ And there is n’t any wind , and so there ca n’t be any fire . [I]65-harry never did think , and [I]65-harry do n’t think now , there ever was any use in [a man]128-a man fashing [himself]128-a man as [you]57-mr. heathcote fash [yourself]57-mr. heathcote . [You]57-mr. heathcote ca n’t alter things , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . ”[65-harry] “ But that ’s just what [I]65-harry can do — what [a man]128-a man has to do . If a match were thrown there at [your]57-mr. heathcote feet , and the grass was aflame , could n’t [you]57-mr. heathcote alter that by putting [your]57-mr. heathcote foot on it ? If [you]57-mr. heathcote find a ewe on [her]1626-her back , ca n’t [you]57-mr. heathcote alter that by putting [her]1626-her on [her]1626-her legs ? ”[65-harry] “ Yes , [I]65-harry can do that , [I]65-harry suppose . ”[65-harry] “ What does [a man]128-a man live for except to alter things ? When [a man]128-a man clears [the forest]361-the forest and sows corn , does [he]128-a man not alter things ? ”[65-harry] “ That ’s not [your]57-mr. heathcote line , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , ”[764-the cunning old man] said [the cunning old man]764-the cunning old man . “ If [I]764-the cunning old man send wool to market , [I]764-the cunning old man alter things . ”[764-the cunning old man] “ [You]57-mr. heathcote ’ll excuse [me]65-harry , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . Of course [I]65-harry ’m old , but [I]65-harry just give [you]57-mr. heathcote [my]65-harry experience . ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry ’m much obliged to [you]57-mr. heathcote ; though [we]1630-we ca n’t always agree , [you]57-mr. heathcote know . Good - night . Go in and say a word to [[my]65-harry wife]1631-my wife , and tell [them]1631-my wife [you]57-mr. heathcote saw [me]65-harry all right . ”[65-harry] “ [I]65-harry ’ll have a crack with [’em]1632-’em , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , before [I]65-harry turn in . ”[65-harry] “ And tell [Mary]40-mary [I]65-harry sent [[my]65-harry love]1633-my love . ”[65-harry] “ [I]765-he will , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ; [I]765-he will . ”[765-he] [He]765-he was thinking always of [[his]765-he wife]104-his wife during [his]765-he solitary rides , and of [her]104-his wife fear and deep anxiety . It was for [her]104-his wife sake and for [the children]767-the children that [he]765-he was so care - worn , not for [his]765-he own . Had [he]765-he been alone in [the world]1427-the world [he]765-he would not have fretted [himself]765-he in this fashion because of the malice of [any man]418-any man . But how would it be with [her]104-his wife should [he]765-he be forced to move [her]104-his wife from [Gangoil]65-harry ? And yet , with all [his]765-he love , [they]770-they had parted almost in anger . Surely [she]104-his wife would understand the tenderness of the message [he]765-he had just sent [her]104-his wife . Of a sudden , as [he]765-he was riding , [he]765-he stopped [his]765-he horse and listened attentively . From a great distance there fell upon [his]765-he accustomed ear a sound which [he]765-he recognized , though [he]765-he was aware that the place from whence it came was at least two miles distant . It was the thud of an axe against a tree . [He]765-he listened still , and was sure that it was so , and turned at once toward the sound , though in doing so [he]765-he left [his]765-he course at a right angle . [He]765-he had been going directly away from [the river]164-the river , with [his]765-he back to [the wool - shed]328-the wool - shed ; but now [he]765-he changed [his]765-he course , riding in the direction of [the spot at which [Jacko]51-jacko had nearly fallen in jumping over the fence]773-the spot at which jacko had nearly fallen in jumping over the fence . As [he]765-he continued on , the sounds became plainer , till at last , reining in [his]765-he horse , [he]765-he could see the form of [the woodman]774-the woodman , who was still at work ringing the trees . This was a job which [the man]451-the man did by contract , receiving so much an acre for the depopulation of the timber . It was now bright moonlight , almost as clear as day — a very different night , indeed , from that on which the rain had come — and [Harry]65-harry could see at a glance that it was [the man called [Boscobel]53-boscobel still at work]776-the man called boscobel still at work . Now there were , as [he]65-harry thought , very good reasons why [Boscobel]53-boscobel at the present moment should not be so employed . [Boscobel]53-boscobel was receiving wages for work of another kind . “ [Bos]72-bos , ”[503-the squatter] said [the squatter]503-the squatter , riding up , and addressing [the man]451-the man by the customary abbreviation of [his]503-the squatter nickname , “ [I]503-the squatter thought [you]451-the man were watching at [[Brownbie]43-georgie ’s boundary]1634-brownbie ’s boundary ? ”[503-the squatter] [Boscobel]53-boscobel lowered [his]53-boscobel axe , and stood for a while contemplating the proposition made to [him]451-the man . “ [You]451-the man are drawing three shillings a night for watching ; is n’t that so ? ”[53-boscobel] “ Yes , that ’s so . Anyways , [I]503-the squatter shall draw it . ”[503-the squatter] “ Then why ai n’t [you]451-the man watching ? ”[503-the squatter] “ There ’s nothing to watch that [I]53-boscobel knows on — not just now . ”[53-boscobel] “ Then why should [I]53-boscobel pay [you]451-the man for it ? [I]53-boscobel ’m to pay [you]451-the man for ringing these trees , ai n’t [I]53-boscobel ? ”[53-boscobel] “ Certainly , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . ”[503-the squatter] “ Then [you]451-the man ’re to make double use of [your]451-the man time , and sell it twice over , are [you]451-the man ? Do n’t try to look like [a fool]1635-a fool , as though [you]451-the man did n’t understand . [You]451-the man know that what [you]451-the man ’re doing is n’t honest . ”[53-boscobel] “ [Nobody]1636-nobody ever said as [I]53-boscobel was n’t honest before . ”[53-boscobel] “ [I]503-the squatter tell [you]451-the man so now . [You]451-the man ’re robbing [me]503-the squatter of the time [you]451-the man ’ve sold to [me]503-the squatter , and for which [I]503-the squatter ’m to pay [you]451-the man . ”[503-the squatter] “ There ai n’t nothing to watch while the wind ’s as it is now , and that chap ai n’t any where about to - night . ”[53-boscobel] “ What chap ? ”[53-boscobel] “ Oh , [I]503-the squatter know . [I]503-the squatter ’m all right . What ’s the use of dawdling about up there in the broad moonlight , and the wind like this ? ”[503-the squatter] “ That ’s for [me]53-boscobel to judge . If [you]451-the man engage to do [my]53-boscobel work and take [my]53-boscobel money , [you]451-the man ’re swindling [me]53-boscobel when [you]451-the man go about another job as [you]451-the man are now . [You]451-the man need n’t scratch [your]451-the man head . [You]451-the man understand it all as well as [I]53-boscobel do . ”[53-boscobel] “ [I]503-the squatter never was told [I]503-the squatter swindled before , and [I]503-the squatter ai n’t a - going to put up with it . [You]451-the man may ring [your]451-the man own trees , and watch [your]451-the man own fences , and [the whole place]1637-the whole place may be burned for [me]503-the squatter . [I]503-the squatter ai n’t a - going to do another turn in [Gangoil]65-harry . Swindle , indeed ! ”[503-the squatter] [So Boscobel]53-boscobel shouldered [his]779-he axe , and marched off through [the forest]361-the forest , visible in the moonlight till the trees hid [him]779-he . There was [another enemy made]781-another enemy made ! [He]779-he had never felt quite sure of [this man]497-this man , but had been glad to have [him]497-this man about [the place]1437-the place as being thoroughly efficient in [his]497-this man own business . It was only during the last ten days that [he]779-he had agreed to pay [him]497-this man for night - watching , leaving [the man]451-the man to do as much additional day - work as [he]451-the man pleased — for which , of course , [he]451-the man would be paid at the regular contract price . There was a double purpose intended in this watching — as was well understood by [all the hands employed]785-all the hands employed : first , that of preventing incendiary fire by the mere presence of [the watchers]786-the watchers ; and secondly , that of being at hand to extinguish fire in case of need . Now [a man ringing trees five or six miles away from [the beat on which [he]787-a man ringing trees five or six miles away from the beat on which he was stationed was stationed]788-the beat on which he was stationed]787-a man ringing trees five or six miles away from the beat on which he was stationed could not serve either of these purposes . [Boscobel]53-boscobel therefore had been fraudulently at work for [his]53-boscobel own dishonest purposes , and knew well that [his]53-boscobel employment was of that nature . All this was quite clear to [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ; and it was clear to [him]57-mr. heathcote , also , that when [he]57-mr. heathcote detected fraud [he]57-mr. heathcote was bound to expose it . Had [the man]451-the man acknowledged [his]451-the man fault and been submissive , there would have been an end of the matter . [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote would have said no word about it to [any one]1493-any one , and would not have stopped a farthing from the week ’s unearned wages . That [he]57-mr. heathcote had to encounter a certain amount of ill usage from [the rough men about [him]57-mr. heathcote]791-the rough men about him , and to forgive it , [he]57-mr. heathcote could understand ; but it could not be [his]57-mr. heathcote duty , either as [a man]128-a man or [a master]793-a master , to pass over dishonesty without noticing it . No ; that [he]57-mr. heathcote would not do , though [Gangoil]65-harry should burn from end to end . [He]57-mr. heathcote did not much mind being robbed . [He]57-mr. heathcote knew that to a certain extent [he]57-mr. heathcote must endure to be cheated . [He]57-mr. heathcote would endure it . But [he]57-mr. heathcote would never teach [[his]57-mr. heathcote men]726-his men to think that [he]57-mr. heathcote passed over such matters because [he]57-mr. heathcote was afraid of [them]726-his men , or that dishonesty on [their]726-his men part was indifferent to [him]57-mr. heathcote . But now [he]57-mr. heathcote had made [another enemy]795-another enemy — [an enemy of [a man who had declared to [him]57-mr. heathcote that [he]57-mr. heathcote knew the movements of “ [that chap , ”[795-another enemy] meaning Nokes]1638-that chap , ” meaning nokes]797-a man who had declared to him that he knew the movements of “ that chap , ” meaning nokes ! How hard [the world]1427-the world was]796-an enemy of a man who had declared to him that he knew the movements of “ that chap , ” meaning nokes ! how hard the world was ! It seemed that all around were trouble to [him]57-mr. heathcote . [He]57-mr. heathcote turned [his]57-mr. heathcote horse back , and made again for the spot which was [[his]57-mr. heathcote original destination]799-his original destination . As [he]57-mr. heathcote cantered on among the trees , twisting here and there , and regulating [his]57-mr. heathcote way by the stars , [he]57-mr. heathcote asked [himself]57-mr. heathcote whether it would not be better for [him]57-mr. heathcote to go [home]103-home and lay [himself]57-mr. heathcote down by [[his]57-mr. heathcote wife]104-his wife and sleep , and await the worst that [these men]802-these men could do to [him]57-mr. heathcote . This idea was so strong upon [him]57-mr. heathcote that at one spot [he]57-mr. heathcote made [his]57-mr. heathcote horse stop till [he]57-mr. heathcote had thought it all out . [No one]339-no one encouraged [him]57-mr. heathcote in [his]57-mr. heathcote work . [Every one about [the place]1437-the place]804-every one about the place , [friend or foe]806-friend or foe , [Bates]71-mr. bates , [[his]71-mr. bates wife]104-his wife , [Medlicot]47-medlicot , and [this Boscobel]808-this boscobel , spoke to [him]57-mr. heathcote as though [he]57-mr. heathcote were fussy and fidgety in [his]57-mr. heathcote anxiety . “ If fires must come , [they]809-they will come ; and if [they]809-they are not to come , [you]57-mr. heathcote are simply losing [your]57-mr. heathcote labor . ”[57-mr. heathcote] This was the upshot of all [they]809-they said to [him]57-mr. heathcote . Why should [he]57-mr. heathcote be wiser than [they]809-they ? If the ruin came , let it come . [Old Bates]38-old bates had been ruined , but still had enough to eat and drink , and clothes to wear , and did not work half as hard as [[his]38-old bates employer]414-his employer . [He]38-old bates thought that if [he]38-old bates could only find [some one person who would sympathize with [him]38-old bates and support [him]38-old bates]811-some one person who would sympathize with him and support him , [he]38-old bates would not mind . But the mental loneliness of [his]38-old bates position almost broke [his]38-old bates heart . Then there came across [his]38-old bates mind the dim remembrance of certain old school words , and [he]38-old bates touched [his]38-old bates horse with [his]38-old bates spur and hurried onward : “ Let there be no steps backward . ”[38-old bates] A thought as to the manliness of persevering , of the want of manliness in yielding to depression , came to [his]38-old bates rescue . Let [him]38-old bates , at any rate , have the comfort of thinking that [he]38-old bates had done [his]38-old bates best according to [his]38-old bates lights . After some dim fashion , [he]38-old bates did come to recognize it as a fact that nothing could really support [him]38-old bates but self - approbation . Though [he]38-old bates fell from [his]38-old bates horse in utter weariness , [he]38-old bates would persevere . As the night wore on [he]38-old bates came to [[the German]415-the german ’s hut]1415-the german ’s hut , and finding [it]1415-the german ’s hut empty , as [he]38-old bates expected , rode on to the outside fence of [his]38-old bates run . When [he]38-old bates reached this [he]38-old bates got off [his]38-old bates horse , and taking a key out of [his]38-old bates pocket , whistled upon it loudly . A few minutes afterward [the German]415-the german came up to [him]38-old bates . “ There ’s been [no one]339-no one about , [I]38-old bates suppose ? ”[38-old bates] [he]38-old bates asked . “ Not a one , ”[451-the man] said [the man]451-the man . “ [You]38-old bates ’ve been across on [Brownbie]43-georgie ’s run ? ”[451-the man] “ [We]816-we ’re on [it]1640-it now , [Mr. ‘ Eathcote]73-mr. ‘ eathcote . ”[816-we] [They]816-we were both on the side of the fence away from [Gangoil station]65-harry . “ [I]816-we do n’t know how that is , [Karl]59-karl bender . [I]816-we think [Gangoil]65-harry goes a quarter of a mile beyond this . But [we]816-we did not quite strike the boundary when [we]816-we put up the fence . ”[816-we] “ [Brownbie]43-georgie ’s cattle is allays here , [Mr. ‘ Eathcote]73-mr. ‘ eathcote , and is knocking down the fence every day . [Brownbie]43-georgie is [a rascal]1641-a rascal , and ‘ is cattle as bad as ‘ isself . ”[451-the man] “ Never mind that , [Karl]59-karl bender , now . When [we]816-we ’ve got through the heats , [we]816-we ’ll put a mile or two of better fencing along here . [You]59-karl bender know [Boscobel]53-boscobel ? ”[816-we] “ In course [I]816-we know [Bos]72-bos . ”[816-we] “ What sort of [a fellow]1504-a fellow is [he]53-boscobel ? ”[451-the man] Then [Harry]65-harry told [his]65-harry German dependent exactly what had taken place between [him]65-harry and [the other man]675-the other man . “ [He]53-boscobel ’s in and in wid all [them]1643-they [young Brownbies]65-harry , ”[59-karl bender] said [Karl]59-karl bender . “ [The Brownbies]65-harry are a bad lot , but [I]65-harry do n’t think [they]1643-they ’d do any thing of this kind , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , whose mind was still dwelling on the dangers of fire . “ [They]1643-they likes muttons , [Mr. ‘ Eathcote]73-mr. ‘ eathcote . ”[65-harry] “ [I]451-the man suppose [they]1643-they do take a sheep or two now and then . [They]1643-they would n’t do worse than that , would [they]1643-they ? ”[451-the man] “ Not’ing too ‘ ot for ’em ; not’ing too ‘ eavy , ”[59-karl bender] said [Karl]59-karl bender , smoking [his]59-karl bender pipe . “ The vind , vat there is , comes just here , [Mr. ‘ Eathcote]73-mr. ‘ eathcote . ”[59-karl bender] And [the man]451-the man lifted up [his]451-the man arm , and pointed across in the direction of [[Brownbie]43-georgie ’s run]819-brownbie ’s run . “ And [you]451-the man do n’t think much of [Boscobel]53-boscobel ? ”[451-the man] [Karl Bender]59-karl bender shook [his]59-karl bender head . “ [He]53-boscobel was always well treated [here]260-here , ”[65-harry] said [Harry]65-harry , “ and has had plenty of work , and earned large wages . [The man]451-the man will be a fool to quarrel with [me]65-harry . ”[65-harry] [Karl]59-karl bender again shook [his]59-karl bender head . With [Karl Bender]59-karl bender , [Harry]65-harry was quite sure of [[his]65-harry man]820-his man , but not on that account need [he]65-harry be quite sure of the correctness of [the man]451-the man ’s opinion . Thence [he]65-harry went on till [he]65-harry met [[his]65-harry other lieutenant]822-his other lieutenant , [O’Dowd]49-mickey , and so , having completed [his]65-harry work , [he]65-harry made [his]65-harry way [home]103-home , reaching [the station]249-the station at sunrise . “ Did [Bates]38-old bates tell [you]104-his wife [he]38-old bates ’d met [me]65-harry ? ”[65-harry] [he]65-harry asked [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife . “ Yes , [Harry]65-harry ; kiss [me]65-harry , [Harry]65-harry . [I]65-harry was so glad [you]65-harry sent a word . Promise [me]65-harry , [Harry]65-harry , not to think that [I]65-harry do n’t agree with [you]65-harry in every thing . ”[65-harry] [Old Brownbie]74-old brownbie , as [he]74-old brownbie was usually called , was [a squatter]1419-a squatter also , but [a squatter of a class very different from that to which [Heathcote]65-harry belonged]827-a squatter of a class very different from that to which heathcote belonged . [He]74-old brownbie had begun [his]74-old brownbie life in [the colonies]828-the colonies a little under a cloud , having been sent out from [home]103-home after the perpetration of some peccadillo of which the law had disapproved . In colonial phrase , [he]74-old brownbie was [a “ lag”—having[830-a “ lag”—having been transported] been transported]830-a “ lag”—having been transported ; but this was many years ago , when [he]74-old brownbie was quite young ; and [he]74-old brownbie had now been [a free man]831-a free man for more than thirty years . It must be owned on [his]74-old brownbie behalf that [he]74-old brownbie had worked hard , had endeavored to rise , and had risen . But there still stuck to [him]74-old brownbie the savor of [his]74-old brownbie old life . [Every one]832-every one knew that [he]74-old brownbie had been [a convict]833-a convict ; and even had [he]74-old brownbie become [a man of high principle]834-a man of high principle — a condition which [he]74-old brownbie certainly never achieved — [he]74-old brownbie could hardly have escaped altogether from the thralldom of [his]74-old brownbie degradation . [He]74-old brownbie had been [a butcher]835-a butcher , [a drover]836-a drover , [part owner of stock]837-part owner of stock , and had at last become possessed of a share of [a cattle - run]838-a cattle - run , and then of [the entire property]839-the entire property , such as it was . [He]74-old brownbie had [four or five sons]840-four or five sons , [uneducated , ill - conditioned , drunken fellows , who had all [[their]840-four or five sons father]842-their father ’s faults without [his]74-old brownbie energy , [some of whom had been in [prison]844-prison , and all of whom were known as pests to [the colony]146-the colony]843-some of whom had been in prison , and all of whom were known as pests to the colony]841-uneducated , ill - conditioned , drunken fellows , who had all their father ’s faults without his energy , some of whom had been in prison , and all of whom were known as pests to the colony . [[Their]840-four or five sons place]846-their place was called [Boolabong]18-boolabong , and was [a cattle - run]838-a cattle - run , as distinguished from a sheep - run ; but it was [a poor place]848-a poor place , was sometimes altogether unstocked , and was supposed to be not unfrequently used as a receptable for stolen cattle . The tricks which [the Brownbies]65-harry played with cattle were notorious throughout [Queensland]5-queensland and [New South Wales]19-new south wales , and by [a certain class of [men]130-men]849-a certain class of men were much admired . [They]840-four or five sons would drive a few head of cattle , perhaps forty or fifty , for miles around [the country]217-the country , across [one station]852-one station and another , traveling many hundreds of miles , and here and there , as [they]840-four or five sons passed along , [they]840-four or five sons would sweep into [their]840-four or five sons own herd the bullocks of [the victims whose lands [they]840-four or five sons passed]853-the victims whose lands they passed . If detected on the spot , [they]840-four or five sons gave up [their]840-four or five sons prey . [They]840-four or five sons were in the right in moving [their]840-four or five sons own cattle , and were not responsible for the erratic tendencies of other animals . If successful , [they]840-four or five sons either sold [their]840-four or five sons stolen beasts to [butchers]854-butchers on [the road]855-the road , or got [them]856-them [home]103-home to [Boolabong]18-boolabong . There were dangers , of course , and occasional penalties . But there was much success . It was supposed , also , that though [they]840-four or five sons did not own sheep , [they]840-four or five sons preferred mutton for [their]840-four or five sons daily uses , and that [they]840-four or five sons supplied [themselves]840-four or five sons at a very cheap rate . It may be imagined how [such a family]858-such a family would be hated by [the respectable squatters on whom [they]840-four or five sons preyed]859-the respectable squatters on whom they preyed . Still there were [men]130-men , [old stagers , who had know [Moreton Bay]20-moreton bay before [it]20-moreton bay was [a colony]862-a colony — in the old days when [convicts]863-convicts were common — who almost regarded [the Brownbies]65-harry as a part of the common order of things , and who were indisposed to persecute [them]840-four or five sons]861-old stagers , who had know moreton bay before it was a colony — in the old days when convicts were common — who almost regarded the brownbies as a part of the common order of things , and who were indisposed to persecute them . [Men]130-men must live ; and what were [a few sheep]865-a few sheep ? Of some such it might be said , that though [they]840-four or five sons were above the arts by which [the Brownbies]65-harry lived , [they]840-four or five sons were not very scrupulous [themselves]840-four or five sons ; and it perhaps served [them]840-four or five sons to have within [[their]840-four or five sons ken neighbours]866-their ken neighbours whose morality was lower even than [their]840-four or five sons own . But to such a one as [Harry Heathcote the Brownbies]65-harry were utterly abominable . [He]65-harry was for the law and justice at any cost . To [his]65-harry thinking , [the Colonial Government]867-the colonial government was grossly at fault , because it did not weed out and extirpate not only [the identical Brownbies]65-harry , but all [Brownbieism]75-brownbieism wherever it might be found . [A dishonest workman]868-a dishonest workman was a great evil , but , to [his]65-harry thinking , [a dishonest man in the position of master]869-a dishonest man in the position of master was [the incarnation of evil]870-the incarnation of evil . As to the difficulties of evidence , and obstacles of that nature , [Harry Heathcote]65-harry knew nothing . [The Brownbies]65-harry were [rascals]871-rascals , and should therefore be exterminated . And [the Brownbies]65-harry knew well the estimation in which [[their]840-four or five sons neighbour]872-their neighbour held [them]840-four or five sons . [Harry]65-harry had made [himself]65-harry altogether disagreeable to [them]840-four or five sons . [They]840-four or five sons were [squatters]1443-squatters as well as [he]65-harry — or at least so [they]840-four or five sons termed [themselves]840-four or five sons ; and though [they]840-four or five sons would not have expected to be admitted to [home intimacies]874-home intimacies , [they]840-four or five sons thought that when [they]840-four or five sons were met out - of - doors or in public places , [they]840-four or five sons should be treated with some respect . On such occasions [Harry]65-harry treated [them]840-four or five sons as though they were dirt beneath [his]65-harry feet . [The Brownbies]65-harry would be found , whenever a little money came among [them]840-four or five sons , at [the public billiard - rooms]875-the public billiard - rooms and [race - courses within one hundred and fifty miles of [Boolabong]18-boolabong]876-race - courses within one hundred and fifty miles of boolabong . At such places [Harry Heathcote]65-harry was never seen . It would have been as easy to seduce [the Bishop of [Brisbane]7-brisbane]877-the bishop of brisbane into a bet as [Harry Heathcote]65-harry . [He]65-harry had never even drank a nobbler with [one of [the Brownbies]65-harry]878-one of the brownbies . To [their]840-four or five sons thinking , [he]65-harry was [a proud , stuck - up , unsocial young cub , whom to rob was a pleasure]879-a proud , stuck - up , unsocial young cub , whom to rob was a pleasure , and to ruin would be a delight . [The old man]763-the old man at [Boolabong]18-boolabong was now almost obsolete . [Property]881-property , that [he]763-the old man could keep in [his]763-the old man grasp , there was in truth none . [He]763-the old man was [the tenant of the run under the Crown]882-the tenant of the run under the crown , and [[his]763-the old man sons]883-his sons would not turn [him]763-the old man out of [the house]226-the house . The cattle , when there were cattle , belonged to [them]883-his sons .
