[They]883-his sons were in no respect subject to [his]763-the old man orders , and [he]763-the old man would have had a bad life among [them]883-his sons were it not that [they]883-his sons quarreled among [themselves]883-his sons , and that in such quarrels [he]763-the old man could belong to [one party]885-one party or to the other . [The house itself]886-the house itself was [a wretched place]887-a wretched place — out of order , with doors and windows and floors shattered , broken , and decayed . There were [none of [womankind]889-womankind belonging to [the family]257-the family]888-none of womankind belonging to the family , and in [such a house]891-such a house [a decent woman - servant]892-a decent woman - servant would have been out of [[her]892-a decent woman - servant place]893-her place . Sometimes there was [one hag there]894-one hag there and sometimes another , and sometimes [feminine]76-feminine aid less respectable than that of [the hags]895-the hags . There had been [six sons]896-six sons . [One]1423-one had disappeared utterly , so that nothing was known of [him]1423-one . [One]1423-one had been absolutely expelled by [the brethren]899-the brethren , and was now [a vagabond in [the country]217-the country]900-a vagabond in the country , turning up now and then at [Boolabong]18-boolabong and demanding food . Of [the whole lot]902-the whole lot [Georgie Brownbie]43-georgie , [the vagabond]903-the vagabond , was the worst . [The eldest son]904-the eldest son was at this time in prison at [Brisbane]7-brisbane , having on some late occasion been less successful than usual in regard to some acquired bullocks . [The three youngest]905-the three youngest were at [home]103-home — [Jerry]77-jerry , [Jack]78-jack , and [Joe]79-joe . [Tom]80-tom , who was in [prison]844-prison , was the only stanch friend to [the father]908-the father , who consequently at this time was in a more than usually depressed condition . Christmas - day would fall on a Tuesday , and on the Monday before it [Jerry Brownbie]77-jerry , [the eldest of those now at [home]103-home]909-the eldest of those now at home , was sitting , with a pipe in [his]77-jerry mouth , on a broken - down stool on [the broken - down veranda of [the house]226-the house]911-the broken - down veranda of the house , and [the old man]763-the old man was seated on a stuffy , worn - out sofa with three legs , which was propped against the wall of [the house]226-the house , and had not been moved for years . [Old Brownbie]74-old brownbie was [a man of gigantic frame]915-a man of gigantic frame , and had possessed immense personal power — [a man , too , of will and energy]916-a man , too , of will and energy ; but [he]74-old brownbie was now worn out and dropsical , and could not move beyond the confines of [the home station]917-the home station . [The veranda]174-the veranda was attached to [a big room which ran nearly the whole length of [the house]226-the house]919-a big room which ran nearly the whole length of the house , and which was now used for all purposes . There was [an exterior kitchen , in which certain processes were carried on — such as salting stolen mutton and boiling huge masses of meat]921-an exterior kitchen , in which certain processes were carried on — such as salting stolen mutton and boiling huge masses of meat , when such work was needed . But the cookery was generally done in [the big room]922-the big room . And here also [two or three of [the sons]924-the sons]923-two or three of the sons slept on beds made upon stretchers along the wall . [They]924-the sons were not probably very particular as to which owned each bed , enjoying a fraternal communism in that respect . At the end of [this chamber]925-this chamber [the old man]763-the old man had [a room of [his]763-the old man own]927-a room of his own . [Boolabong]18-boolabong was certainly [a miserable place]928-a miserable place ; and yet , such as [it]18-boolabong was , [it]18-boolabong was frequented by [many guests]929-many guests . The vagabondism of [the colonies]828-the colonies is proverbial . [Vagabonds]931-vagabonds are taken in almost every where throughout [the bush]218-the bush . But the welcome given to [them]931-vagabonds varies . Sometimes [they]931-vagabonds are made to work before [they]931-vagabonds are fed — to [their]931-vagabonds infinite disgust . But no such cruelty was exercised at [Boolabong]18-boolabong . [Boolabong]18-boolabong was [a very Paradise for]933-a very paradise for [vagabonds]931-vagabonds . There was always flour and meat to be had , generally tobacco , and sometimes even the luxury of [a nobbler]935-a nobbler . [The Brownbies]65-harry were wise enough to have learned that it was necessary for [their]936-their very existence that [they]936-their should have [friends]510-friends in [the land]499-the land . On the Sunday [the father]908-the father and [Jerry Brownbie]77-jerry were sitting out in [the veranda]174-the veranda at about noon , and [the other two sons]941-the other two sons , [Jack]78-jack and [Joe]79-joe , were lying asleep on the beds within . The heat of the day was intense . There was a wind blowing , but it was that which is called there the hot wind , which comes dry , scorching , sometimes almost intolerable , over [the burning central plain of [the country]217-the country]942-the burning central plain of the country . [No one]339-no one can understand without feeling it how much a wind can add to the sufferings inflicted by heat . [The old man]763-the old man had on a dirty , wretched remnant of a dressing - gown , but [Jerry]77-jerry was clothed simply in trowsers and an old shirt . Only that the mosquitoes would have flayed [him]77-jerry , [he]77-jerry would have dispensed probably with these . [He]77-jerry had been quarreling with [[his]77-jerry father]1454-his father respecting a certain horse which [he]763-the old man had sold , of the price of which [the father]908-the father demanded a share . [Jerry]77-jerry had unblushingly declared that [he]77-jerry [himself]77-jerry had “ shaken ”[77-jerry] the horse — [Anglice]81-anglice , had stolen [him]81-anglice — twelve months since on [Darnley Downs]21-darnley downs , and was therefore clearly entitled to the entire plunder . [The father]908-the father had rejoined with animation that unless “ half a quid”—or[908-the father] ten shillings — were given [him]908-the father as [his]908-the father contribution to the keep of the animal , [he]908-the father would inform against [[his]908-the father son]949-his son to [the squatter on [the Darnley Downs]21-darnley downs]950-the squatter on the darnley downs , and had shown [him]908-the father that [he]908-the father knew the very run from which the horse had been taken . Then [the sons within]951-the sons within had interfered from [their]951-the sons within beds , swearing that [[their]951-the sons within father]842-their father was [the noisiest old “ cuss ”[951-the sons within] unhung]953-the noisiest old “ cuss ” unhung , [they]951-the sons within having had [their]951-the sons within necessary slumbers disturbed . At this moment the debate was interrupted by the appearance of [a man outside the veranda]954-a man outside the veranda . “ Well , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry , how goes it ? ”[207-the stranger] asked [the stranger]207-the stranger . “ What , [Bos]72-bos , is that [you]82-jerry ? What brings [you]82-jerry up to [Boolabong]18-boolabong ? [I]207-the stranger thought [you]82-jerry was ringing trees for [that young scut at [Gangoil]65-harry]1646-that young scut at gangoil ? [I]207-the stranger ’ll be even with [him]1646-that young scut at gangoil some of these days ! [He]1646-that young scut at gangoil had the impudence to send [a man of [his]1646-that young scut at gangoil]1647-a man of his up here last week looking for sheep - skins . ”[207-the stranger] “ [He]1646-that young scut at gangoil was n’t that soft , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry , was [he]1646-that young scut at gangoil ? Well , [I]763-the old man ’ve dropped working for him.—How are [you]82-jerry , [Mr. Brownbie]83-mr. brownbie ? [I]763-the old man hope [I]763-the old man see [you]82-jerry finely , [Sir]1648-sir . It ’s stiffish sort of weather , [Mr. Brownbie]83-mr. brownbie , ai n’t it , [Sir]1648-sir ? ”[763-the old man] [The old man]763-the old man grunted out some reply , and then asked [Boscobel]53-boscobel what [he]763-the old man wanted . “ [I]74-old brownbie ’ll just hang about for the day , [Mr. Brownbie]83-mr. brownbie , and get a little grub . [You]82-jerry never begrudged [a working - man that yet]1650-a working - man that yet . ”[74-old brownbie] [Old Brownbie]74-old brownbie again grunted , but said no word of welcome . That , however , was to be taken for granted , without much expression of opinion . “ No , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry , ”[53-boscobel] continued [Boscobel]53-boscobel , “ [I]53-boscobel ’ve done with [that fellow]1651-that fellow . ”[53-boscobel] “ And so has [Nokes]58-nokes done with [him]1651-that fellow . ”[763-the old man] “ [Nokes]58-nokes is at work on [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill . That sugar business would n’t suit [me]53-boscobel . ”[53-boscobel] “ An axe in [your]83-mr. brownbie hand is what [you]83-mr. brownbie ’re fit for , [Bos]72-bos . ”[53-boscobel] “ There ’s a many things [I]763-the old man can turn [my]763-the old man hand to , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry . [You]82-jerry could n’t give [a fellow]1504-a fellow such a thing as [a nobbler]935-a nobbler , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry , could [you]82-jerry ? [I]763-the old man ’d offer money for it , only [I]763-the old man know it would be taken amiss . It ’s that hot that [a fellow]1504-a fellow ’s very in’ards get parched up . ”[763-the old man] Upon this [Jerry]82-jerry slowly rose , and going to a cupboard , brought forth a modicum of spirits , which [he]82-jerry called Battle - Axe , but which was supposed to be brandy . [This Boscobel]53-boscobel swallowed at a gulp , and then washed it down with a little water . “ Come , [Jerry]82-jerry , ”[763-the old man] said [the old man]763-the old man , somewhat relenting in [his]763-the old man wrath , “ [you]82-jerry might as well give [us]958-the two brothers a drop , as it ’s going about . ”[763-the old man] [The two brothers]958-the two brothers , who had now been thoroughly aroused from [their]958-the two brothers sleep , and who had heard the enticing sound of the spirit bottle , joined the party , and so [they]958-the two brothers drank all round . “ [Heathcote]65-harry ’s in an awful state about them fires , ai n’t [he]53-boscobel ? ”[82-jerry] asked [Jerry]82-jerry . [Boscobel]53-boscobel , who had squatted down on [the veranda]174-the veranda , and was now lighting [his]53-boscobel pipe , bobbed [his]53-boscobel head . “ [I]82-jerry wish [he]53-boscobel was clean burned out — over head and ears , ”[82-jerry] said [Jerry]82-jerry . [Boscobel]53-boscobel bobbed [his]53-boscobel head again , sucking with great energy at the closely staffed pipe . “ If [he]53-boscobel treated [me]82-jerry like [he]53-boscobel does [[you]1655-you fellows]1656-you fellows , ”[82-jerry] continued [Jerry]82-jerry , “ [he]53-boscobel should n’t have a yard of fencing or a blade of grass left — nor a ewe , nor a lamb , nor [a hogget]1657-a hogget . [I]82-jerry do hate [fellows who come here and want to be better than [any one about [’em]1660-’em]1659-any one about ’em]1658-fellows who come here and want to be better than any one about ’em — [young chaps]1661-young chaps especially . Sending up here to look for sheep - skins , cuss [his]53-boscobel impudence ! [I]82-jerry sent [that German fellow of [his]1662-that german fellow of his]1662-that german fellow of his away with a flea in [his]1662-that german fellow of his ear . ”[82-jerry] “ [Karl Bender]59-karl bender ? ”[53-boscobel] “ It ’s some such name as that . ”[82-jerry] “ [He]53-boscobel ’s all in all with [the young squire]1663-the young squire , ”[53-boscobel] said [Boscobel]53-boscobel . “ And there ’s [a chap there called [Jacko]51-jacko]1664-a chap there called jacko — [he]1664-a chap there called jacko ’s another . [He]53-boscobel gets ’em down there to [Gangoil]65-harry , and [the ladies]471-the ladies talks to [’em]1660-’em , and then [they]471-the ladies ’d go through fire and water for [him]53-boscobel . There ’s [Mickey]49-mickey — [he]49-mickey ’s another , jist the same way . [I]53-boscobel do n’t like them ways , [myself]53-boscobel . ”[53-boscobel] “ Too much of [master]169-master and [man]1667-man about it , ai n’t [there]290-there , [Bos]72-bos ? ”[82-jerry] “ Just that , [Mr. Jerry]82-jerry . That ai n’t [my]53-boscobel idea of [a free country]1669-a free country . [I]53-boscobel can work as well as another , but [I]53-boscobel ai n’t going to be told that [I]53-boscobel ’m [a swindler]1670-a swindler because [I]53-boscobel ’m making the most of [my]53-boscobel time . ”[53-boscobel] “ [He]49-mickey turned [Nokes]58-nokes out by the scruff of [his]49-mickey neck ? ”[82-jerry] said [Jerry]82-jerry . [Boscobel]53-boscobel again bobbed [his]53-boscobel head . “ [I]53-boscobel did n’t think [Nokes]58-nokes was [the sort of fellow to stand that]1671-the sort of fellow to stand that . ”[53-boscobel] “ No more [he]58-nokes ai n’t , ”[53-boscobel] said [Boscobel]53-boscobel . “ [Heathcote]65-harry ’s [a good plucked un]1672-a good plucked un all the same , ”[79-joe] said [Joe]79-joe . “ It ’s like [you]53-boscobel to speak up for [such a fellow]1673-such a fellow is that , ”[82-jerry] said [Jerry]82-jerry . “ [I]82-jerry say [he]1673-such a fellow ’s [a good plucked un]1672-a good plucked un . [I]82-jerry ’m not standing up for [him]1673-such a fellow . [Nokes]58-nokes is half a stone heavier than [him]1673-such a fellow , and ought to have knocked [him]1673-such a fellow over . That ’s what [you]53-boscobel ’d ’ve done , would n’t [you]53-boscobel , [Bos]72-bos ? [I]82-jerry know [I]82-jerry would . ”[82-jerry] “ [He]1673-such a fellow ’d ‘ ve had [my]53-boscobel axe at [his]1673-such a fellow head , ”[53-boscobel] said [Boscobel]53-boscobel . “ [We]1675-we all know [Joe]79-joe ’s game to the backbone , ”[82-jerry] said [Jerry]82-jerry . “ [I]960-the brother ’m game enough for [you]82-jerry , anyway , ”[960-the brother] said [the brother]960-the brother . “ And [you]82-jerry can try it out any time [you]82-jerry like . ”[960-the brother] “ That ’s right ; fight like dogs , do , ”[763-the old man] said [the old man]763-the old man . The quarrel at this point was interrupted by the arrival of [another man , who crept up round the corner on to [the veranda]174-the veranda exactly as [Boscobel]53-boscobel had done]962-another man , who crept up round the corner on to the veranda exactly as boscobel had done . This was [Nokes]58-nokes , of whom [they]964-they had that moment been speaking . There was silence for a few moments among [them]964-they , as though [they]964-they feared that [he]58-nokes might have heard [them]964-they , and [Nokes]58-nokes stood hanging [his]58-nokes head as though half ashamed of [himself]58-nokes . Then [they]964-they gave [him]58-nokes the same kind of greeting as [the other men]965-the other men had received . [Nobody]1636-nobody told [him]58-nokes that [he]58-nokes was welcome , but the spirit jar was again brought into use , [Jerry]82-jerry measuring out the liquor , and it was understood that [Nokes]58-nokes was to stay there and get [his]58-nokes food . [He]58-nokes too gave some account of [himself]58-nokes , which was supposed to suffice , but which [they]964-they all knew to be false . It was Sunday , and [they]964-they were off work at [the sugar - mill]419-the sugar - mill . [He]58-nokes had come across [Gangoil]65-harry run , intending to take back with [him]58-nokes things of [his]58-nokes own which [he]58-nokes had left as [[Bender]59-karl bender ’s hut]968-bender ’s hut , and having come so far , had thought that [he]58-nokes would come on and get [his]58-nokes dinner at [Boolabong]18-boolabong . As this was being told , a good deal was said of [Harry Heathcote]65-harry . [Nokes]58-nokes declared that [he]58-nokes had come right across [Gangoil]65-harry , and explained that [he]58-nokes would not have been at all sorry to meet [Master Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote in the bush . [Master Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote had had [his]57-mr. heathcote own way up at [the station]249-the station when [he]57-mr. heathcote was backed by a lot of [his]57-mr. heathcote own hands ; but a good time was coming , perhaps . Then [Nokes]58-nokes gave it to be understood very plainly that it was the settled practice of [his]58-nokes life to give [Harry Heathcote]65-harry a thrashing . During all this there was an immense amount of bad language , and a large portion of the art which in [the colony]146-the colony is called “ blowing . ”[82-jerry] [Jerry]82-jerry , [Boscobel]53-boscobel , and [Nokes]58-nokes all boasted , each that on the first occasion [he]58-nokes would give [Harry Heathcote]65-harry such a beating that a whole bone should hardly be left in [the man]451-the man ’s skin . “ There is n’t one of [you]1676-you man enough to touch [him]65-harry , ”[79-joe] said [Joe]79-joe , who was known as [the freest fighter of [the Brownbie family]973-the brownbie family]972-the freest fighter of the brownbie family . “ And [you]79-joe ’d eat [him]65-harry , [I]82-jerry suppose , ”[82-jerry] said [Jerry]82-jerry . “ [He]65-harry ’s not likely to come in [my]79-joe way , ”[79-joe] said [Joe]79-joe ; “ but if [he]65-harry does , [he]65-harry ’ll get as good as [he]65-harry brings . That ’s all . ”[79-joe] This was unpleasant to [the visitors]974-the visitors , who , of course , felt [themselves]974-the visitors to be snubbed . [Boscobel]53-boscobel affected to hear the slight put upon [his]53-boscobel courage with good humor , but [Nokes]58-nokes laid [himself]58-nokes down in a corner and sulked . [They]974-the visitors were soon all asleep , and remained dozing , snoring , changing [their]974-the visitors uncomfortable positions , and cursing the mosquitoes , till about four in the afternoon , when [Boscobel]53-boscobel got up , shook [himself]53-boscobel , and made some observation about “ grub . ”[53-boscobel] The meal of the day was then prepared . A certain quantity of flour and raw meat , ample for [their]974-the visitors immediate wants , was given to [the two strangers]975-the two strangers , with which [they]974-the visitors retired into [the outer kitchen]976-the outer kitchen , prepared it for [themselves]974-the visitors , and there ate [their]974-the visitors dinner , and each of [the brothers]977-the brothers did the same for [himself]978-himself in [the big room]922-the big room — [Joe]79-joe , [the fighting brother]980-the fighting brother , providing for [[his]79-joe father]1454-his father ’s wants as well as [his]79-joe own . [One of [them]977-the brothers]982-one of them had half a leg of cold mutton , so that [he]982-one of them was saved the trouble of cooking , but [he]982-one of them did not offer to share this comfort with [the others]983-the others . An enormous kettle of tea was made , and that was common among [them]977-the brothers . While this was being consumed , [Boscobel]53-boscobel put [his]53-boscobel head into [the room]199-the room , and suggested that [he]53-boscobel and [[his]53-boscobel mate]985-his mate wanted a drink . [Whereupon Jerry]84-jerry , without a word , pointed to the kettle , and [Boscobel]53-boscobel was allowed to fill two pannikins . Such was the welcome which was always accorded to [[strangers]986-strangers in [Boolabong]18-boolabong]987-strangers in boolabong . After [their]977-the brothers meal [the men]292-the men came back on to [the veranda]174-the veranda , and there were more smoking and sleeping , more boasting and snarling . Different allusions were made to the spirit jar , especially by [the old man]763-the old man ; but they were made in vain . The “ Battle - Axe ”[84-jerry] was [[Jerry]84-jerry ’s own property]991-jerry ’s own property , and [he]84-jerry felt that [he]84-jerry had already been almost foolishly liberal . But [he]84-jerry had an object in view . [He]84-jerry was quite sure that [Boscobel]53-boscobel and [Nokes]58-nokes had not come to [Boolabong]18-boolabong on the same Sunday by any chance coincidence . [The men]292-the men had something to propose , and in [their]292-the men own way [they]292-the men would make the proposition before [they]292-the men left , and would make it probably to [him]84-jerry . [Boscobel]53-boscobel intended to sleep at [Boolabong]18-boolabong , but [Nokes]58-nokes had explained that it was [his]58-nokes purpose to return that night to [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s Mill]468-medlicot ’s mill . The proposition no doubt would be made soon — a little after seven , when the day was preparing to give way suddenly to night . [Nokes]58-nokes first walked off , sloping out from [the veranda]174-the veranda in a half - shy , half - cunning manner , looking nowhither , and saying a word to [no one]339-no one . Quickly after [him]58-nokes [Boscobel]53-boscobel jumped up suddenly , hitched up [his]53-boscobel trowsers , and followed [the first man]633-the first man . At about a similar interval [Jerry]84-jerry passed out through [the big room]922-the big room to [the yard]641-the yard at the back , and from [the yard]641-the yard to [a shed that was used as a shambles]1000-a shed that was used as a shambles . Here [he]84-jerry found [the other two men]1001-the other two men , and no doubt the proposition was made . “ There ’s something up , ”[763-the old man] said [the old man]763-the old man , as soon as [Jerry]84-jerry was gone . “ Of course there ’s something up , ”[79-joe] said [Joe]79-joe . “ [Those fellows]1677-those fellows did n’t come all the way to [Boolabong]18-boolabong for nothing . ”[79-joe] “ It ’s something about [young Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote , ”[908-the father] suggested [the father]908-the father . “ If it is , ”[78-jack] said [Jack]78-jack , “ what ’s that to [you]908-the father ? ”[78-jack] “ [They]1677-those fellows ’ll get [themselves]1677-those fellows hanged , that ’s all about it . ”[79-joe] “ That be blowed , ”[78-jack] said [Jack]78-jack ; “ [you]908-the father go easy and hold [your]908-the father tongue . If [you]908-the father know nothing , [nobody]1636-nobody can hurt [you]908-the father . ”[78-jack] “ [I]79-joe know nothing , ”[79-joe] said [Joe]79-joe , “ and do n’t mean . If [I]79-joe had scores to quit with [a fellow like [Harry Heathcote]65-harry]1679-a fellow like harry heathcote , [I]79-joe should do it after [my]79-joe own fashion . [I]79-joe should n’t get [Boscobel]53-boscobel to help [me]79-joe , nor yet [such a fellow as [Nokes]58-nokes]1680-such a fellow as nokes . But it ’s no business of [mine]79-joe . [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote ’s made [the place]1437-the place too hot to hold [him]57-mr. heathcote . That ’s all about it . ”[79-joe] There was no more said , and in an hour ’s time [Jerry]84-jerry returned , to [the family]257-the family . Neither [the father]908-the father nor [brother]1006-brother asked [him]84-jerry any questions , nor did [he]84-jerry volunteer any information . [Boolabong]18-boolabong was about fourteen miles from [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill . [Nokes]58-nokes had walked this distance in the morning , and now retraced it at night — not going right across [Gangoil]65-harry , as [he]58-nokes had falsely boasted of doing early in the day , but skirting [it]65-harry , and keeping on the outside of the fence nearly the whole distance . At about two in the morning [he]58-nokes reached [[his]58-nokes cottage outside [the mill]484-the mill on [the river - bank]1009-the river - bank]1007-his cottage outside the mill on the river - bank ; but [he]58-nokes was unable to skulk in unheard . Some dogs made a noise , and presently [he]58-nokes heard a voice calling [him]58-nokes from [the house]226-the house . “ Is that [you]58-nokes , [Nokes]58-nokes , at this time of night ? ”[47-medlicot] asked [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . [Nokes]58-nokes grunted out some reply , intending to avoid any further question . But [[his]58-nokes master]337-his master came up to the hut door and asked [him]58-nokes where [he]58-nokes had been . “ Just amusing [myself]58-nokes , ”[58-nokes] said [Nokes]58-nokes . “ It ’s very late . ”[58-nokes] “ It ’s not later for [me]47-medlicot than for [you]337-his master , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . ”[47-medlicot] “ That ’s true . [I]58-nokes ’ve just ridden [home]103-home from “[58-nokes] From [Gangoil]65-harry ? [I]0-i did n’t know [you]337-his master were so friendly there , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . ” “[47-medlicot] And where have [you]337-his master been ? ” “[47-medlicot] Not to [Gangoil]65-harry , anyway . Good - night , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . ” Then [the man]451-the man took [himself]451-the man into [[his]451-the man hut]1684-his hut , and was safe from further questioning that night . All the Saturday night [Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote had been on the run , and [he]57-mr. heathcote did not return [home]103-home to bed till nearly dawn on the Sunday morning . At about noon prayers were read out on [the veranda]174-the veranda , [the congregation consisting of [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote and [[her]42-mrs. heathcote sister]180-her sister]1687-the congregation consisting of mrs. heathcote and her sister , [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , and [Jacko]51-jacko . [Harry]65-harry [himself]65-harry was rather averse to this performance , intimating that [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler , if [she]45-mrs. growler were so minded , could read the prayers for [herself]45-mrs. growler in [the kitchen]1456-the kitchen , and that , as [regarded Jacko]51-jacko , [they]1687-the congregation consisting of mrs. heathcote and her sister would be altogether thrown away . But [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife had made a point of maintaining the practice , and [he]65-harry had of course yielded . The service was not long , and when it was over [Harry]65-harry got into a chair and was soon asleep . [He]65-harry had been in the saddle during sixteen hours of the previous day and night , and was entitled to be fatigued . [[His]65-harry wife]104-his wife sat beside [him]65-harry , every now and again protecting [him]65-harry from the flies , while [Kate Daly]41-kate sat by with [her]41-kate Bible in [her]41-kate hand . But [she]41-kate , too , from time to time , was watching [[her]41-kate brother - in - law]1692-her brother - in - law . The trouble of [his]65-harry spirits and the work that [he]65-harry felt [himself]65-harry bound to do touched [them]1693-them with a strong feeling , and taught [them]1693-them to regard [him]65-harry for the time as [a young hero]1694-a young hero . “[47-medlicot] How quietly [he]1012-he sleeps ! ” [Kate]41-kate said . “[1012-he] The fatigue of the last week must have been terrible . ” “[1012-he] [He]1012-he is quite , quite knocked up , ” said [the wife]108-the wife . “[1012-he] [I]0-i ai n’t knocked up a bit , ” said [Harry]65-harry , jumping up from [his]65-harry chair . “[0-i] What should knock [me]0-i up ? [I]0-i was n’t asleep , was [I]0-i ? ” “[0-i] Just dozing , [dear]1452-dear . ” “[1452-dear] Ah , well ; there is n’t any thing to do , and it ’s too hot to get out . [I]0-i wonder [Old Bates]38-old bates did n’t come in for prayers . ” “[38-old bates] [I]0-i do n’t think [he]38-old bates cares much for prayers , ” said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote . “[38-old bates] But [he]38-old bates likes an excuse for [a nobbler]935-a nobbler as well as [any one]1493-any one . Did [I]0-i tell [you]0-i that [they]1016-they had fires over at [Jackson]85-jackson ’s yesterday — at [Goolaroo]24-goolaroo ? ” “[0-i] Was there any harm done ? ” “[0-i] A deal of grass burned , and [they]1016-they had to drive the sheep , which wo n’t serve [them]1016-they this kind of weather . [I]0-i do n’t know which [I]0-i fear most — the grass , the fences , or the sheep . As for [the buildings]522-the buildings , [I]0-i do n’t think [they]1016-they ’ll try that again . ” “[1016-they] Why not , [Harry]65-harry ? ” “[65-harry] The risk of being seen is too great . [I]0-i can hardly understand that [a man like [Nokes]58-nokes]1018-a man like nokes should have been such [a fool]1635-a fool as [he]1018-a man like nokes was . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i think it was [Nokes]58-nokes ? ” “[58-nokes] Oh yes , certainly . In the first place , [Jacko]51-jacko is as true as steel . [I]0-i do n’t mean to swear by [the boy]375-the boy , though [I]0-i think [he]375-the boy is [a good boy]1021-a good boy . But [I]0-i ’m sure [he]51-jacko ’s true in this . And then [the man]451-the man ’s manner to [myself]0-i was conclusive . [I]0-i can not understand [a man in [Medlicot]47-medlicot]1023-a man in medlicot ’s position supporting [a fellow like that]1545-a fellow like that . By [Heavens]86-heavens ! it nearly drives [me]0-i mad to think of it . Thousands and thousands of pounds are at stake . All that [a man]128-a man has in [the world]1427-the world is exposed to the malice of [a scoundrel like Nokes]1027-a scoundrel like nokes ! And then [a man who calls [himself]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman [a gentleman]122-a gentleman]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman will talk about it being un - English to look after [him]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman . [He]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman ’s [a ‘ new chum]1030-a ‘ new chum ; ’ [I]0-i suppose that ’s [his]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman excuse . ” “[1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman] If it ’s a sufficient excuse , [you]1031-you should excuse [him]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman , ” said [Kate]41-kate , with good feminine logic . “[1031-you] That ’s just like [you]1031-you all over . [He]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman ’s good - looking , and therefore it ’s all right . [He]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman ought to have learned better . [He]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman ought , at any rate , to believe that [men who have been here]1032-men who have been here much longer than [he]1028-a man who calls himself a gentleman has must know the ways of [the country]217-the country a great deal better . ” “[65-harry] It ’s Christmas - time , [Harry]65-harry , ” said [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife , “[65-harry] and [you]65-harry should endeavor to forgive [[your]65-harry neighbors]1034-your neighbors . ” “[65-harry] What sort of a Christmas will it be if [you]1031-you and [I]0-i , and [these young fellows here]1035-these young fellows here , and [Kate]41-kate , are all burned out of [Gangoil]65-harry ? Here ’s [Bates.—Well]87-bates.—well , [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates , how goes it ? ” “[71-mr. bates] Tremendous hot , [Sir]1648-sir . ” “[1648-sir] [We]1037-we ’ve found that out already . [You]1031-you have n’t heard where [that fellow Boscobel]1038-that fellow boscobel has gone ? ” “[1031-you] No ; [I]0-i have n’t heard . But [he]1038-that fellow boscobel ’ll be over with [some of [those Brownbie lads]1040-those brownbie lads]1039-some of those brownbie lads . [They]1039-some of those brownbie lads say [Georgie Brownbie]43-georgie ’s about [the country]217-the country somewhere . If so , there ’ll be a row among [’em]1042-’em . ” “[1039-some of those brownbie lads] When [thieves]1043-thieves fall out , [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates , [honest men]1044-honest men come by [their]1044-honest men own . ” “[1044-honest men] So [they]1044-honest men say , [Mr. Heathcote]57-mr. heathcote . All the same , [I]0-i should n’t care how far [Georgie]43-georgie was away from [any place [I]0-i had to do with]1045-any place i had to do with . ” Then [the young master]1697-the young master and [[his]1697-the young master old superintendent]1698-his old superintendent sauntered out to [[his]1697-the young master back premises]1699-his back premises to talk about sheep and fires , and plans for putting out fires . And no doubt [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates had the glass of brandy - and - water which [he]71-mr. bates had come to regard as one of [his]71-mr. bates Sunday luxuries . From [the back premises]1700-the back premises [they]1046-they went down to [the creek]316-the creek to gauge the water . Then [they]1046-they sauntered on , keeping always in the shade , sitting down here to smoke , and standing up there to discuss the pedigree of [some particular ram]1702-some particular ram , till it was past six . “[57-mr. heathcote] [You]57-mr. heathcote may as well come in and dine with [us]1046-they , [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates , ” [Harry]65-harry suggested , as [they]1046-they returned toward [the station]249-the station . [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates said that [he]71-mr. bates thought that [he]71-mr. bates would . As the same invitation was given on almost every Sunday throughout the year , and was invariably answered in the same way , there was not much excitement in this . But [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates would not have dreamed of going in to dinner without being asked . “[71-mr. bates] That ’s [Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s trap , ” said [Mr. Bates]71-mr. bates , as [they]1046-they entered [the yard]641-the yard . “[47-medlicot] [I]0-i heard wheels when [they]1047-they were in [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock . ” [Harry]65-harry looked at the trap , and then went quickly into [the house]226-the house . [He]65-harry walked with a rapid step onto [the veranda]174-the veranda , and there [he]65-harry found [the sugar grower]553-the sugar grower and [[his]553-the sugar grower mother]488-his mother . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote looked at [[her]42-mrs. heathcote husband]116-her husband almost timidly . [She]42-mrs. heathcote knew from the very sound of [his]116-her husband feet that [he]116-her husband was perturbed in spirit . Under [his]116-her husband own roof - tree [he]116-her husband would certainly be courteous ; but there is a constrained courtesy very hard to be borne , of which [she]42-mrs. heathcote knew [him]116-her husband to be capable . [He]116-her husband first went up to [the old lady]524-the old lady , and to [her]524-the old lady [his]116-her husband greeting was pleasant enough . [Harry Heathcote]65-harry , though [he]65-harry had assumed the bush mode of dressing , still retained the manners of [a high - bred gentleman in [his]65-harry intercourse with [women]403-women]1711-a high - bred gentleman in his intercourse with women . Then , turning sharply round , [he]65-harry gave [his]65-harry hand to [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . “[1047-they] [I]0-i am glad to see [you]1049-you at [Gangoil]65-harry , ” [he]65-harry said ; “[0-i] [I]0-i was not fortunate enough to be at [home]103-home when [you]1049-you called the other day . [Mrs. Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot must have found the drive very hot , [I]0-i fear . ” [[His]65-harry wife]104-his wife was still looking into [his]65-harry face , and was reading there , as in a book , the mingled pride and disdain with which [[her]104-his wife husband]116-her husband exercising civility to [[his]116-her husband enemy]1715-his enemy . [Harry]65-harry ’s countenance wore a look not difficult of perusal , and [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot could read the lines almost as distinctly as [[Harry]65-harry ’s wife]1716-harry ’s wife . “[48-mrs. medlicot] [I]0-i have asked [Mrs. Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot to stay and dine with [us]1051-they , ” [she]48-mrs. medlicot said , “[0-i] so that [she]48-mrs. medlicot may have it cool for the drive back . ” “[48-mrs. medlicot] [I]0-i am almost afraid of [the bush]218-the bush at night , ” said [the old woman]194-the old woman . “[0-i] [You]48-mrs. medlicot ’ll have a full moon , ” said [Harry]65-harry ; “[48-mrs. medlicot] it will be as light as day . ” So that was settled . [Heathcote]65-harry thought it odd that [the man whom [he]65-harry regarded as [[his]65-harry enemy , whom [he]65-harry had left at [their]1051-they last meeting in positive hostility]1719-his enemy , whom he had left at their last meeting in positive hostility]1718-the man whom he regarded as his enemy , whom he had left at their last meeting in positive hostility , should consent to accept a dinner under [his]65-harry roof ; but that was [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot ’s affair , not [his]65-harry . [They]1051-they dined at seven , and after dinner strolled out into [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock , and down to [the creek]316-the creek . As [they]1051-they started , [the three men]1722-the three men went first , and [the ladies]471-the ladies followed [them]1722-the three men ; but [Bates]71-mr. bates soon dropped behind . It was [his]71-mr. bates rest day , and [he]71-mr. bates had already moved quite as much as was usual with [him]71-mr. bates on a Sunday . “[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i was a little hard with [you]1053-you the other day , ” said [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot , when [they]1051-they were alone together . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [we]1054-we hardly understand [each other]647-each other ’s ideas , ” said [Harry]65-harry . [He]65-harry spoke with a constrained voice , and with an almost savage manner , engendered by a determination to hold [his]65-harry own . [He]65-harry would forgive any offense for which an apology was made , but no apology had been made as yet ; and , to tell the truth , [he]65-harry was a little afraid that if [they]1051-they got into an argument on the matter [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot would have the best of it . And there was , too , almost a claim to superiority in [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot ’s use of the word “[1054-we] hard . ” When [one man]759-one man says that [he]759-one man has been hard to [another]1725-another , [he]759-one man almost boasts that , on that occasion , [he]759-one man got the better of [him]759-one man . “[1054-we] That ’s just it , ” said [Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot ; “[1054-we] [we]1054-we do not quite understand [each other]647-each other . But [we]1054-we might believe in [each other]647-each other all the same , and then the understanding would come . But it is n’t just that which [I]0-i want to say ; such talking rarely does any good . ” “[0-i] What is it , then ? ” “[0-i] [You]0-i may perhaps be right about [that man Nokes]1058-that man nokes . ” “[0-i] No doubt [I]0-i may . [I]0-i know [I]0-i ’m right . When [I]0-i asked [him]1058-that man nokes whether [he]1058-that man nokes ’d been at [[my]0-i shed]1059-my shed , what made [him]1058-that man nokes say that [he]1058-that man nokes had n’t been there at night - time ? [I]0-i said nothing about night - time . But [the man]451-the man was there at night - time , or [he]1058-that man nokes would n’t have used the word . ” “[1058-that man nokes] [I]0-i ’m not sure that that is evidence . ” “[1058-that man nokes] Perhaps not in [England]8-england , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot , but it ’s good enough evidence for the bush . And what made [him]1058-that man nokes pretend [he]1058-that man nokes did n’t know the distances ? And why ca n’t [he]1058-that man nokes look [a man in the face]1061-a man in the face ? And why should [the boy]375-the boy have said it was [he]1058-that man nokes if it was n’t ? Of course , if [you]1063-you think well of [him]1058-that man nokes [you]1063-you ’re right to keep [him]1058-that man nokes . But [you]1063-you may take it as a rule out here that when [a man]128-a man has been dismissed it has n’t been done for nothing . [Men]130-men treated that way should travel out of [the country]217-the country . It ’s better for [all parties]1067-all parties . It is n’t [here]260-here as it is at [home]103-home , where [people]1472-people live so thick together that nothing is thought of [a man being dismissed]1071-a man being dismissed . [I]0-i was obliged to discharge [him]1058-that man nokes , and now [he]1058-that man nokes ’s [[my]0-i enemy]1072-my enemy . ” “[1058-that man nokes] [A man]128-a man may be [[your]1063-you enemy]1074-your enemy without being [a felon]1075-a felon . ” “[128-a man] Of course [he]128-a man may . [I]0-i ’m [[his]128-a man enemy]1715-his enemy in a way , but [I]0-i would n’t hurt a hair of [his]128-a man head unjustly . When [I]0-i see the attempts made to burn [me]0-i out , of course [I]0-i know that [an enemy]578-an enemy has been at work . ” “[578-an enemy] Is there [no one else]1078-no one else has got a grudge against [you]1063-you ? ” [Harry]65-harry was silent for a moment . What right had [this man]497-this man to cross - examine [him]65-harry about [his]65-harry enmities — [the man whose own position in [the place]1437-the place had been one of hostility to [him]65-harry , whom [he]65-harry had almost suspected of harboring [Nokes]58-nokes at [the mill]484-the mill simply because [Nokes]58-nokes had been dismissed from [Gangoil]65-harry]1727-the man whose own position in the place had been one of hostility to him , whom he had almost suspected of harboring nokes at the mill simply because nokes had been dismissed from gangoil ? That suspicion was , indeed , fading away . There was something in [Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s voice and manner which made it impossible to attribute such motives to [him]47-medlicot . Nevertheless [the man]451-the man was [a free - selector]1432-a free - selector , and had taken a bit of the [Gangoil]65-harry run after a fashion which to [Heathcote]65-harry was objectionable politically , morally , and socially . Let [Medlicot]47-medlicot in regard to character be what [he]47-medlicot might , [he]47-medlicot was [a free - selector]1432-a free - selector , and [[a squatter]1419-a squatter ’s enemy]1734-a squatter ’s enemy , and had clinched [his]47-medlicot hostility by employing [a servant dismissed from the very run out of which [he]47-medlicot had bought [[his]47-medlicot land]1736-his land]1735-a servant dismissed from the very run out of which he had bought his land . “[1078-no one else] It is hard to say , ” [he]0-i replied at length , “[1078-no one else] who have grudges , as against whom , or why . [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i have a great grudge against [you]1079-you , if the truth is to be known ; but [I]0-i sha’n’t burn down [[your]1079-you mill]1080-your mill . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m sure [you]1079-you wo n’t . ” “[1079-you] Nor yet say worse of [you]1079-you behind [your]1079-you back than [I]0-i will to [your]1079-you face . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t want [you]1079-you to think that [you]1079-you have occasion to speak ill of [me]0-i , either one way or the other . What [I]0-i mean is this — [I]0-i do n’t quite think that the evidence against [Nokes]58-nokes is strong enough to justify [me]0-i in sending [him]58-nokes away ; but [I]0-i ’ll keep an eye on [him]58-nokes as well as [I]0-i can . It seems that [he]58-nokes left [[our]1081-our place]1082-our place early this morning ; but [the men]292-the men are not supposed to be there on Sundays , and of course [he]58-nokes does as [he]58-nokes pleases with [himself]58-nokes . ” The conversation then dropped , and in a little time [Harry]65-harry made some excuse for leaving [them]292-the men , and returned to [the house]226-the house alone , promising , however , that [he]0-i would not start for [his]0-i night ’s ride till after the party had come back to [the station]249-the station . “[292-the men] There is no hurry at all , ” [he]0-i said ; “[0-i] [I]0-i sha n’t stir for two hours yet , but [Mickey]49-mickey will be waiting there for stores for [himself]49-mickey and [the German]60-the german . ” “[49-mickey] That means a nobbler for [Mickey]49-mickey , ” said [Kate]41-kate . “[49-mickey] [Either of those men]1084-either of those men would think it a treat to ride ten miles in and ten miles back , with a horse - load of sugar and tea and flour , for the sake of a glass of brandy - and - water . ” “[1085-you] And so would [you]1085-you , ” said [Harry]65-harry , “[1085-you] if [you]1085-you lived in [a hut]1086-a hut by [yourself]1085-you for a fortnight , with nothing to drink but tea without milk . ” [The old lady]524-the old lady and [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote were soon seated on the grass , while [Medlicot]47-medlicot and [Kate Daly]41-kate roamed on together . [Kate]41-kate was [a pretty , modest girl]1740-a pretty , modest girl , timid withal and shy , unused to society , and therefore awkward , but with the natural instincts and aptitudes of [her]41-kate sex . What the glass of brandy - and - water was to [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey after a fortnight ’s solitude in [a bush hut]1741-a bush hut , with tea , dampers , and lumps of mutton , [a young man in the guise of [a gentleman]122-a gentleman]1742-a young man in the guise of a gentleman was to poor [Kate Daly]41-kate . [A brother - in - law]1744-a brother - in - law , let [him]1742-a young man in the guise of a gentleman be ever so good , is after all no better than tea without milk . No doubt [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey often thought about a nobbler in [his]49-mickey thirsty solitude , and so did [Kate]41-kate speculate on what might possibly be the attractions of [a lover]1745-a lover . [Medlicot]47-medlicot probably indulged in no such speculations ; but [the nobbler]1746-the nobbler , when brought close to [his]1087-he lips , was grateful to [him]1087-he as to [others]158-others . That [Kate Daly]41-kate was very pretty [no man]156-no man could doubt . “[1085-you] Is n’t it sad that [he]1087-he should have to ride about all night like that ? ” said [Kate]41-kate , to whom , as was proper , [Harry Heathcote]65-harry at the present moment was of more importance than [any other human being]1749-any other human being . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [he]1087-he likes it . ” “[1087-he] Oh no , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot ; how can [he]1087-he like it ? It is not the hard work [he]1087-he minds , but the constant dread of coming evil . ” “[47-medlicot] The excitement keeps [him]1087-he alive . ” “[47-medlicot] [There]290-there ’s plenty on [a station]1089-a station to keep [a man]128-a man alive in that way at all times . ” “[128-a man] And plenty to keep [ladies]1091-ladies alive too ? ” “[1091-ladies] Oh , [ladies]1091-ladies ! [I]0-i do n’t know that [ladies]1091-ladies have any business in [the bush]218-the bush . [Harry]65-harry ’s trouble is all about [[my]0-i sister]1095-my sister and [the children]767-the children and [me]0-i . [He]65-harry would n’t care a straw for [himself]65-harry . ” “[65-harry] Do [you]0-i think [he]65-harry ’d be better without [a wife]1097-a wife ? ” [Kate]41-kate hesitated for a moment . “[0-i] Well , no . [I]0-i suppose it would be very rough without [Mary]40-mary ; and [he]65-harry ’d be so lonely when [he]65-harry came in . ” “[65-harry] And [nobody]1636-nobody to make [his]65-harry tea . ” “[1636-nobody] Or to look after [his]65-harry things , ” said [Kate]41-kate , earnestly . “[0-i] [I]0-i know it was very rough before [we]1099-we came [here]260-here . [He]65-harry says that [himself]65-harry . There were no regular meals , but just food in a cupboard when [he]65-harry chose to get it . ” “[65-harry] That is not comfortable , certainly . ” “[65-harry] Horrid , [I]0-i should think . [I]0-i suppose it is better for [him]65-harry to be married . [You]1101-you ’ve got [[your]1101-you mother]1102-your mother , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . ” “[47-medlicot] Yes : [I]0-i ’ve got [[my]0-i mother]1103-my mother . ” “[0-i] That makes a difference , does it not ? ” “[1103-my mother] A very great difference . [She]1103-my mother ’ll save [me]0-i from having to go to a cupboard for [my]0-i bread and meat . ” “[1103-my mother] [I]0-i suppose having [a woman]1104-a woman about is better for [a man]128-a man . [They]128-a man have n’t got any thing else to do , and therefore [they]128-a man can look to things . ” “[0-i] Do [you]0-i help to look to things ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i do something . [I]0-i often feel ashamed to think how very little it is . As for that , [I]0-i ’m not wanted at all . ” “[0-i] So that [you]0-i ’re free to go elsewhere ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i did n’t mean that , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot ; only [I]0-i know [I]0-i ’m not of much use . ” “[0-i] But if [you]0-i had [a house of [your]0-i own]1106-a house of your own ? ” “[0-i] [Gangoil]65-harry is [[my]0-i home]1107-my home just as much as [it]1108-it is [Mary]40-mary ’s ; and [I]0-i sometimes feel that [Harry]65-harry is just as good to [me]0-i as [he]65-harry is to [Mary]40-mary . ” “[0-i] [[Your]0-i sister]1109-your sister will never leave [Gangoil]65-harry . ” “[1109-your sister] Not unless [Harry]65-harry gets [another station]1110-another station . ” “[65-harry] But [you]0-i will have to be transplanted some day . ” [Kate]41-kate merely chucked up [her]41-kate head and pouted [her]41-kate lips , as though to show that the proposition was one which did not deserve an answer . “[65-harry] [You]0-i ’ll marry [a squatter]1419-a squatter , of course , [Miss Daly]66-miss daly ? ” “[66-miss daly] [I]0-i do n’t suppose [I]0-i shall ever marry [any body]1471-any body , [Mr. Medlicot]47-medlicot . ” “[47-medlicot] [You]0-i would n’t marry [any one but a squatter]1113-any one but a squatter ? [I]0-i can quite understand that . [The squatters]489-the squatters [here]260-here are what [the lords]1116-the lords and [the country gentlemen]1117-the country gentlemen are at [home]103-home . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t even picture to [myself]0-i what sort of life [people]1472-people live at [home]103-home . ” Both [Medlicot]47-medlicot and [Kate Daly]41-kate meant [England]8-england when [they]1750-they spoke of [home]103-home . “[0-i] There is n’t so much difference as [people]1472-people think . [Classes]1122-classes hang together just in the same way ; only [I]0-i think there ’s a little more exclusiveness here than there was there . ” In answer to this , [Kate]41-kate asserted with innocent eagerness that [she]41-kate was not at all exclusive , and that if ever [she]41-kate married [any one]1493-any one [she]41-kate ’d marry [the man [she]41-kate liked]1753-the man she liked . “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [you]1123-you ’d like [me]0-i , ” said [Medlicot]47-medlicot . “[1123-you] That ’s nonsense , ” said [Kate]41-kate , in a low , timid whisper , hurrying away to rejoin [the other ladies]1754-the other ladies . [She]41-kate could speculate on the delights of the beverage as would [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey in [[his]49-mickey hut]1684-his hut ; but when it was first brought to [her]41-kate lips [she]41-kate could only fly away from it . In this respect [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey was the more sensible of [the two]370-the two . No other word was spoken that night between [them]370-the two , but [Kate]41-kate lay awake till morning thinking of the one word that had been spoken . But the secret was kept sacredly within [her]41-kate own bosom . Before [the Medlicots]46-the medlicots started that night [the old lady]524-the old lady made a proposition that [the Heathcotes]52-the heathcotes and [Miss Daly]66-miss daly should eat the Christmas dinner at [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s [Mill]25-mill]468-medlicot ’s mill . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote , thinking perhaps of [[her]42-mrs. heathcote sister]180-her sister , thoroughly liking what [she]42-mrs. heathcote [herself]42-mrs. heathcote had seen of [the Medlicots]46-the medlicots , looked anxiously into [Harry]65-harry ’s face . If [he]65-harry would consent to this , an intimacy would follow , and probably a real friendship be made . “[1123-you] It ’s out of the question , ” [he]65-harry said . The very firmness , however , with which [he]65-harry spoke gave a certain cordiality even to [his]65-harry refusal . “[1123-you] [I]0-i must be at [home]103-home , so that [the men]292-the men may know where to find [me]0-i till [I]0-i go out for the night . ” Then , after a pause , [he]65-harry continued , “[1123-you] As [we]1126-we ca n’t go to [you]1127-you , why should [you]1127-you not come to [us]1126-we ? ” So it was at last decided , much to [Harry]65-harry ’s own astonishment , much to [[his]65-harry wife]104-his wife ’s delight . [Kate]41-kate , therefore , when [she]41-kate lay awake , thinking of the one word that had been spoken , knew that there would be an opportunity for another word . [Medlicot]47-medlicot drove [[his]47-medlicot mother]488-his mother [home]103-home safely , and , after [he]47-medlicot had taken [her]488-his mother into [the house]226-the house , encountered [Nokes]58-nokes on [his]47-medlicot return from [Boolabong]18-boolabong , as has been told at the close of the last chapter . On the Monday morning [Harry]65-harry came [home]103-home as usual , and , as usual , went to bed after [his]65-harry breakfast . “[1127-you] [I]0-i would n’t care about the heat if it were not for the wind , ” [he]0-i said to [[his]0-i wife]104-his wife , as [he]0-i threw [himself]0-i down . “[0-i] The wind carries it so , [I]0-i suppose . ” “[0-i] Yes ; and it comes from just the wrong side — from the northwest . There have been half a dozen fires about to - day . ” “[0-i] During the night , [you]0-i mean . ” “[0-i] No ; yesterday — Sunday . [I]0-i can not make out whether [they]1128-they come by [themselves]1128-they . They certainly are not all made by incendiaries . ” “[1128-they] Accidents , perhaps . ” “[1128-they] Well , yes . [Somebody]1496-somebody drops a match , and the sun ignites it . But the chances are much against a fire like that spreading . Care is wanted to make it spread . As far as [I]0-i can learn , the worst fires have not been just after midday , when , of course , the heat is greater , but in the early night , before the dews have come . All the same , [I]0-i feel that [I]0-i know nothing about it — nothing at all . Do n’t let [me]0-i sleep long . ” In spite of this injunction , [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote determined that [he]0-i should sleep all day if [he]0-i would . Even the nights were fearfully hot and sultry , and on this Monday morning [he]0-i had come [home]103-home much fatigued . [He]0-i would be out again at sunset , and now [he]0-i should have what rest nature would allow [him]0-i . But in this resolve [she]42-mrs. heathcote was opposed by [Jacko]51-jacko , who came in at eleven , and requested to see [the master]193-the master . [Jacko]51-jacko had been over with [the German]415-the german ; and , as [he]51-jacko explained to [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote , [they]1769-they two had been in and out , sometimes sleeping and sometimes watching . But now [he]51-jacko wanted to see [the master]193-the master , and under no persuasion would impart [his]51-jacko information to [the mistress]1771-the mistress . [The poor wife]1772-the poor wife , anxious as [she]1772-the poor wife was that [[her]1772-the poor wife husband]116-her husband should sleep , did not dare in these perilous times to ignore [Jacko]51-jacko and [his]51-jacko information , and therefore gently woke [the sleeper]1774-the sleeper . In a few minutes [Jacko]51-jacko was standing by [the young squatter]461-the young squatter ’s bedside , and [Harry Heathcote]65-harry , quite awake , was sitting up and listening . “[43-georgie] [George Brownbie]43-georgie ’s at [Boolabong]18-boolabong . ” That at first was the gravamen of [Jacko]51-jacko ’s news . “[43-georgie] [I]0-i know that already , [Jacko]51-jacko . ” “[51-jacko] [My]0-i word ! ” exclaimed [Jacko]51-jacko . In those parts [Georgie Brownbie]43-georgie was regarded almost as [the Evil One]1776-the evil one [himself]43-georgie , and [Jacko]51-jacko , knowing what mischief was , as it were , in the word , thought that [he]51-jacko was entitled to bread and jam , if not to a nobbler itself , in bringing such tidings to [Gangoil]65-harry . “[51-jacko] Is that all ? ” asked [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote . “[72-bos] And [Bos]72-bos is at [Boolabong]18-boolabong , and [Bill Nokes]58-nokes was there all Sunday , and [Jerry Brownbie]77-jerry ’s been out with [Bos]72-bos and [Georgie]43-georgie . ” “[77-jerry] [The old man]763-the old man would n’t say any thing of that kind , [Jacko]51-jacko . ” “[763-the old man] [The old man]763-the old man ! [He]763-the old man knows nothing about it . [My]0-i word ! [they]1132-they do n’t tell [him]763-the old man about nothing . ” “[80-tom] Or [Tom]80-tom ? ” “[80-tom] [Tom]80-tom ’s away in [prison]844-prison . [They]1132-they always cotches the best when [they]1132-they want to send [’em]1134-’em to [prison]844-prison . If [they]1132-they ’d lock up [Jerry]77-jerry and [Georgie]43-georgie and [Jack]78-jack ! [My]0-i word ! yes . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i think [they]1132-they ’re arranging it all at [Boolabong]18-boolabong ? ” “[1132-they] In course [they]1132-they are . ” “[1132-they] [I]0-i do n’t see why [Boscobel]53-boscobel should n’t be at [Boolabong]18-boolabong without intending [me]0-i any harm . Of course [he]53-boscobel ’d go [there]290-there when [he]53-boscobel left [Gangoil]65-harry . That ’s where [they]1132-they all go . ” “[58-nokes] And [Bill Nokes]58-nokes , [Mr. Harry]37-harry ? ” “[37-harry] And [Bill Nokes]58-nokes too . Though why [he]58-nokes should travel so far from [his]58-nokes work this weather [I]0-i ca n’t say . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i word ! no , [Mr. Harry]37-harry . ” “[37-harry] Did [you]37-harry see any fires about [your]37-harry way last night ? ” [Jacko]51-jacko shook [his]51-jacko head . “[37-harry] [You]37-harry go into [the kitchen]1456-the kitchen and get something to eat , and wait for [me]0-i . [I]0-i shall be out before long now . ” Though [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had made light of the assemblage of evil spirits at [Boolabong]18-boolabong which had seemed so important to [Jacko]51-jacko , [he]37-harry by no means did regard the news as unessential . Of [[Nokes]58-nokes ’s villany]58-nokes [he]37-harry was convinced . Of [Boscobel]53-boscobel [he]37-harry had imprudently made [a second enemy]1777-a second enemy at a most inauspicious time . [Georgie Brownbie]43-georgie had long been [[his]37-harry bitter foe]1778-his bitter foe . [He]37-harry had prosecuted and , perhaps , persecuted [Georgie]43-georgie for various offenses ; but as [Georgie]43-georgie was supposed to be as much at war with [[his]43-georgie own brethren]1779-his own brethren as with [the rest of [the world]1427-the world]1780-the rest of the world at large , [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had not thought much of [that miscreant]1782-that miscreant in the present emergency . But if [the miscreant]1783-the miscreant were in truth at [Boolabong]18-boolabong , and if evil things were being plotted against [Gangoil]65-harry , [Georgie]43-georgie would certainly be among [the conspirators]1784-the conspirators . Soon after noon [Harry]37-harry was on horseback and [Jacko]51-jacko was at [his]37-harry heels . The heat was more intense than ever . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had twisted round [Harry]37-harry ’s hat a long white scarf , called a puggeree , though [we]1785-we are by no means sure of [our]1785-we spelling . [Jacko]51-jacko had spread a very dirty fragment of an old white handkerchief on [his]51-jacko head , and wore [his]51-jacko hat over it . [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had begged [Harry]37-harry to take a large cotton parasol , and [he]37-harry had nearly consented , being unable at last to reconcile [himself]37-harry to the idea of riding with such an accoutrement even in the bush . “[0-i] The heat ’s a bore , ” [he]0-i said , “[0-i] but [I]0-i ’m not a bit afraid of it as long as [I]0-i keep moving . Yes , [I]0-i ’ll be back to dinner , though [I]0-i wo n’t say when , and [I]0-i wo n’t say for how long . It will be the same thing all day to - morrow . [I]0-i wish with all [my]0-i heart [those people]1138-those people were not coming . ” [He]0-i rode straight away to [the German ’s hut]1415-the german ’s hut , which was on the northwestern extremity of [[his]0-i further paddock]1787-his further paddock in that direction . From thence the western fence ran in a southerly direction , nearly straight to [the river]164-the river . Beyond the fence was a strip of land , in some parts over a mile broad , in others not much over a quarter of a mile , which [he]0-i claimed as belonging to [Gangoil]65-harry , but over which [the Brownbies]65-harry had driven [their]1138-those people cattle since the fence had been made , under the pretense that the fence marked the boundary of two runs . Against this assumption [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote had remonstrated frequently , had driven the cattle back , and had exercised the ownership of [a Crown tenant]1789-a crown tenant in such fashion as the nature of [his]0-i occupation allowed . Beyond [this strip]1790-this strip was [Boolabong]18-boolabong ; [the house at [Boolabong]18-boolabong]1791-the house at boolabong being not above three miles distant from the fence , and not above four miles from [the German ’s hut]1415-the german ’s hut . So that [the Brownbies]65-harry were in truth [much nearer neighbors to [the German]60-the german]1793-much nearer neighbors to the german than was [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote and [[his]0-i family]1794-his family . But between [the German]60-the german and [the Brownbies]65-harry there raged an internecine feud . No doubt [Harry Heathcote]65-harry , in [his]65-harry heart , liked [the German]60-the german all the better on this account ; but it behooved [him]65-harry both as [a master]793-a master and [a magistrate]1796-a magistrate to regard reports against [Boolabong]18-boolabong coming from [the German]60-the german with something of suspicion . Now [Jacko]51-jacko had been introduced to [Gangoil]65-harry under German auspices , and had soon come to a decision that it would be a good thing and a just to lock up [all the Brownbies in [the great jail of [the colony]146-the colony at [Brisbane]7-brisbane]1798-the great jail of the colony at brisbane]1797-all the brownbies in the great jail of the colony at brisbane . [He]51-jacko probably knew nothing of law or justice in the abstract , but [he]51-jacko greatly valued law when exercised against those [he]51-jacko hated . The western fence of which mention has been made ran down to [the Mary River]4-the mary river , hitting [it]4-the mary river about four miles west of [Medlicot ’s Mill]11-medlicot ’s mill ; so that there was [a considerable portion of [the Gangoil run]235-the gangoil run]1800-a considerable portion of the gangoil run having a frontage to [the water]1621-the water . As has been before said , [[Medlicot]47-medlicot ’s plantation]1803-medlicot ’s plantation was about fourteen miles distant from [the house at [Boolabong]18-boolabong]1791-the house at boolabong , and the distance from [the Gangoil house]1805-the gangoil house to that of [the Brownbies]65-harry was about the same . The oppressiveness of the day was owing more to the hot wind than to the sun itself . This wind , coming from [the arid plains of [the interior]1807-the interior]1806-the arid plains of the interior , brought with it a dry , suffocating heat . On this occasion it was odious to [Harry Heathcote]65-harry , not so much on account of [its]65-harry own intrinsic abominations , as because it might cause a fire to sweep across [his]65-harry run from [its]65-harry western boundary . Just beyond the boundary there lay [Boolabong]18-boolabong , and there were collected [[his]65-harry enemies]152-his enemies . A fire that should have passed for a mile or so across [the pastures]1809-the pastures outside and beyond [[his]65-harry own farm]1810-his own farm would be altogether unextinguishable by the time that it had reached [[his]65-harry paddock]1811-his paddock . [The Brownbies]65-harry , as [he]65-harry knew well , would care nothing for burning a patch of [their]1812-their own grass . [Their]1812-their stock , if [they]1812-their had any at the present moment , were much too few in number to be affected by such a loss . [The Brownbies]65-harry had not [a yard of fencing to be burned]1813-a yard of fencing to be burned ; and a fire , if once it got a hold on the edge of [their]1812-their run , would pass on away from [them]1812-their , right across [[Harry]65-harry ’s pastures]1814-harry ’s pastures and [[Harry]65-harry ’s fences]1815-harry ’s fences . If such were the case , [he]65-harry would have quite enough to do to drive [his]65-harry sheep from the fire , and it might be that many of [them]1812-their also would perish in the flames . The catastrophe might even be so bad , so frightful , that [the shed and station]1816-the shed and station and all should go ; though , in thinking of all the fires of which [he]65-harry had heard , [he]65-harry could remember none that had spread with fatality such as that . [He]65-harry found [Karl Bender]59-karl bender in [[his]65-harry hut]1684-his hut asleep . [The man]451-the man was soon up , apologizing for [his]451-the man somnolence , and preparing tea for [[his]451-the man master]337-his master ’s entertainment . “[0-i] It is not Christmas like at [home]103-home at all ; is it , [Mr. ‘ Eathcote]73-mr. ‘ eathcote ? [Dear]1452-dear , no ! Them red divils is there ready to give [us]1141-us a Christmas roasting . ” Then [he]65-harry told how [he]65-harry had boldly ridden up to [Boolabong]18-boolabong that morning , and had seen [Georgie]43-georgie and [Boscobel]53-boscobel with [his]65-harry own eyes . When asked what [they]1820-they had said to [him]65-harry , [he]65-harry replied that [he]65-harry did not wait till any thing had been said , but had hurried away as fast as [his]65-harry horse could carry [him]65-harry . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll go up to [Boolabong]18-boolabong [myself]0-i , ” said [Harry]65-harry . “[0-i] [My]0-i word ! [They]1142-they ’ll just about knock [your]1143-your head off , ” suggested [Jacko]51-jacko . [Karl Bender]59-karl bender also thought that the making of such a visit would be a source of danger . But [Heathcote]65-harry explained that any personal attack was not to be apprehended from [these men]802-these men . “[1142-they] That ’s not [their]1142-they game , ” [he]65-harry said , arguing that [men who premeditated a secret outrage]1822-men who premeditated a secret outrage would not probably be tempted into personal violence . The horror of the position lay in this — that though a fire should rise up almost under the feet of [men who were known to be hostile to him , and whose characters were acknowledged to be bad]1823-men who were known to be hostile to him , and whose characters were acknowledged to be bad , still would there be no evidence against [them]1142-they . It was known to [all men that , at periods of heat such as that which was now raging , fires]1824-all men that , at periods of heat such as that which was now raging , fires were common . Every day [the pastures]1809-the pastures were in flames , here , there , and every where . It was said , indeed , that there existed no evidence of fires in the bush till [men]130-men had come with [their]130-men flocks . But then there had been no smoking , no boiling of pots , no camping out , till [men]130-men had come , and no matches . [Every one around]1828-every one around might be sure that some particular fire had been the work of [an incendiary]1829-an incendiary , might be able to name [the culprit who had done the deed]1830-the culprit who had done the deed ; and yet [no jury]1831-no jury could convict [the miscreant]1783-the miscreant . Watchfulness was the best security , watchfulness day and night till rain should come ; and [Heathcote]65-harry calculated that it would be better for [him]65-harry that [[his]65-harry enemies]152-his enemies should know that [he]65-harry was watchful . [He]65-harry would go up among [them]152-his enemies and show [them]152-his enemies that [he]65-harry was not ashamed to speak to [them]152-his enemies of [his]65-harry anxiety . [They]152-his enemies could hear nothing by [his]65-harry coming which [they]152-his enemies did not already know . [They]152-his enemies were well aware that [he]65-harry was on the watch , and it might be well that [they]152-his enemies should know also how close [his]65-harry watch was kept . [He]65-harry took [the German]60-the german and [Jacko]51-jacko with [him]65-harry , but left [them]152-his enemies with [their]152-his enemies horses about a mile on [[the Boolabong]29-the boolabong side of [his]65-harry own fence]1834-the boolabong side of his own fence , nigh to [the extreme boundary of [the Debatable Land]30-the debatable land]1835-the extreme boundary of the debatable land . [They]152-his enemies knew [his]65-harry whistle , and were to ride to [him]65-harry at once should [he]65-harry call [them]152-his enemies . [He]65-harry had left [the house]226-the house about noon , saying that [he]65-harry would be [home]103-home to dinner — which , however , on such occasions , was held to be a feast movable over a wide space of time . But on this occasion [the women]601-the women expected [him]65-harry to come early , as it was [his]65-harry intention to be out again as soon as it should be dark . [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler was asked to have the dinner ready at six . During the day [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote was backward and forward in [the kitchen]1456-the kitchen . Then was something wrong [she]42-mrs. heathcote knew , but could not quite discern the evil . [Sing Sing]54-sing sing , [the cook]1840-the cook , was more than ordinarily alert ; but [Sing Sing]54-sing sing , [the cook]1840-the cook , was not much trusted . [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler was “[1142-they] as good as [the Bank]1144-the bank , ” as far as that went , having lived with [old Mr. Daly]88-old mr. daly when [he]65-harry was prosperous ; but [she]45-mrs. growler was apt to be downhearted , and on the present occasion was more than usually low in spirits . Whenever [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote spoke , [she]42-mrs. heathcote wept . At six o’clock [she]42-mrs. heathcote came into [the parlor]335-the parlor with a budget of news . [Sing Sing]54-sing sing , [the cook]1840-the cook , had been gone for the last half hour , leaving the leg of mutton at the fire . It soon became clear to [them]1844-them that [he]65-harry had altogether absconded . “[1142-they] Them rats always does leave [a falling house]1145-a falling house , ” said [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler . At seven o’clock the sun was down , though the gloom of the tropical evening had not yet come . [The two ladies]196-the two ladies went out to the gate , which was but a few yards from [the veranda]174-the veranda , and there stood listening for the sound of [Harry]65-harry ’s horse . The low moaning of the wind through the trees could be heard , but it was so gentle , continuous , and unaltered that it seemed to be no more than a vehicle for other sounds , and was as death - like as silence itself . [The gate of [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock through which [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote must pass on [his]65-harry way [home]103-home]1847-the gate of the horse paddock through which heathcote must pass on his way home was nearly a mile distant ; but [the road]855-the road there was hard , and [they]196-the two ladies knew that [they]196-the two ladies could hear from there the fall of [his]65-harry horse ’s feet . There [they]196-the two ladies stood from seven to nearly eight , whispering a word now and then to [each other]647-each other , listening always , but in vain . Looking away to the west every now and then , [they]196-the two ladies fancied that [they]196-the two ladies could see the sky glow with flames , and then [they]196-the two ladies would tell [each other]647-each other that it was fancy . The evening grew darker and still darker , but no sound was heard through the moaning wind . From time to time [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler came out to [them]196-the two ladies , declaring [her]45-mrs. growler fears in no measured terms . “[1142-they] Well , [marm]1146-marm , [I]0-i do declare [I]0-i think [we]1147-we ’d better go away out of this . ” “[0-i] Go away , [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler ! What nonsense ! Where can [we]1147-we go to ? ” “[45-mrs. growler] [The mill]484-the mill would be nearest , [ma’am]1149-ma’am , and [we]1147-we should be safe [there]290-there . [I]0-i ’m sure [Mrs. Medlicot]48-mrs. medlicot would take [us]1147-we in . ” “[48-mrs. medlicot] Why should [you]1151-you not be safe [here]260-here ? ” said [Kate]41-kate . “[1151-you] [That wretched Chinese]1153-that wretched chinese has n’t gone and left [us]1147-we for nothing , [miss]1154-miss , and what would [we]1147-we [three lone women]1155-three lone women do here if [all [them]1156-all them brownbies [Brownbies]65-harry]1156-all them brownbies came down upon [us]1147-we ? Why do [n’t master]1157-n’t master come back ? [He]1157-n’t master ought to come back ; ought n’t [he]1157-n’t master , [ma’am]1149-ma’am ? [He]1157-n’t master never do think what [lone women]1159-lone women are . ” [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote took [[her]42-mrs. heathcote husband]116-her husband ’s part very strongly , and gave [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler as hard a scolding as [she]42-mrs. heathcote knew how to pronounce . But [her]42-mrs. heathcote own courage was giving way much as [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler ’s had done . “[1157-n’t master] [We]1147-we are bound to stay [here]260-here , ” [she]42-mrs. heathcote said ; “[1147-we] and if the worst comes , [we]1147-we must bear it as [others]158-others have done before [us]1147-we . ” Then [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler was very sulky , and , retreating to [the kitchen]1456-the kitchen , sobbed there in solitude . “[41-kate] Oh , [Kate]41-kate , [I]0-i do wish [he]1157-n’t master would come , ” said [the elder sister]186-the elder sister . “[41-kate] Are [you]41-kate afraid ? ” “[41-kate] [It]1162-it is so desolate , and [he]1157-n’t master may be so far off , and [we]1147-we could n’t get to [him]1157-n’t master if any thing happened , and [we]1147-we should n’t know . ” Then [they]1147-we were again silent , and remained without exchanging more than a word or two for nearly half an hour . [They]1147-we took hold of [each other]647-each other , and every now and then went to the [kitchen]1857-kitchen door that [the old woman]194-the old woman might be comforted by [their]1147-we presence , but [they]1147-we had no consolation to offer [each other]647-each other . The silence of the bush , and the feeling of great distances , and the dread of calamity almost crushed [them]1147-we . At last there was a distant sound of horse ’s feet . “[1157-n’t master] [I]0-i hear [him]1157-n’t master , ” said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote , rushing forward toward the outer gate of [the horse paddock]306-the horse paddock , followed by [[her]42-mrs. heathcote sister]180-her sister . [Her]42-mrs. heathcote ears were true , but [she]42-mrs. heathcote was doomed to disappointment . [The horseman]1862-the horseman was only [a messenger from [[her]42-mrs. heathcote husband]116-her husband]1863-a messenger from her husband — [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey , [the Irish boundary rider]1865-the irish boundary rider . [He]49-mickey had great tidings to tell , and was so long telling [them]1866-them that [we]1867-we will not attempt to give [them]1866-them in [his]49-mickey own words . The purport of [his]49-mickey story was as follows : [Harry]65-harry had been to [Boolabong House]31-boolabong house , but had found there [no one]339-no one but [the old man]763-the old man . Returning [home]103-home thence toward [his]49-mickey own fence , [he]49-mickey had smelled the smoke of fire , and had found within a furlong of [his]49-mickey path a long ridge of burning grass . According to [Mickey]49-mickey ’s account , it could not have been lighted above a few minutes before [Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote ’s presence on the spot . As it was , it had got too much ahead for [him]49-mickey to put it out single - handed ; a few yards [he]49-mickey might have managed , but — so [Mickey]49-mickey said , probably exaggerating the matter — there was half a quarter of a mile of flame . [He]49-mickey had therefore ridden on before the fire , had called [[his]49-mickey own two men]1871-his own two men to [him]49-mickey , and had at once lighted the grass [himself]49-mickey some two hundred yards in front , making a second fire , but so keeping it down that it should be always under control . Before the hinder flames had caught [him]49-mickey , [Bender]59-karl bender and [Jacko]51-jacko had been with [him]49-mickey , and [they]1871-his own two men had thus managed to consume the fuel which , had it remained there , would have fed the fire which was too strong to be mastered . By watching the extremities of the line of fire , [they]1871-his own two men overpowered it , and so the damage was for the moment at an end . The method of dealing with [the enemy]1872-the enemy was so well known in [the bush]218-the bush , and had been so often canvassed in the hearing of [the two sisters]611-the two sisters , that it was clearly intelligible to [them]1871-his own two men . The evil had been met in the proper way , and the remedy had been effective . But why did not [Harry]65-harry come [home]103-home ? [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey , after [his]49-mickey fashion , explained that too . [The ladies]471-the ladies were not to wait dinner . [The master]193-the master felt [himself]193-the master obliged to remain out at night , and had gotten food at [[the German]415-the german ’s hut]1415-the german ’s hut . [He]193-the master , [Mickey]49-mickey , was commissioned to return with a flask full of brandy , as it would be necessary that [Harry]65-harry , with all [the men whom [he]65-harry could trust]1880-the men whom he could trust , should be “[1157-n’t master] on the rampage ” all night . [This small body]1881-this small body was to consist of [Harry]65-harry [himself]65-harry , of [the German]415-the german , of [Jacko]51-jacko , and , according to the story as at present told , especially of [Mickey O’Dowd]49-mickey . Much as [she]1883-she would have wished to have kept [the man]451-the man at [the station]249-the station for protection , [she]1883-she did not think of disobeying [[her]1883-she husband]116-her husband ’s orders . So [Mickey]49-mickey was fed , and then sent back with the flask — with tidings also as to the desertion of [that wretched cook]1887-that wretched cook , [Sing Sing]54-sing sing . “[0-i] [I]0-i shall sit [here]260-here all night , ” said [Mrs. Heathcote]42-mrs. heathcote to [[her]1883-she sister]180-her sister . “[0-i] As things are , [I]0-i shall not think of going to bed . ” [Kate]41-kate declared that [she]41-kate would also sit in [the veranda]174-the veranda all night ; and , as a matter of course , [they]1890-they were joined by [Mrs. Growler]45-mrs. growler . [They]1890-they had been so seated about an hour when [Kate Daly]41-kate declared that [the heavens]1891-the heavens were on fire . [The two young women]106-the two young women jumped up , flew to the gate , and found that the whole western horizon was lurid with a dark red light . [Harry Heathcote]65-harry had on this occasion entertained no doubt whatever that the fire had been intentional and premeditated . A lighted torch must have been dragged along the grass , so as to ignite a line many yards long all at the same time . [He]65-harry had been luckily near enough to the spot to see almost the commencement of the burning , and was therefore aware of its form and circumstances . [He]65-harry almost wondered that [he]65-harry had not seen the figure of [the man who had drawn the torch]1893-the man who had drawn the torch , or at any rate heard [his]65-harry steps . [Pursuit]89-pursuit would have been out of the question , as [his]65-harry work was wanted at the moment to extinguish the flames .
